Finding ID Audit Year Audit ID Audit Title Recommendation ID Recommendation Type Recommendation Status Severity Finding Title Finding Description Category Recommendation Details Issue Date Initial Deadline Current Deadline Closing Date Auditee Submission Date No. of Deadline Shifts Relevant Legal Entities Open for Relevant Legal Entities Recommendation Owner - Legal Entity Action Plan Responsible Responsible Auditor Audit Lead Finding Owner - Responsible Board Member Recom Owner - Responsible Board Member Recommendation Owner - Division Recommendation Owner - Area Recommendation Owner - Managing Director Recommendation Owner - Business Unit Management Response Risk Recommendation Owner - Head of BU Board member Root cause Finding source Finding Tag Reason for extension Rationale for extension                                                                  
2022-027_F12 2022 2022-027 Cyber & Information Security [DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL] 2022-027_F12-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of adherence to min. control requirements and definition of roles and responsibilities for IAM According to EMIR RTS 153 Article 4, “a CCP shall have adequate internal control mechanisms to assist the board in monitoring and assessing the adequacy and effectiveness of a its risk management policies, procedures and systems.”
Moreover, according to BaFin Supervisory Requirements for IT in Financial Institutions (BAIT) 2.2 “the management is responsible for ensuring that the regulations governing the IT structure and IT process organization are defined on the basis of the IT strategy and that they are adjusted promptly in the event of changes to activities and processes. It must be ensured that these regulations are implemented effectively.” According to CSSF Circular 20/750, point 31“Financial institutions should define, document and implement procedures for logical access control (identity and access management). These procedures should be implemented, enforced, monitored and periodically reviewed. The procedures should also include controls for monitoring anomalies”

The unit Identity & Access Management (ICA) created the Identity and Access Management Guideline V1.3.2. The aim of this guideline is to define an IAM framework and access handling for DBG. The guideline distinguishes between responsibilities for each IAM topic depending on the onboarding status to SailPoint IIQ (AID760) of the target applications (e.g. in most cases Group Security is accountable/responsible if the asset is onboarded, respectively the asset owner is accountable/responsible if the asset is not onboarded).

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the control environment of the 1st line of defence (LoD):
§ Lack of clarity of responsibility to adhere to information security standards issued by Information Security Framework & Governance (ISFG) on topics such as Identity and Access Management (IAM).
§ Lack of clear definition of roles and responsibilities for execution and monitoring of the above-mentioned control requirements.

As a result of the above-mentioned weaknesses in the control environment, Internal Audit detected several cases where asset owners may not have fully met their responsibilities and this was not identified by the current first line control approach, neither in ICA nor in the affected Product IT teams:
§ Reconciliation: aim of the reconciliation is to check if authorisation managed/approved in IIQ correctly reflect the actually assigned authorisation in the target systems. Nevertheless, depending on the connector between IIQ and target application, IIQ may not be able to directly analyse the assigned authorisation within the target application. For example, with the Onboard Administrator Active Directory (OAAD) connector, IIQ is only able to reconcile based on the assigned Active Directory workgroups, whereas additional authorisation directly assigned within the target application would not be identified. A control to detect such bypasses is not established.
§ Usage of central IAM IIQ processes: the onboarding of a target application to IIQ is supported by ICA. After the successful onboarding, the central IAM processes provided by IIQ itself (e.g. provisioning request, recertification etc.) have to be used for/by the target application. Nevertheless, a control (e.g. plausibility check) is not required and not established to monitor if the asset owner of the target application indeed uses the IAM processes provided by IIQ.
Internal Audit noted at least one productive business application which was onboarded for several months without having assigned any users to the onboarded authorisations.
Onboarding status of this business application has been reset during the audit. New planned onboarding finalisation target is February 2023.
§ Completeness of authorisations: as part of the onboarding process, all available target application authorisation are implemented in IIQ. Nevertheless, no central IAM control (e.g. plausibility check) existed to monitor authorisation added to the target application after onboarding, and not published to IIQ. Internal Audit noted that, for the business application C7 (AID021), a mismatch existed between the onboarded IIQ roles and roles actually available in C7. Internal Audit further noted procedures did not require such control be established.
This was due to a change management process omission (no IIQ update for C7) upon implementing ECC roles in C7 subsequent to the initial C7 onboarding to IIQ in September 2019.
The annual C7 risk assessment process (RAP-3570) started in parallel to our audit, with due date 13 December 2022. It identified the missing ECC roles/business users onboarding to IIQ as a risk and started mitigation activities (completion planned by 30 June 2023). Therefore, Internal Audit issued no additional recommendation. An exceptional risk ticket has been created (ISRM-92912).		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Internal Audit recommends IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) to implement oversight and quality assurance measures to ensure the implementation of the Identity and Access Management requirements that will address the weaknesses in the above-mentioned description.
Depending on the outcome of recommendation 2022-027_F12-A01, ownership and due date of this recommendation may be changed to align with the newly defined owner and related corrective action plan after framework definition.		 22.12.2022 10.06.2024 31.12.2025 24.05.2024 1 CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Boris Link, Oliver Vossmann Karl Ulber Anna Kenar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Lack of adherence to minimum control requirements and definition of roles and responsibilities for IAM in first Line of Defence represents a material violation of internal and external provisions related to the information security framework. This could lead to regulatory risks (e.g. BAIT 6.5) as well as operational risks (such as the detailed deficiencies identified above, which may in turn result in incorrect or obsolete access rights remaining undetected, facilitating misuse or operational incidents). Boris Link CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Singapore Branch) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Core audit process - obsolete from 01 Jan 2024 Dependency on other Team(s), SME, Consultants, External Find As discussed and in line with the actions for A01, remediation for some parts of the finding is dependent on Ameli. Especially reconciliation and digital authorization concepts. As agreed, we will evidence design effectiveness and first onboardings / implementations for closure. Full implementation to be tracked via external findings with final due date 31 Dec 2026.
2024-018_F05 2024 2024-018 CCAG Microsoft Azure & M365 (GITA, DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-018_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in Microsoft M365 Security Incident Management, E-Discovery and Cloud Forensics Internal Audit (IA) noted for Microsoft M365 Security Response Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) the following weaknesses:
1. Contained inconsistent terminology (e.g. referencing process actors). (SEF-01-01)
2. Lack of an overarching RACI matrix for roles and responsibilities. (SEF-01-01)
3. Contained non-traceable references to sections and other documents. (SEF-01-01)
4. Did not include sufficient details on key concepts such as incident closure criteria, application of incident prioritisation factors or response strategies based on compromise scenarios. (SEF-01-01)
5. Did not mention in the SOP all used metrics, e.g. not TTE (Time to Engage) metrics or TTPIR (Time to Post Incident Review). (SEF-01-01)
6. Did not include incident classification types, e.g. APT or Engineering Bug (SEF-01-01)
7. Inconsistent incident severity definitions in comparison to those used in the incident tracking system, for example 2-Urgent Alert in SOP and 2-Medium in the tool (SEF-06-01)

Further, the following SEF effectiveness deficiencies were identified:
8. Post-Incident Reviews (PIR) were either conducted and closed before the incidents were mitigated or closed or a complete PIR was not conducted, although the incident ticket was marked as having a PIR; instead, only a privacy Root Cause Analysis (RCA) was done, which did not include proper lessons learned or actual post-incident activities. (SEF-03-02)
9. Metrics to track the time between breach declaration and customer notification were not identified. Incorrect values to track ‘Time to acknowledge’ and missing values to track ‘Time to declare’ were presented in the dashboards. (SEF-05-01)
10. Information about four GDPR-notifiable incidents (~22% of the total population of 18 GDPR notifiable incidents) was communicated past the SLA   of 72 hours (ranging from 73 hours to 352   hours). (SEF-05-01)
11. Time limits (e.g., SLAs, targets, thresholds) were not established for the timeliness of breach declaration once customer impact was confirmed. (SEF-07-01)

The identified items were likely caused by a lack of awareness by the Microsoft process owners of financial institutions’ regulatory demands.

External provisions require that the institution shall appropriately manage the risks associated with outsourcing and shall monitor the provision of the outsourced activities and processes in a due and proper manner.
In case of identified IT risks, appropriate monitoring and management processes shall be set up.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) to assess the measures as outlined and implemented by Microsoft’s management response (appendix 6.3). Particularly to:
1-Assess the documents as outlined and implemented by Microsoft’s management response. Specifically, to verify that the Security Response SOP has been updated to clarify inconsistencies outlined in the finding description.
2-Verify results of Microsoft Security Future Initiative (SFI) to ensure alignment between incident management and communication process.

In case of not fully remediated risks, GAL might consider risk measures to manage the residual risk. 		 26.03.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Aniket Deshpande, Benoit Krier, François Leveling, Samira Amirli Yigit Gullu Oliver Wolff CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT Cloud Operations (Dpt) Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in M365 Security Incident Management, E-Discovery and Cloud Forensics may hinder the efficiency and timeliness of incident response. Consequently, this may lead to increased exposure of customer data and affect operational stability. Deficiencies in the traceability of security incident records and related cases pose risks to potential forensic efforts and the effective mitigation of incidents if significant dependencies are not identified timely. These weaknesses represent a material breach of external requirements.   François Leveling CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - External Outsourcing framework 70,1,75,7,CSDR L2 2017/392
2024-018_F08 2024 2024-018 CCAG Microsoft Azure & M365 (GITA, DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-018_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Deficiencies in Microsoft M365 documentation Internal Audit noted for Microsoft M365 the following documentation deficiencies in the areas of Cryptography, Encryption and Key Management (CEK) and Infrastructure and Virtualisation Security (IVS):
1. CEK: The CEK SOP did not contain the following information (CEK-01-01):
a. Pre-notification periods for manual certificate rotation.
b. Keys rotation schedules for BitLocker Data Recovery Agent (DRA) certificates and Trusted Platform Module (TPM) keys rotation schedule.
c. Requirements or exceptions regarding manual rotated certifications.
Further, the SOP allowed Hash-Based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) with a 112-bit key, which contradicted the online version of the SOP that required a minimum of 128 bits.
2. CEK: The “Fundamentals M365 Security Requirements” SOP required to rotate BitLocker DRA Certificates every 90 days, while the template for creating DRA secrets set the default rotation to 270-days. A changed policy had been implemented by   end of fieldwork (mitigated during the fieldwork). (CEK-03-01)

The identified items were likely caused by a lack of awareness by the Microsoft process owners of financial institutions’ regulatory demands.

External provisions require that the institution shall appropriately manage the risks associated with outsourcing and shall monitor the provision of the outsourced activities and processes in a due and proper manner.
In case of identified IT risks, appropriate monitoring and management processes shall be set up.		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) to assess the controls as outlined and implemented by Microsoft’s management response (appendix 6.3), particularly to review the update of the SOPs.

In case of not fully remediated risks, GAL might consider risk measures to manage the residual risk.		 26.03.2025 16.03.2026 16.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Aniket Deshpande, Benoit Krier, François Leveling, Samira Amirli Yigit Gullu Oliver Wolff CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT Cloud Operations (Dpt) Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Without clear guidelines on rotation of manual certificates, risk exist that certificates expire or being compromised, leaving sensitive data vulnerable to unauthorised access. Missing definitions of rotation schedule for BitLocker DRA certificates could lead to these certificates becoming compromised allowing unauthorised access to encrypted data.
Incomplete or outdated procedures can cause confusion, errors, and inefficiencies, reducing overall productivity and effectiveness.

Overall, this represents a minor risk exposure due to the violation of external provisions. 		 François Leveling CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - External Outsourcing framework 70,1,75,7,CSDR L2 2017/392
2024-019_F01 2024 2024-019 CCAG Google (GITA, DBAG, ECAG,CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-019_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes Internal Audit (IA) identified the following gaps within Google’s Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability (STA) process, specifically in the supply chain inventory and supply chain risk management processes.

1. Disclosure of sub-sub-processors
The review has shown that Google does not proactively notify customers regarding identified sub-processing activities beyond the first level of (sub ) processors engaged by Google. Google customers, as data controllers, need to ensure that, in the whole supply chain, only those processors that provide sufficient guarantee to meet the GDPR requirements will process data. Restricting customer information violates external provisions such as GDPR and Google’s own Cloud Data Processing Addendum (CDPA) requiring disclosure to data controllers, the entire chain of sub-processors.  
Google did not perform an analysis of whether a service provider acts as a sub-processor in line with GDPR and all underlying levels of sub-processing. This requires the same quality of information before the provider gets access to customer data as for the first level of sub-processing. If the provider was not identified as processor in line with GDPR, the need to share information still should have been aligned with the general contractual arrangements for nonmaterial vendors and subcontractors.

2. Incomplete documentation of vendor exit strategies
The review of vendor exit strategies identified documentation completeness shortcomings for four out of five vendor categories, namely Cloud Support, Chronicle, Colocation, Security Guards. E.g. some exit strategies mainly covered non-stressed scenarios, but stressed scenarios were not sufficiently addressed. This impacted the description of the team's resiliency strategy to ensure no disruption to business activities, as well as the documentation of continuity processes to ensure service quality to Google customers. Additionally, the description of alternative solutions/transition plans in stressed scenarios and compliance requirements for exiting a material vendor were found insufficient.

For three out of the four exit strategies with identified shortcomings, the necessary updates have been completed during the audit fieldwork and have been provided to CCAG auditors. Only the update of the exit strategy for Colocation remained outstanding: the stressed exit scenario needed to be reflected within the document.

The root cause was attributed to a lack of governance and guidance during the process execution for de-centralised process activities.

EU, German and Luxembourg regulation requires institutions to have an overview and control over the data processing and involved parties including the strategies to terminate any vendor relationship.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) either to implement internal controls to mitigate the risks identified for missing disclosure of sub-sub-processors or to require Google to implement mitigating controls such as outlined in Google’s response (see Appendix A). Alternatively, risk acceptance can be evaluated and requested following DBG’s procedures. 06.03.2025 30.09.2025 31.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jennifer Beate Riedl, Michael Girg, Christian Tüffers Shravankumar Mohankumar André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrast (Dpt) Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes could result in increased risk for information security. Consequently, this could lead to major operational risk, minor financial loss and/or minor reputational loss. Michael Girg CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Lack of Awareness of Group/Cross Funct Processes Outsourcing framework
2024-019_F01 2024 2024-019 CCAG Google (GITA, DBAG, ECAG,CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-019_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes Internal Audit (IA) identified the following gaps within Google’s Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability (STA) process, specifically in the supply chain inventory and supply chain risk management processes.

1. Disclosure of sub-sub-processors
The review has shown that Google does not proactively notify customers regarding identified sub-processing activities beyond the first level of (sub ) processors engaged by Google. Google customers, as data controllers, need to ensure that, in the whole supply chain, only those processors that provide sufficient guarantee to meet the GDPR requirements will process data. Restricting customer information violates external provisions such as GDPR and Google’s own Cloud Data Processing Addendum (CDPA) requiring disclosure to data controllers, the entire chain of sub-processors.  
Google did not perform an analysis of whether a service provider acts as a sub-processor in line with GDPR and all underlying levels of sub-processing. This requires the same quality of information before the provider gets access to customer data as for the first level of sub-processing. If the provider was not identified as processor in line with GDPR, the need to share information still should have been aligned with the general contractual arrangements for nonmaterial vendors and subcontractors.

2. Incomplete documentation of vendor exit strategies
The review of vendor exit strategies identified documentation completeness shortcomings for four out of five vendor categories, namely Cloud Support, Chronicle, Colocation, Security Guards. E.g. some exit strategies mainly covered non-stressed scenarios, but stressed scenarios were not sufficiently addressed. This impacted the description of the team's resiliency strategy to ensure no disruption to business activities, as well as the documentation of continuity processes to ensure service quality to Google customers. Additionally, the description of alternative solutions/transition plans in stressed scenarios and compliance requirements for exiting a material vendor were found insufficient.

For three out of the four exit strategies with identified shortcomings, the necessary updates have been completed during the audit fieldwork and have been provided to CCAG auditors. Only the update of the exit strategy for Colocation remained outstanding: the stressed exit scenario needed to be reflected within the document.

The root cause was attributed to a lack of governance and guidance during the process execution for de-centralised process activities.

EU, German and Luxembourg regulation requires institutions to have an overview and control over the data processing and involved parties including the strategies to terminate any vendor relationship.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) either to implement internal controls to mitigate the risks identified through the incomplete documentation of vendor exit strategies or to require Google to implement mitigating controls such as outlined in Google’s response (see Appendix A). Alternatively, risk acceptance can be evaluated and requested following DBG’s procedures. 06.03.2025 30.09.2025 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jennifer Beate Riedl, Michael Girg, Christian Tüffers Shravankumar Mohankumar André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrast (Dpt) Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes could result in increased risk for information security. Consequently, this could lead to major operational risk, minor financial loss and/or minor reputational loss. Michael Girg CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Lack of Awareness of Group/Cross Funct Processes Outsourcing framework
2024-037_F05 2024 2024-037 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2024-037_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Control weaknesses in Risk Services processes The business procedure 8.2.1.4.32 Own Issues required that the related outgoing emails were labelled as confidential due to the information contained. This confidential information was derived from various reports obtained through StatistiX. In that context, Internal Audit noted the following two issues:

The emails/attachments from StatistiX were not visibly labelled, and considered internal, e.g., when forwarding the info.

Email correspondence between Risk Services staff containing the confidential info were labelled internal.

 

8.2.1.4.18 Clearing Member Price Change Monitoring contained explanations related to the use of search terms for identifying Clearing Members. A diligent use of search terms was important to capture the entire company with all margin pools and clearing funds, and therefore for the understanding of the risk situation. The described four-eyes principle control did however not contain any assessment of the adequacy of the used search term by an additional person.

 

The identified issues were caused by poor design and inadequacy of controls.

 

German regulation requires that the IT systems, related IT processes and other components of the information domain ensure the integrity, availability, authenticity and confidentiality of the data. DBG policy requires that all personnel protect information according to its classification level. All information is to be classified based on its criticality level. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Risk Services (DDQ):

analyze and provide StatistiX with information about which data is considered confidential. Implement the requirements by, amongst others, instructing StatistiX to label the confidential data as such, and having the attachments amended accordingly

remind staff about email requirements related to confidentiality and include a check in the four-eyes principle control and/or take samples throughout the year, as deemed required, to ensure the requirements are met

include in the existing four-eyes principle control an assessment by an additional person of the adequacy of the used search term for identifying Clearing Members  		 11.12.2024 19.02.2025 30.06.2026 19.02.2025 1 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Martina Burianova Randi Montgomery Randi Montgomery THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Risk Services (U) Risk Services (DDQ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Control weaknesses in Risk Services processes enhance the risk of data leakage which may have minor financial impact and could cause reputational damage. They may also have a negative operational impact, which could result in financial damage.  Martina Burianova DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Process and/or Controls ICS Dependency on IT Implementation of the solution on StatistiX side is estimated for Q1/Q2 2026
2024-041_F01 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of oversight & considerations for backup replication performance in applications hosted on GCP Internal Audit identified that :
The internal written rules did not specify requirements for cloud-hosted applications’ backup replication to on-premise or to other Cloud Service Provider (CSP) environments.
Specifically:
▪ In cases where critical data was hosted in the cloud, an oversight control was missing to enforce the replication of backups to on-premise or to another CSP.
▪ Out of the ten sampled applications, two applications (one “Critical”, and one “Minor”) did not have backup replication on-premise or to
another CSP.
▪ The “Critical” application Terraform Enterprise (AID768) only had partial on-premise backups (Infrastructure as Code of the
applications was stored in GitHub, which had an on-premise backup, as well as the setup of Terraform enterprise itself).

The above-mentioned deficiencies were caused by the absence of clear guidelines and criteria pertaining to cloud backup strategy.

Germany and Luxembourg regulation require that supplier redundancies are adequately considered and implemented.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) to establish suitable metrics and monitoring measures to identify and manage deviations from above requirements/criteria. 13.12.2024 30.04.2026 30.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Boris Link, Jennifer Beate Riedl Milos Medrik Shravankumar Mohankumar JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Lack of considerations and oversight over the performance of cloud backup replications could result in critical cloud data not being backed up on-premises or to another CSP, resulting in unrecoverable data loss in case of a complete CSP failure. This in turn, could result in material violation of external provisions and regulatory requirements. It is acknowledged that a complete outage of a CSP is unlikely as CSPs are designed with very high levels of redundancies and resilience.  Boris Link ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KIEßLING ANJA(European Energy Exchange),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Other framework 45,CSDR L1 909/14
2024-041_F01 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of oversight & considerations for backup replication performance in applications hosted on GCP Internal Audit identified that :
The internal written rules did not specify requirements for cloud-hosted applications’ backup replication to on-premise or to other Cloud Service Provider (CSP) environments.
Specifically:
▪ In cases where critical data was hosted in the cloud, an oversight control was missing to enforce the replication of backups to on-premise or to another CSP.
▪ Out of the ten sampled applications, two applications (one “Critical”, and one “Minor”) did not have backup replication on-premise or to
another CSP.
▪ The “Critical” application Terraform Enterprise (AID768) only had partial on-premise backups (Infrastructure as Code of the
applications was stored in GitHub, which had an on-premise backup, as well as the setup of Terraform enterprise itself).

The above-mentioned deficiencies were caused by the absence of clear guidelines and criteria pertaining to cloud backup strategy.

Germany and Luxembourg regulation require that supplier redundancies are adequately considered and implemented.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Chief Technology Officer (ZJS) to implement suitable technical solutions, that provide capability to allow application owners to replicate cloud data backups on-premises or to another CSP. 13.12.2024 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jennifer Beate Riedl, Christian Tüffers, Aymon Delbridge, Sebastian Wedeniwski Milos Medrik Shravankumar Mohankumar JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Technology Officer (A) Chief Technology Officer (ZJS) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Lack of considerations and oversight over the performance of cloud backup replications could result in critical cloud data not being backed up on-premises or to another CSP, resulting in unrecoverable data loss in case of a complete CSP failure. This in turn, could result in material violation of external provisions and regulatory requirements. It is acknowledged that a complete outage of a CSP is unlikely as CSPs are designed with very high levels of redundancies and resilience.  Sebastian Wedeniwski ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KIEßLING ANJA(European Energy Exchange),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Other framework 45,CSDR L1 909/14
2024-041_F02 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F02-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Missing guidance for requirements to  perform penetration tests prior to cloud application go-live Internal Audit identified that seven out of ten sampled applications had not undergone a penetration test prior to going live on Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Section 3.1 of Vulnerability Management Standard v4.0 mandated that penetration tests of all IT Applications and
Infrastructure assets must be conducted upfront before initial go-live, and whenever security relevant changes are released into production.
Security-relevant changes were broadly defined as “any change to a system configuration, information content or functionality, which has the potential to change the information security risk status”. The underlying infrastructure change would fall under this definition, even when applications were only “lift-and-shifted” without functional changes to the application code.

Factors that have contributed to this finding include:
▪ Unclear guidance from Group Security (ZZA) as to whether and under which conditions penetration tests would be required for “lift
and shift” migrations.
▪ Misunderstanding that penetration tests would only be required upon application changes, not infrastructure changes, and consequently assumption that previous penetration tests on the application within the last 12 months would still be valid.
▪ Assumption that Google Cloud Platform Penetration Testing (which was executed once a year) would be sufficient to address the
infrastructure changes.
▪ Assumption that the need for penetration testing would be identified or advised by the Security cross-stream or through the Major Change Process.

German and Luxembourg regulation as noted below require that applications are subject to penetration testing to ensure identification of
vulnerabilities. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Cyber Protection & Automation (IFB), in liaison with IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT), analyse and establish clear criteria for performing penetration tests and amend as necessary the written rules as a long-term measure. Specifically, it should be ensured that the requirements are sufficiently specific if a differentiation between application penetration testing, and platform penetration testing is intended. Potential requirement exemptions (e.g. for “lift and shift” migrations) need to be clearly defined and delineated to prevent misinterpretation. 13.12.2024 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sibylle Hick Daniel Hart Shravankumar Mohankumar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Cyber Protection (S) Cyber Protection & Automation (IFB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation Missing guidance for requirements to perform penetration tests prior to cloud application go-live could result in penetration tests not being performed. Hence vulnerabilities introduced during the migration process or in the cloud infrastructure setup could remain undetected and unmitigated. This could result in material violation of internal and external provisions and regulatory requirements.  Sibylle Hick CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Information Security framework 45,CSDR L1 909/14
2024-041_F03 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F03-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of a funded action plan to remediate MS Azure related Self-Identified Issues Eight Self-Identified Issues (SII), related to deficiencies within DBG’s MS Azure environment as reported in the 2023-020 “MS Azure – Central Services, Security in the Cloud and Vendor Management” audit, were expected to be addressed as part of the Hyperion Program. A detailed implementation plan should had been in place by October 2023. The severity ratings of the SIIs were one S3, six S2 and one S1.

Internal Audit recognized that the Hyperion Program had meanwhile been restricted exclusively to Google Cloud. As a result, limited progress had been made in relation to Azure. Particularly, Azure IAM, PAM and Cyber Protection-related SIIs with severity S2 had been put on hold.

Though no concrete Secure Landing Zone implementation plans, or budgetary provisions were available at the time of the audit, tentative
high-level plans were created upon IA request. IA acknowledges the SIIs had a due date of December 2025 but was unable to opine on the feasibility due to the lack of detailed plans.
The Hyperion project's exclusive focus on GCP has caused the SIIs and associated deficiencies for Microsoft Azure to remain unresolved.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation as noted below require that adequate and robust security controls are in place to secure the cloud workloads. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Chief Cloud Officer (ZFJ) to collaborate with Group Security (ZZA) to ensure adequate closure of the SIIs noted in 2023-020 report. 13.12.2024 31.01.2026 31.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jennifer Beate Riedl, Michael Girg, Christian Tüffers, Adam Banister Shravankumar Mohankumar Shravankumar Mohankumar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrast (Dpt) Chief Cloud Officer (ZFJ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of a funded action plan to remediate MS Azure related SIIs may result in delays in the remediation of the identified deficiencies
pertaining to absence of preventive, detective and runtime security features for workloads onboarded to the Azure Cloud Estate. This could manifest in a weakened Azure Cloud security posture, potentially resulting in a material violation of applicable internal and external regulatory requirements. 		 Michael Girg CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Information Security framework 45,CSDR L1 909/14
