2024-043_F01 2024 2024-043 Project Controlling (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-043_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening The existing Project Portfolio Management (PPM) functions for ECAG and EFAG within the Strategy & Initiatives team (ZDS) should be strengthened. At the time of the audit, ZDS performed only a high-level project monitoring. ZDS included projects in the portfolio that met the financial materiality threshold of €5 million. For EFAG no projects qualified during the audited period and therefore no monitoring took place. For ECAG, the monitoring took place via the monthly jour-fixe meeting in which Clarity one-pagers for each monitored project and the portfolio risk heatmap were collated by ECAG PPM and a brief status update was given verbally in the meeting by each project manager. ECAG PPM also checked for the existence of key project documents. However, ZDS did not perform any controlling functions, only monitoring. Only one individual from each entity was responsible for executing this project-level monitoring. 

Further, there was no budget controlling process in place for projects. ZDS only monitored on the basis of a Key Risk indicator (KRI) to determine if an overall project portfolio budget overrun of more than 5% had occurred. For EFAG this KRI monitoring process was not documented. There was no controlling process in place to identify, analyse variances, evaluate their impact, ensure corrective actions were taken and escalate large variances or discrepancies that could not be resolved. Neither was there a process to forecast future costs and potential over/underruns, nor to perform headroom analyses.

The main benefits of an empowered PPM function were not realised. The authority was absent to ensure strategic alignment, optimise resource allocation, assess and manage portfolio risks and provide a structured framework for project management. Specifically, the following important PPM functions were missing from the mandate: 
 - Strategic alignment: align projects with an organisation's strategic objectives and business goals and ensure that resources are allocated to projects that contribute most to the company's overall strategy and vision.
 - Efficient resource allocation: provide visibility into resource availability and utilisation to prevent overburdening of staff and ensure the right people are assigned to the right tasks.
 - Portfolio risk management: implement a comprehensive risk management approach at the portfolio level to identify risks that could impact multiple projects or the entire portfolio and assess interdependencies and cumulative risks across projects.
 - Governance structure: establish a clear governance framework that defines roles, responsibilities and processes to facilitate transparent and consistent project management processes across the portfolio.

Internal Audit identified the root cause of the above identified weaknesses as an inadequate governance structure.

German and European regulation as well as internal policies require a suitable and transparent organisational structure and adequate internal governance. Internal documentation should include, but not be limited to, a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls. Accounting standards require businesses to maintain accurate financial records, to faithfully represent the effects of transactions and prepare an analysis of expenses. 		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) update the EFAG Project Portfolio Management (PPM) framework to:
 - implement and document a project budget controlling process for EFAG projects
 - deliberate with legal entity and department senior and executive management on the appropriate mandate for the PPM function for EFAG, considering the benefits of an empowered PPM
 - implement and document any changes to the PPM mandate agreed with management 		 19.11.2024 13.06.2025 31.12.2025 03.06.2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Frankfurt AG Joschka Josten Gianluca Tripepi Robert Pardikes THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) ROBBERT BOOIJ Trading & Clearing (Div) Trading & Clearing Strategy / Chie (Dpt) Eric Leupold Project & Portfolio Management (U) Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening, as the current approach could lead to suboptimised project delivery, increased risk of project failures, inefficient use of organisational resources and reduced ability to maximise business value from the project portfolio. These risks could lead to material adverse regulatory impact, material reputational damage and minor financial impact.  Joschka Josten MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework External Event (force majeur) Main reason for the extension request is the capacity situation in the Project & Portfolio Management team (5 FTEs on long-term leave, including 3 unexpected).
2024-043_F01 2024 2024-043 Project Controlling (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-043_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening The existing Project Portfolio Management (PPM) functions for ECAG and EFAG within the Strategy & Initiatives team (ZDS) should be strengthened. At the time of the audit, ZDS performed only a high-level project monitoring. ZDS included projects in the portfolio that met the financial materiality threshold of €5 million. For EFAG no projects qualified during the audited period and therefore no monitoring took place. For ECAG, the monitoring took place via the monthly jour-fixe meeting in which Clarity one-pagers for each monitored project and the portfolio risk heatmap were collated by ECAG PPM and a brief status update was given verbally in the meeting by each project manager. ECAG PPM also checked for the existence of key project documents. However, ZDS did not perform any controlling functions, only monitoring. Only one individual from each entity was responsible for executing this project-level monitoring. 

Further, there was no budget controlling process in place for projects. ZDS only monitored on the basis of a Key Risk indicator (KRI) to determine if an overall project portfolio budget overrun of more than 5% had occurred. For EFAG this KRI monitoring process was not documented. There was no controlling process in place to identify, analyse variances, evaluate their impact, ensure corrective actions were taken and escalate large variances or discrepancies that could not be resolved. Neither was there a process to forecast future costs and potential over/underruns, nor to perform headroom analyses.

The main benefits of an empowered PPM function were not realised. The authority was absent to ensure strategic alignment, optimise resource allocation, assess and manage portfolio risks and provide a structured framework for project management. Specifically, the following important PPM functions were missing from the mandate: 
 - Strategic alignment: align projects with an organisation's strategic objectives and business goals and ensure that resources are allocated to projects that contribute most to the company's overall strategy and vision.
 - Efficient resource allocation: provide visibility into resource availability and utilisation to prevent overburdening of staff and ensure the right people are assigned to the right tasks.
 - Portfolio risk management: implement a comprehensive risk management approach at the portfolio level to identify risks that could impact multiple projects or the entire portfolio and assess interdependencies and cumulative risks across projects.
 - Governance structure: establish a clear governance framework that defines roles, responsibilities and processes to facilitate transparent and consistent project management processes across the portfolio.

Internal Audit identified the root cause of the above identified weaknesses as an inadequate governance structure.

German and European regulation as well as internal policies require a suitable and transparent organisational structure and adequate internal governance. Internal documentation should include, but not be limited to, a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls. Accounting standards require businesses to maintain accurate financial records, to faithfully represent the effects of transactions and prepare an analysis of expenses. 		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) update the ECAG Project Portfolio Management (PPM) framework to:
 - implement and document a project budget controlling process for ECAG
 - deliberate with legal entity and department senior and executive management on the appropriate mandate for the PPM function for ECAG, considering the benefits of an empowered PPM
 - implement and document any changes to the PPM mandate agreed with management 		 19.11.2024 13.06.2025 31.12.2025 03.06.2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Joschka Josten Robert Pardikes Robert Pardikes THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Trading & Clearing Strategy / Chie (Dpt) Eric Leupold Project & Portfolio Management (U) Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening, as the current approach could lead to suboptimised project delivery, increased risk of project failures, inefficient use of organisational resources and reduced ability to maximise business value from the project portfolio. These risks could lead to material adverse regulatory impact, material reputational damage and minor financial impact.  Joschka Josten MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework External Event (force majeur) Main reason for the extension request is the capacity situation in the Project and Portfolio Management team (5 FTEs are on long-term leave, including 3 FTEs unexpected).
2024-048_F01 2024 2024-048 SAP Application & Vendor & Project (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-048_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S3 SAP contract breach by limitation of agreed audit rights Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) key business applications run in SAP’s Software as a Service (SaaS) cloud environment are e.g. SAP C/4 HANA (CX), SAP SuccessFactors (SFSF), SAP Business Technology Platform, Enterprise Analytics Cloud, SAP Ariba, SAP Concur or SAP Fieldglass.

Internal Audit (IA) noted that SAP did not properly support DBAG in performing audit activities (e.g. risk assessments, process inspections or control validations) although the contract with SAP granted DBAG “unrestricted audit rights”. In essence, SAP did not disclose (neither hand-over of documentation nor reading opportunity) any policy document, process, controls, tools, risk data or third-party information, which are essential for DBAG’s Third-Party Risk Management.

Specifically, SAP did not disclose the following:
1. Policies, standards, and procedures (e.g. Wiki, Confluence, or WebPage), including e.g. SAP Risk Management Policy, SAP Defensive Penetration Standard or SAP Third Party Security Annex.
2. Internal processes, including e.g. Risk Management, Incident Management or Customer Impact assessment.
3. Internal control frameworks and internal controls on processes, including e.g. Global Security Framework or controls for Risk Management.
4. Internal reporting, including e.g. KPIs on overall SAP’s compliance status, vulnerabilities, or incidents.
5. Supporting tools, including e.g. an overview of used tools and linkage to processes, security concepts or risk profiles for each tool such as Compliance Cockpit, Splunk, Brinqa or ServiceNow.
6. Risk data, including e.g. risk inventory, missing patches, vulnerability or penetration test results. SAP refused by stating “… details regarding the Risk Management topics cannot be shared as they are highly confidential information which is not shared with customers at any time, …”.
7. Engaged third parties, including e.g. overview of third parties, risk assessment of these third parties or the contractual pass-through of DBAG audit rights.

During the three-day on-site visit, SAP shared information verbally based on standardised, high-level slide decks.

As a result, IA was not in the position to examine SAP’s ICT (Information and Communications Technology) Governance and Risk Management. IA could not gain assurance whether the SAP organisation had developed a comprehensive control environment to manage ICT risks, processes, assets, and individuals. This applied to all five Cloud Security Alliance - Cloud Control Matrix control domains in scope: Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC), Business Continuity Management and Operational Resilience (BCR), Threat & Vulnerability Management (TVM), Security Incident Management, E-Discovery, & Cloud Forensics (SEF), and Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability (STA).

As a justification, SAP pointed out a strong internal legal advice to treat the audit as a limited customer review for which such detailed requests were not allowed.

After IA triggered DBAG senior management escalation, SAP provided further information and three one-hour policy review sessions for the BCR control domain, delaying audit fieldwork by two weeks. Despite this increased cooperation, SAP did not provide these documents to IA DBAG for review, even though the documents were classified as SAP “internal” and accessible to SAP employees via SAP’s policy portal. At the end of the extended fieldwork, 14 of 41 requests had not been fulfilled at all, most others only partially and still no internal documents after the second document request. SAP also explained that further evidence could not be shared as this would provide an insider’s view of how SAP functions and the internal value SAP places on a subset of mission-critical processes.

Ineffectively established audit rights for a critical outsourcing engagement constitutes a violation of regulatory requirements to properly manage the respective third-party risks, monitor the provision of the outsourced activities, and assess the performance and quality of the services provided.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends Corporate IT (ITH) to create and implement a Corrective Action Plan along the following illustrative steps:
1. Establish legal exchange between SAP and DBAG about the meaning and impact of “unrestricted audit rights” in the contract accordingly and document the result of the alignment.
2. Advise SAP to educate their organisation internally about DBAG’s “unrestricted audit rights”.
3. Perform an additional review to demonstrate that SAP is sharing and handing over appropriate information to DBAG.
All steps require solid evidence to demonstrate holistic and sustainable risk remediation.		 25.09.2024 18.12.2024 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lars Bolanca, Aniket Deshpande, Samira Amirli, Vasiliki Ziaka Oliver Wolff André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT (A) Corporate IT (ITH) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. SAP contract breach by limitation of agreed audit rights hindered Internal Audit to perform its duties and to form an opinion on SAP’s internal risk management and control system. Such lack of cooperation further impedes the DBAG business owner to implement an adequate vendor risk management approach and violates regulatory requirements.
Significant audit right limitation can lead to serious adverse regulatory impact such as a service termination note, extra reporting requirements or regulatory examinations (special audit pursuant to section 44 KwG). Furthermore, it represents a serious violation of internal and external provisions resulting in financial risks or adverse impact on the internal control system.		 Lars Bolanca CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Singapore Branch) Obsolete - Lack of Awareness of Group/Cross Funct Processes Outsourcing framework
2024-048_F02 2024 2024-048 SAP Application & Vendor & Project (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-048_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S3 Inappropriate SAP vendor risk management Internal Audit noted that SAP vendor risk management was not developed to a maturity level which would be considered appropriate in view of the vendor’s importance. Contributing factors for the conclusion:
- Corporate IT performed a targeted review on SAP in 2023, identifying severe audit right limitations for the following topics: Incident and Data Breach Management, Third Party Provider Management, Malware Management and Penetration Testing.
- DBAG and SAP followed up in working sessions to align on the collaboration and joint understanding for future audits in order to receive the required information. Nevertheless, remediation actions did not result in a sustainably improved DBAG audit support. DBAG was still asked to rely on documents validated by independent certified third parties, e.g. SOC 2 audit reports.
- Corporate IT did not validate the effectiveness of allegedly improved audit support, to confirm the removal of audit right limitations. Further, appropriate risk management measures such as risk entries, risk acceptance, or further escalation were not initiated.

Although IT Security is currently strengthening the “Supplier Security Risk” process, supported by the Prevalent tool, the contract business owner’s duty to capture, assess and manage supplier risk remains untouched. Considering SAP’s refusal to provide information as outlined in 2024-048_F01, SAP vendor risk management is deemed systematically incomplete.

According to MaRisk, the internal audit function shall examine and assess in a risk-oriented and process-independent manner the effectiveness and appropriateness of the risk management system, as well as the appropriateness of all activities and processes in general, irrespective of whether or not they have been outsourced. For material outsourced activities and processes, the outsourcing contract shall specifically set out appropriate internal auditors’ rights of information and review.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Corporate IT (ITH) to create and implement a Corrective Action Plan along the following illustrative steps:
- Design and implement a robust SAP vendor risk management and monitoring in line with applicable policies and related regulatory requirements.
- Develop and implement the resulting SAP vendor management processes for vendor monitoring and control activities.
- Develop and implement KPIs for the vendor SAP to assess the effectiveness of the newly implemented processes on a regular basis.		 25.09.2024 18.12.2024 31.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lars Bolanca, Aniket Deshpande, Samira Amirli, Vasiliki Ziaka Oliver Wolff André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT (A) Corporate IT (ITH) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inappropriate SAP vendor risk management could lead to unacceptable vendor behaviour that in consequence breaches contractual obligations and thus violates regulatory requirements. This may cause a high potential for penalty payments, extra reporting requirements and regulatory examinations with serious adverse regulatory impact. Further, minor financial risks may arise for DBAG paying charges for contractually agreed services which are not delivered by SAP. Lars Bolanca CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Singapore Branch) Obsolete - Lack of Awareness of Group/Cross Funct Processes Outsourcing framework
2024-051_F08 2024 2024-051 Corporate Governance (DBAG, ECAG) 2024-051_F08-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of and inconsistencies in risk strategies Internal Audit (IA) noted that EFAG risk strategy, that shall serve as basis for risk management framework and support for EFAG business strategy, was in draft and not yet approved by EFAG Executive Board.
Moreover, IA noted inconsistencies in Business Risk assessments, based on review of the following EFAG and ECAG strategies:
▪
2024 Eurex Corporate Strategy (EFAG Business Strategy) and draft Eurex Frankfurt AG Risk Strategy - In capacity as Exchange Operator for Eurex Deutschland (ED), version 1 (draft EFAG Risk Strategy)
▪
Eurex Clearing Business Strategy 2024 (ECAG Business Strategy) and Eurex Clearing Risk Strategy, version 4.2 (ECAG Risk Strategy)
Namely, in both draft EFAG and approved ECAG Risk Strategy, Business Risk was assessed as not applicable. The assessment resulted from the annual Risk Inventory process and was based on implemented Group risk quantification approach, Risk Appetite Framework and Value-at-Risk (VaR) model. However, this was not in line with the risk assessments available in respective EFAG Business Strategy and ECAG Business Strategy, outlining the Business Risks (Regulatory and Macroeconomic risks) as material.
IA learned that risk assessment in business strategies follows “gross” approach, meaning that material risks are those that negatively impact entity’s financial targets prior to considering operating agreements and transfer of revenues to shareholders. However, no clear rationale for deviations in materiality assessments was provided in strategic and process documents.
Identified issue was caused by incorrect interpretation of regulatory requirements.
In line with external and internal provisions, management must implement appropriate arrangements and systems to identify all significant risks to its operation, and to put in place effective measures to mitigate those risks. Risk strategies should be consistent with business strategies and provide support in reaching strategic goals by identifying, assessing and managing resulting risks.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) aligns the risk strategy with ECAG business strategy by providing justification, in sufficient level of details, for ECAG Business Strategy risk assessment results and any deviations between business strategy and risk strategy.  19.12.2024 15.06.2025 31.12.2025 11.06.2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Cesar Matos Ana Kosela Iryna Neurath THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of and inconsistencies in risk strategies may lead to inadequate identification and management of main risks impacting strategic goals and success of the business strategies. This can lead to material financial and operational losses and represents a breach of regulatory and internal requirements. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Other framework Other Further clarification on provided evidences needed
2024-056_F03 2024 2024-056 Physical security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2024-056_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Non-compliance with encryption policy requirements for CCTV data transmission Internal Audit (IA) noted that the communication between the video cameras and the Closed-Circuit Television (CCTV) servers hosting the Honeywell Digital Video Manager (DVM) software was not encrypted.

 

IA identified the root cause of the identified issue as human error/omission.

 

The DBG CISO Technological Security Standard requires the encryption of data during transmission within the internal network, especially for information classified as “strictly confidential” or “confidential”.

 

Article 36 of the EBA Guidelines on ICT and security risk management requires the encryption of data at rest and in transit in accordance with the data classification. In Luxembourg, compliance with these EBA guidelines is enforced by the CSSF, while in Germany, the BaFin has incorporated them into their regulatory framework through the Banking Supervisory Requirements for IT (BAIT), based on the Minimum Requirements for Risk Management (MaRisk). 		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends that Physical Security (FSE) implements encryption protocols for data in transit between the CCTV cameras and the DVM servers.  18.12.2024 12.06.2026 12.06.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Moritz Dierkes, David Krüger, Winfried Ries Xavier Karthaeuser Xavier Karthaeuser CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Physical Security (U) Physical Security (FSE) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Non-compliance with encryption policy requirements for CCTV data transmission may expose the company to several risks, including:

risk of non-compliance with internal and external provisions

risk of interception by unauthorised parties and access to sensitive footage, potentially exposing private information about individuals (Personally Identifiable Information)

This may result in a material adverse regulatory impact, minor financial impact or material reputational damage. 		 David Krüger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Human Error/ Omission Information Security framework
2024-056_F05 2024 2024-056 Physical security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2024-056_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Outdated and incomplete Physical Security documentation Internal Audit (IA) noted that several internal documents related to Physical Security were outdated and did not reflect the transfer of Threat Intelligence and Travel Risk Management from Physical Security (FSE) to Cyber Defense (CBD) as of 1 March 2023:

DBG’s Physical Security Standard, Section 4.4 contained still "Intelligence & Travel Risk Management" although last updated in October 2023.

All intra-group outsourcing agreements for Physical Security services still included FSE’s responsibility for “Intelligence and Travel Risk Management” in chapter 3 Detailed Service Description.

The Threat Intelligence and Travel Risk Management processes were still part of FSE's Risk and Control Matrix (RCM) and Process Map.

 

Furthermore, IA noted that the Process Manual Physical Access Control, last reviewed in March 2023, was outdated. The processes described were still based on the Multifunctional Operating Centre (MOC) system which was linked to Hydra but not to the Honeywell EBI system. Hydra was only operational at Hausen1; all other locations have transitioned to Honeywell.

 

Additionally, IA observed that the Process Handbook for Visitor Management lacked several critical topics required by the Physical Security Standard (specifically in the section on Physical Site Security & Event Risk Management – Reception Services):

The Handbook did not specify the need for receptionist staff to register status changes (e.g., checked-in/checked-out) in the Proxyclick application, which was essential for tracking visitors within the building.

The Handbook did not clarify the receptionists' responsibility to inform visitors about the security requirements and emergency procedures indicated on the back of their badges.

The receptionists were unaware that the emergency procedures were indicated on the back of the visitor badges.

The Handbook failed to address the escorting requirements for DBG data centre server rooms.

 

Also, the Handbook did not include procedures for handling visitors from law enforcement authorities (e.g., those with search warrants). The Handbook should either incorporate the Guideline for Official Searches procedure developed by Group Legal (GCA) or provide a link to it.

 

Furthermore, although the Physical Security procedures (i.e., the Process Handbook on Technical Security, the Specific Procedures on site “The Square” and the Besondere Dienstanweisung für den Objektschutz und Empfangsdienst in der Liegenschaft der “The Cube”) outlined several steps and processes for managing non-functioning cameras, they did not explicitly detail a specific process for analysing the risks associated to camera downtimes. A procedure for identifying and implementing risk mitigating controls during such downtimes was not defined.

 

In addition, several key topics related to visitor management, specifically blacklist procedures and entry/accompany regulations, were not addressed in the procedure titled Besondere Dienstanweisung für den Objektschutz und Empfangsdienst in der Liegenschaft der “The Cube”.

 

Finally, during the 2024-079 CFCL Cork Branch audit, Internal Audit identified a finding relevant to all DBG legal entities: the Process Manual Physical Access Control did not document the existing process for offboarding external contractors.

 

IA identified the root cause of the identified issues as human error/omission, and lack of awareness of group/cross functional processes.

 

External and internal provisions require the institution to ensure that business activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines (e.g., manuals, work instructions or workflow descriptions), and that the guidelines are swiftly amended in the event of changes to the activities and processes. 		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends that Physical Security (FSE):

updates the Physical Security Standard, intra-group outsourcing agreements, Risk and Control Matrix (RCM), and Process Map to reflect the transfer of responsibilities to Cyber Defense (CBD)

revises the Process Manual Physical Access Control to reflect the current procedures based on the Honeywell EBI system and ensures that it accurately describes the processes in use across all locations

revises the Process Handbook for Visitor Management to include guidelines for receptionist staff to register status changes, requirements for informing visitors about security protocols and emergency procedures (as indicated on the back of their badges), guidelines for escorting visitors in the DBG data center server rooms, information on handling law enforcement authorities, including the Guideline for Official Searches developed by Group Legal, or a link to it, ensuring this guideline is integrated into the Physical Security process

updates the Physical Security procedures for assessing the risks associated with non-functioning cameras as well as the risk mitigation strategies during camera downtime. This should include criteria for evaluating the potential impact on security, safety and operational continuity

revises the procedure Besondere Dienstanweisung für den Objektschutz und Empfangsdienst in der Liegenschaft der “The Cube” to include comprehensive guidelines on blacklist procedures and entry/accompany regulations. These guidelines should align with best practices

updates the Process Manual Physical Access Control to document the offboarding process for external contractors 		 18.12.2024 12.12.2025 12.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Moritz Dierkes, David Krüger, Winfried Ries Sandra Schwarz Xavier Karthaeuser CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Physical Security (U) Physical Security (FSE) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Outdated and incomplete Physical Security documentation bears the risk of operational errors and inefficiencies (e.g., inconsistent visitor handling or insufficient handling of surveillance interruptions, potentially compromising the security of the premises during periods when cameras are non-functional) resulting from unclear defined roles and responsibilities as well as non-compliance with regulations.

This may result in a material adverse regulatory impact, minor financial impact or material reputational damage. 		 David Krüger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Human Error/ Omission Physical security/accesses
2024-063_F01 2024 2024-063 Technology Governance (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-063_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework & lack of harmonisation between DBG’s first and second LoD As identified in the CIO Strategy 2021 and the CIO division reorganisation, which was effective from Q3 2022, the closed 2022-051_F01 self-identified issue (SII)  planned to establish a consistent Group-wide IT Governance framework and function, including clear delineation of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) first (1LoD) and second (2LoD) lines of defence roles and responsibilities, by January 2024.

Internal Audit’s (IA) review of this SII noted that, although progress was made since 2022, the planned actions for IT Governance framework were incomplete. Due to responsibility shifts triggered by the January 2024 reorganisation and a new written rule structure, formalisation of the ICT Risk Management framework was prolonged. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.
§ Although SII 2022-051_F01 anticipated 1LoD IRT’s alignment of the IT Governance framework with all affected Shared and Product ITs, this was not ensured since the alignment was on a best effort basis.

Moreover, the priority-oriented DORA-readiness implementation plan scheduled completion of Design (DE) and Operating Effectiveness (OE) for 7 out of 18 areas by January 2025. For the remaining eleven areas, prioritisation efforts were channeled towards achieving maturity, with DE completed by that date, and continuous improvements towards OE scheduled to last until end of 2025. The DBG Legal Entities’ DORA progress was tracked and monitored by appropriate oversight mechanisms, e.g. Steering Committees, Board presentations.

2) DBG 1LoD and 2LoD responsibilities
By end of 2023, DBG’s 2LoD lacked an IT framework and performed no IS Compliance control activities. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

The identified weaknesses and some ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures are separately detailed in this report’s section 6 “Annex - Audit Observations”.
6. Annex - Audit Observations
Referencing the F01 finding raised above, the details included herewith are supporting some of its identified weaknesses and the ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures:

6.1 Incomplete requirements of ICT Governance Framework
Internal Audit noted that 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) development of the encompassing 14 ICT Guidelines aligned with the DORA risk management framework was scheduled for completion by December 2024 and progress tracked in the IT Amelioration (AMELI) program. Besides, MCRC (Minimum Control Requirements Checklist) IT control requirements are/will be gradually moved into updated or newly developed Guidelines.

-------
6.2 Alignment on arrangement of new IT Compliance setup within DBG’s legal entities
In 2023, the first IT Compliance control plan was generated on a risk-based approach and controls were executed accordingly. In 2024, a control plan was developed to execute controls on critical topics and the first DBAG IT Compliance Risk Assessment (CRAF “Compliance Risk Assessment Framework” Methodology) finalised.

At the end of Q3 2024, the following Group-wide activities were planned by DBAG Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) as outlined below:
§ Planned activities for 2025:
- At DBAG level, a revised control planning methodology was in development, and in alignment with ExR, CBF (incl. CH), CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and ECAG (incl. EFAG), reflecting a 4-year cycle (2023-26) to complete controls for all ICS L1 processes.
- New TOM “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements (Project supported by Protiviti consultant); rollout was scheduled through 2024 and will be operational beginning of 2025.
- Revise the CRAF 2.0 reflecting the DORA requirements as well.
- Enhance regulatory screening process going forward for all IT and IS related regulations.
§ For 2025, the status regarding service agreements are as follows:
- ExR, CBF (incl. CH): IT Compliance is fully outsourced to DBAG.
- ECAG (incl. EFAG): Framework and Risk Assessment are outsourced to DBAG since 1 September 2024; and controls will be jointly executed where deemed feasible. IT and IS Compliance topics were covered in its Annual Compliance Control Plans.
- CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) is currently in clarification. An outsourcing will take place, yet its frame is still under discussion. Implementation expected by 2025. 
- CFCL: although the outsourcing setup discussion is ongoing, no decision has been finalised as the agreement over the services that DBAG Compliance will be offering is in draft. The effective date is targeted for the end of Q1 2025.
-------
6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that IT Governance Risk and Transformation (IRT):
§ completes the 1LoD detailed IT written rules (“procedures”) within the remit of IRT, i.e. for IT Run, IT Change and IT Governance process bundles in DBAG. Formalise and implement associated control governance to fulfil related 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) DORA-aligned ICT guideline requirements “process based”.
§ rolls out the procedures to all DBAG Shared and Product ITs and record their approval/decision. LEs are informed/consulted and can adopt DBAG procedure at LE discretion.
§ extends the IRT target operating model with “asset based” IT Risk Management once new second/first line delineation is established.
§ includes further process and asset-based metrics and KPIs in existing reporting and committee escalation processes.
§ takes over the ICS processes co-ordination role for DBAG IT from 2LoD i.e., to provide 1LoD – Shared and Product ITs – with guidance on how to define and execute the controls/assess risks.		 05.12.2024 18.12.2026 18.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Boris Link Aleksandra Galaganova Yezad Wadia JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework results in an inadequately established control environment. The delineation between DBG’s 1LoD and 2LoD did not effectively allow performing all responsibilities provided in the Information Security Policy, and effective assurance of 1LoD’s compliance with the framework. This could lead to major financial impact and serious reputational damage due to failure in identifying potential deficiencies. Potential synergies, LE alignment and efficient prioritisation of different ICT initiatives may also not be achieved. Boris Link BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework 3,47,3,9,CSDR L2 153/2023,CSDR L2 2017/392
2024-063_F01 2024 2024-063 Technology Governance (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-063_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework & lack of harmonisation between DBG’s first and second LoD As identified in the CIO Strategy 2021 and the CIO division reorganisation, which was effective from Q3 2022, the closed 2022-051_F01 self-identified issue (SII)  planned to establish a consistent Group-wide IT Governance framework and function, including clear delineation of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) first (1LoD) and second (2LoD) lines of defence roles and responsibilities, by January 2024.

Internal Audit’s (IA) review of this SII noted that, although progress was made since 2022, the planned actions for IT Governance framework were incomplete. Due to responsibility shifts triggered by the January 2024 reorganisation and a new written rule structure, formalisation of the ICT Risk Management framework was prolonged. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.
§ Although SII 2022-051_F01 anticipated 1LoD IRT’s alignment of the IT Governance framework with all affected Shared and Product ITs, this was not ensured since the alignment was on a best effort basis.

Moreover, the priority-oriented DORA-readiness implementation plan scheduled completion of Design (DE) and Operating Effectiveness (OE) for 7 out of 18 areas by January 2025. For the remaining eleven areas, prioritisation efforts were channeled towards achieving maturity, with DE completed by that date, and continuous improvements towards OE scheduled to last until end of 2025. The DBG Legal Entities’ DORA progress was tracked and monitored by appropriate oversight mechanisms, e.g. Steering Committees, Board presentations.

2) DBG 1LoD and 2LoD responsibilities
By end of 2023, DBG’s 2LoD lacked an IT framework and performed no IS Compliance control activities. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

The identified weaknesses and some ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures are separately detailed in this report’s section 6 “Annex - Audit Observations”.
6. Annex - Audit Observations
Referencing the F01 finding raised above, the details included herewith are supporting some of its identified weaknesses and the ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures:

6.1 Incomplete requirements of ICT Governance Framework
Internal Audit noted that 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) development of the encompassing 14 ICT Guidelines aligned with the DORA risk management framework was scheduled for completion by December 2024 and progress tracked in the IT Amelioration (AMELI) program. Besides, MCRC (Minimum Control Requirements Checklist) IT control requirements are/will be gradually moved into updated or newly developed Guidelines.

-------
6.2 Alignment on arrangement of new IT Compliance setup within DBG’s legal entities
In 2023, the first IT Compliance control plan was generated on a risk-based approach and controls were executed accordingly. In 2024, a control plan was developed to execute controls on critical topics and the first DBAG IT Compliance Risk Assessment (CRAF “Compliance Risk Assessment Framework” Methodology) finalised.

At the end of Q3 2024, the following Group-wide activities were planned by DBAG Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) as outlined below:
§ Planned activities for 2025:
- At DBAG level, a revised control planning methodology was in development, and in alignment with ExR, CBF (incl. CH), CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and ECAG (incl. EFAG), reflecting a 4-year cycle (2023-26) to complete controls for all ICS L1 processes.
- New TOM “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements (Project supported by Protiviti consultant); rollout was scheduled through 2024 and will be operational beginning of 2025.
- Revise the CRAF 2.0 reflecting the DORA requirements as well.
- Enhance regulatory screening process going forward for all IT and IS related regulations.
§ For 2025, the status regarding service agreements are as follows:
- ExR, CBF (incl. CH): IT Compliance is fully outsourced to DBAG.
- ECAG (incl. EFAG): Framework and Risk Assessment are outsourced to DBAG since 1 September 2024; and controls will be jointly executed where deemed feasible. IT and IS Compliance topics were covered in its Annual Compliance Control Plans.
- CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) is currently in clarification. An outsourcing will take place, yet its frame is still under discussion. Implementation expected by 2025. 
- CFCL: although the outsourcing setup discussion is ongoing, no decision has been finalised as the agreement over the services that DBAG Compliance will be offering is in draft. The effective date is targeted for the end of Q1 2025.
-------
6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT):
§ operationalises the control monitoring (as per new Target Operating Model -TOM), i.e. to check the responsibility for controls in 1LoD and completeness of controls executed by 1LoD DBAG IT.
§ completes the two new pilot assessments from H2 2024 as per new ICT Assurance methodology.
§ executes the 2025 ICT Assurance assessment cycle and planned activities as per the new methodology and perform follow-up activities (refer section 6.3).		 05.12.2024 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer, Petr Strnad, Christian Gorke Aleksandra Galaganova Yezad Wadia HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (Dpt) Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework results in an inadequately established control environment. The delineation between DBG’s 1LoD and 2LoD did not effectively allow performing all responsibilities provided in the Information Security Policy, and effective assurance of 1LoD’s compliance with the framework. This could lead to major financial impact and serious reputational damage due to failure in identifying potential deficiencies. Potential synergies, LE alignment and efficient prioritisation of different ICT initiatives may also not be achieved. Christian Gorke BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework 3,47,3,9,CSDR L2 153/2023,CSDR L2 2017/392
2024-063_F01 2024 2024-063 Technology Governance (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-063_F01-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework & lack of harmonisation between DBG’s first and second LoD As identified in the CIO Strategy 2021 and the CIO division reorganisation, which was effective from Q3 2022, the closed 2022-051_F01 self-identified issue (SII)  planned to establish a consistent Group-wide IT Governance framework and function, including clear delineation of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) first (1LoD) and second (2LoD) lines of defence roles and responsibilities, by January 2024.

Internal Audit’s (IA) review of this SII noted that, although progress was made since 2022, the planned actions for IT Governance framework were incomplete. Due to responsibility shifts triggered by the January 2024 reorganisation and a new written rule structure, formalisation of the ICT Risk Management framework was prolonged. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.
§ Although SII 2022-051_F01 anticipated 1LoD IRT’s alignment of the IT Governance framework with all affected Shared and Product ITs, this was not ensured since the alignment was on a best effort basis.

Moreover, the priority-oriented DORA-readiness implementation plan scheduled completion of Design (DE) and Operating Effectiveness (OE) for 7 out of 18 areas by January 2025. For the remaining eleven areas, prioritisation efforts were channeled towards achieving maturity, with DE completed by that date, and continuous improvements towards OE scheduled to last until end of 2025. The DBG Legal Entities’ DORA progress was tracked and monitored by appropriate oversight mechanisms, e.g. Steering Committees, Board presentations.

2) DBG 1LoD and 2LoD responsibilities
By end of 2023, DBG’s 2LoD lacked an IT framework and performed no IS Compliance control activities. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Group Compliance Strategy (SCG), with support of LE CCO (Chief Compliance Officer) or IT Compliance Officers, where needed:
§ designs and executes the IT Compliance Control plans.
§ executes the planned activities for 2025 (detailed in this report’s section 6.2) and operationalises the new Target Operating Model “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements, i.e. rollout, adoption, focusing on design type controls and performing reviews of ICT or IS regulations (subject to decision at the LE level).
§ finalises the outsourcing service agreements.		 05.12.2024 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Marco Popp Aleksandra Galaganova Yezad Wadia JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Group Compliance Strategy (S) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Marco Popp BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework 3,47,3,9,CSDR L2 153/2023,CSDR L2 2017/392

Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Business Information Security (PWW) – legal entity (LE) CISOs for ExR, ECAG, EFAG:
§ establish a LE-specific operating model to ensure oversight and controlling of ICT risks and operationalise it.
§ finalise service agreements between the LEs ECAG with ExR and EFAG respectively by end of Q2 2025.

Further, in support and collaboration with Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT), update the service agreements - between ECAG and DBAG, ExR and DBAG, EFAG and DBAG - with relevant ICT elements by end of Q2 2025.

The first bullet has been adequately addressed before the issuance of the audit report.		 05.12.2024 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Eurex Clearing AG Petr Strnad, Christian Gorke, Henning Volz Aleksandra Galaganova Yezad Wadia JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij ICT Risk and Information Security (U) Business Information Security (PWW) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework results in an inadequately established control environment. The delineation between DBG’s 1LoD and 2LoD did not effectively allow performing all responsibilities provided in the Information Security Policy, and effective assurance of 1LoD’s compliance with the framework. This could lead to major financial impact and serious reputational damage due to failure in identifying potential deficiencies.
