Néjib Zaouali BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework 3,47,3,9,CSDR L2 153/2023,CSDR L2 2017/392
2024-065_F07 2024 2024-065 Compliance (incl. AML & CTF) (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-065_F07-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the Conflict of Interests (CoI) framework Internal Audit (IA) noted that the Employee Compliance Assessment Tool application (ECAT), (AID700) managed by Employee & Securities Compliance (ZJG), distinguished between an employee’s personal outside business interests (Personal CoI) and Conflicts of Interests (CoI) related to business activities (Corporate CoI). In both cases, the CoIs had to be disclosed by a DBG individual in the Employee Compliance Portal (ECP). Personal CoIs are associated to individuals, whereas Corporate CoIs were linked to an entity or organisation.

Besides, IA identified the 1st LoD insufficient awareness on the process specifics and lack of line managers’ pre-approval process for Corporate CoIs. As of November 2024, Corporate conflict assessment was not performed by the line manager, but only by ZJG as independent 2LoD. For secondary employment (personal CoI), where the assessment also includes a review by the line manager as well as HR, before ZJG performs a conflict assessment.

IA identified, during previous audits and reviews, the following issues that were directly addressed to the owners of the CoIs:
§ different personal CoIs may trigger one transversal CoI at the activity level (reorganisation of Clearstream Group Credit activities). IA also did not observe any additional analysis to identify any connections between these transversal cases.
§ cases where the concerned persons did not notify interests entailing (potential) CoIs to ZJG (e.g. potential conflicts in relation to the Credit Crisis Management Team).

The main root cause identified for the above-mentioned cases was a lack of awareness, adherence to the Policy and processes in place.

Additionally, IA observed that the current ECP setup only allows CoI-related information to be linked to individual names and not specific roles in case of Corporate CoI.

The identified issues were mainly caused by inadequate controls, technical restrictions in the Employee Compliance Portal, as well as complexity and volume of operations.

In line with European, German and Luxembourg regulations, the CoI framework shall outline procedures for identifying, assessing, managing and mitigating potential CoI to prevent unjustified consequences for the institution, counterparties and customers. Moreover, the framework shall outline the reporting and escalation procedures withing the institution. Staff members must be able promptly inform and involve their senior managers if they encounter a CoI.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Employee & Securities Compliance (ZJG) enhance the Conflict of Interests (CoI) framework by:
§ incorporating practical examples on Corporate CoIs as part of the regular Group Compliance training
§ extending the requirement for Line Manager pre-approval of CoIs to additional groups/sub-categories of interests that do not contain private information but may impact the direct work environment
§ involving line managers in the periodic review of CoIs impacting their business line
§ assessing the technical feasibility of linking CoI related information to a specific role, ensuring the previous CoIs are retained in the event of a Line Manager change		 16.12.2024 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,ISS-STOXX GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,ISS-STOXX GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Katja Röhle Nadezda Savchenkova Vladan Simunovic HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Employee & Securities Compliance (U) Employee & Securities Compliance (ZJG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation, provided that sufficient resources and technical solutions supporting the procedural changes are available. Weaknesses in the Conflict of Interests` (CoI) framework bear the risk of incomplete CoI registers reported to regulators. This could lead to material violation of external and internal provisions and could expose DBG to extra regulatory examinations, limited reputational damage and a minor financial loss. Katja Röhle ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),ERIK TIM MÜLLER(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK PRASSE(ISS-STOXX GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Complexity/ Volume of operations/ Pressure Other framework
2024-077_F01 2024 2024-077 Identity and Access Management (DBAG, ECAG, ECC, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-077_F01-A02 Recommendation Open S2 Insufficient Governance of AD Groups under OAAD Domain During a review of the DBG Active Directory (AD) Groups, which is used to manage network resources and provides centralised authentication and authorisation, Internal Audit (IA) noted that:
§ Guidelines to ensure the consistent rollout of access management, procedures among the AD Groups were missing.
§ AD groups within OAAD were inadequately managed. IA noted that from the 60474 known AD Groups managed by IT SecOps,
- 11159 (18%) did not have a designated owner.
- of these 11159 ADs, 8547 (14%) were not onboarded to CyberArk or IIQ and 1114 of them are potentially PAM relevant.
- 1483 (2.5%) AD Groups were being populated and in use. Affected applications included, among others, Artifactory (AID283), Blueprism (AID425), ESET Easy Protect (AID959), O365 (AID551), MTS.nom (AID530), Jenkins (AID286), Fortify (AID985).

IA noted Project Luna is in progress and aims to streamline the Domain Forest structure and create guidelines for management of Active Directories. Review of the governance of active directories showed no evidence of severe issues due to the lack of governance.

Insufficient Governance of AD Groups under OAAD Domain was attributed to Inadequate Governance Structure.

In line with the German and Luxembourg regulations and internal requirements, organisations are required to implement strong access management controls over elevated system access entitlements (e.g., Administrator Accounts). An entity shall use standardised processes and controls to effectively support access control tasks. Also, user access rights concept shall ensure that users are assigned access rights according to the need-to-know and least privileged principles. Adequate controls and processes should be in place to ensure enforcement of access revocation or adjustments in case a user moves within the organisation due to an organisational shift or transfer		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO):
§ reviews the existing ADs objects in OAAD and identify the correct owners and applications
§ removes the regional office AD directories
§ migrates technical accounts to the new AD design
§ migrates groups to new AD design		 19.12.2024 15.05.2026 15.05.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Geoffrey Saint-Alary, Ana-Simona Pop Kevin Gregory Floro Akhilesh Dhancholia CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Inn (U) Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficient governance of AD Groups under OAAD Domain may:
§ lead to granting access to users who no longer need it, increasing the risk of unauthorised access.
§ result in a material violation of internal and external provisions related to the Information Security Framework.
This could lead to extra reporting requirements and regulatory examinations as well as operational risks, for example, obsolete access rights remaining undetected due to inadequate/ineffective recertification processes which could be misused to perform unauthorised activities.		 Geoffrey Saint-Alary CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Information Security framework
2024-078_F02 2024 2024-078 Privileged Access Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-078_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditor S2 Lack of processing controls and escalation mechanism for Privileged Account Inventory The Privileged Account Inventory (PAI, AID928) was implemented to ensure and measure proper onboarding to CyberArk (AID756) as well as compliance with internal and external requirements for privileged accounts.

PAI is based on two major input sources: Configuration Management Database (CMDB) data for relevant IT-assets within Deutsche Börse Group (servers, databases, storage and network assets) as well as the information from respective IT-asset owners with privileged accounts for those assets. PAI then compares e.g. if all reported privileged accounts from the asset owners are onboarded to CyberArk.

Via inspection of CMDB input data processing within PAI, Internal Audit noted:
§ Input controls: no controls were established to review the error log and correct errors within PAI. Between 1 September and 21 October 2024, the log recorded 132 errors overall regarding, e.g. empty asset owners input data or inadequate input data formatting. PAI errors were only corrected based on IT-asset owners’ feedback on the PAI report for privileged account onboarding.
§ Escalation mechanism: the privileged account onboarding PAI report is sent out to the IT-asset owners bi-weekly. In addition, the product-level non-compliance status is presented to the Digital Security Committee. Per December 2024, 3,77% of active privileged accounts in production environments (5.000 out of 132.600) were not onboarded to CyberArk as well as no information risk for each of the 5.000 accounts was created. In addition, 200 out of the 5.000 accounts were inventoried within PAI more than 12 months ago. Furthermore, so far, no documented process to follow up on IT-asset owners’ feedback on non-compliant privileged accounts was implemented. CBL TISO raised a feature request to track and monitor such non-compliance instances via a ticketing system including escalation mechanism in case of missing/delayed the asset owners’ feedback.

The root cause was inadequate governance structure and inadequate / missing controls with regards to PAI.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations and internal rules require institutions to secure the usage of privileged accounts.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends Identity & Access Management (ICA) to implement a tracking and monitoring process including escalation mechanism for the follow-up on non-compliant privileged accounts. 18.12.2024 31.10.2025 31.10.2025 30.09.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Carsten Kreuz Karl Ulber Volker Scheer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Identity & Access Management (U) Identity & Access Management (ICA) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. A lack of processing controls and escalation mechanism for the Privileged Account Inventory may lead to an incomplete and inaccurate reporting on privileged accounts’ compliance status. Therefore, such privileged accounts might not be monitored and could be misused. This might lead to minor financial impact and material breach of internal and external provisions. Furthermore, it may result in material adverse regulatory impact, such as material potential for extra reporting requirements and/or regulatory examinations. Carsten Kreuz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Information Security framework
2024-078_F04 2024 2024-078 Privileged Access Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-078_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Not strict enough 2LoD Information Security requirements for Tier 1 privileged accounts The 2LoD Information Security Standard “Identity and Access Management V4.0” defined requirements for the handling of privileged accounts according to their tier level.

Internal Audit noted that the Tier 1 control requirements are not strict enough, specifically for video session recording (ID 77.1.1), password obfuscation (ID 77.1.2) and threat analysis (ID 77.1.3). All three control requirements were only required for Tier 0 accounts based on the 2LoD Information Security’s IAM standard (note: at least the 1LoD “PAM guideline V1.3” already required the stricter control requirements for Tier 1 accounts).

The root cause was the inadequate governance structure for the alignment of the fixed written rules.		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit recommend that ICT Risk Framework (KJU) adjust the information security standard “Identity & Access Management” for the three Tier 1 control requirements 17.1.1, 17.1.2 and 17.1.3 analogous Tier 0. 18.12.2024 12.12.2025 12.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sarah Ahmad Jahn, Petr Strnad, Christian Gorke Karl Ulber Volker Scheer HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Not strict enough 2nd LoD Information Security requirements for Tier 1 privileged accounts may lead to insecurely handling Tier 1 privileged accounts. This might lead to minor financial impact and material breach of internal and external provisions. Furthermore, it may result in material adverse regulatory impact, such as material potential for extra reporting requirements and/or regulatory examinations. Sarah Ahmad Jahn BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Information Security framework
2025-006_F01 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the Document – Business Development Process  Description As part of the preparation phase, Internal Audit (IA) obtained the outdated Document – Business Development Process Description, version 1.7. This version was already audited as part of the 2023-001 Product/Service Development audit identifying process description weaknesses as documented in finding 2023-001_F02. Additionally, OTC Product & Clearing Business Development (ZDY) initially showed a lack of awareness of responsibility for the process description again during this audit. ZDY then provided IA with Document – Business Development Process Description, version 1.8. This version was only partially dated indicating incompleteness of the process document review.

 

Based on version 1.8 provided, IA noted the following weaknesses:

There was a lack of evidence that version 1.8 was approved by the Head of Unit ZDY.

ZDY did not perform an annual review of the process description since submission of the process document to IA as part of the follow-up of 2023-001_F02 where version 1.8 was provided. Consequently, the process document was not up-to-date including outdated references to units and section names as well as the organisational chart. Additionally, IA noted the use of imprecise terminology whereas sections and units were referred to as an entity.

The procedure stated that initiatives were submitted to ZDY via a business requirement request form. However, there were other options such as emails, meetings and Committee input that were omitted from the procedure.

ZDY did not have central storage place within the unit for the process description where it would be available to all ZDY employees, nor was the updated version available in the ECAG Manual.

As part of the Eurex reorganisation, the unit ZDY was dissolved. The responsibility of the Business Development process was taken over by Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC).  		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) to assign clear roles and responsibilities within the Business Development process and corresponding process documentation.
Additionally, IA recommends DEC to assess potential impacts on the process following the reorganisation and document the Business Development process accordingly. IA recommends DEC e.g. to create or review and update the Document – Business Development Process Description, particularly to:
- Create or update the process description where necessary including, but not limited to, a description of how the business requirements are collected and documented, references to units and sections involved as well as the up-to-date organisational chart
- use precise terminology with regards to stakeholders involved in the process
- ensure an annual review is performed regularly 
- obtain approval of the updated version by at least the responsible Head of Section and respective approval documentation
- retain annual review and approval documentation for audit purposes
IA also recommends DEC to make the up-to-date process description available in a central place, namely the ECAG Manual. 		 21.05.2025 19.11.2025 19.11.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Efthimia Kefalea Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Derivatives Clearing Development (U) Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. 
Weaknesses in the Document – Business Development Process Description represent a material breach of regulatory requirements and internal provisions. It could impede on transparency and thus result in misunderstandings, processing errors and/or inadequately conducted tasks.  		 Efthimia Kefalea JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Obsolete - Lack of Awareness of Own Process Other framework
2025-006_F04 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Incorrect data controller information in RoPA ID 908 Business development services were provided under SDS MA-004371-2017 whereby EFAG London Branch as the insourcer provided services for ECAG as the outsourcer and sole data controller.

Internal Audit noted that the Record of Processing Activities (RoPA) ID 908 incorrectly included EFAG as a data controller. 		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit (IA) recommends Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) to assess if the current Record of Processing Activities (RoPA) ID 908 is still valid following reallocations of responsibilities and processes as part of the reorganisation. If the existing RoPA remains valid, IA recommends DEC to update the controller information data within the RoPA ID 908.  21.05.2025 19.11.2025 19.11.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Efthimia Kefalea Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Derivatives Clearing Development (U) Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Incorrect data controller information in RoPA ID 908 represents a minor violation of internal and external provisions. This could lead to a limited regulatory impact and limited reputational damage.  Efthimia Kefalea JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission GDPR framework
2025-006_F06 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Imprecise KPIs and non-timely monitoring in context of MA-004371-2017 Internal Audit (IA) assessed the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that were agreed as part of the SDS MA-004371-2017 between ECAG as outsourcer and EFAG London Branch as insourcer.

 

In context of OTC Product and Business Development two KPIs were agreed, namely KPI 1 “Task Completion” and KPI 2 “Timely Monthly Management Reporting”.

 

KPI 1

IA verified with the out- and insourcer that KPI 1 “Task Completion” was referring to the resource allocation of OTC Product & Clearing Business Development (ZDY) and their task completion. ZDY performed their services entirely for ECAG, hence this KPI would always be met in terms of resource allocation. Thus, IA concluded that this KPI was not meaningful.

KPI 2

According to the SDS, KPI 2 “Timely Monthly Management Reporting” foresees a monthly fulfilment. However, this KPI was tracked only on an annual basis via email confirmation at the beginning of the following year instead of an aligned monthly review to ensure timely monitoring and if necessary, intervention from ECAG. 		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends Strategy (DPA) to:

evaluate how to adequately measure the performance of the service provider in quantitative and/or qualitative terms

update the SDS MA-004371-2017 to include the measurable key performance indicators (KPIS) and circulate the SDS through the review cycle

monitor the KPIs timely 		 21.05.2025 19.11.2025 19.11.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Christian Schloter, Vasileios Vergotis Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Strategy (U) Strategy (DPA) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Imprecise KPIs and non-timely monitoring in context of MA-004371-2017 represent a minor violation of internal and external provisions. It could result in increased operational risk, negligible financial risk and limited reputational damage. It also bears the risk of a limited regulatory impact.   Vasileios Vergotis MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Outsourcing framework
2025-006_F08 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inconsistency between Pre-Assessment and RoPA ID 162 regarding controllership Internal Audit noted that joint controllership of ECAG and EFAG was incorrectly stated in the Pre-Assessment (Appway ID AN003), whereas only ECAG was correctly indicated as the controller in the RoPA ID 162.   Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends Strategy (DPA) to scrutinise the Pre-Assessment (Appway ID AN003), particularly the controller information and correct the inconsistency between the Pre-Assessment and RoPA ID 162.  21.05.2025 19.11.2025 19.11.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Christian Schloter, Vasileios Vergotis Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Strategy (U) Strategy (DPA) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Inconsistency between Pre-Assessment and RoPA ID 162 regarding controllership represents a minor violation of internal and external provisions. This could also lead to operational non-compliance with regulation with a limited regulatory impact and a potential of limited reputational damage.  Vasileios Vergotis MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Human Error/ Omission GDPR framework
2025-010_F02 2025 2025-010 CCP Regulation (ECAG) 2025-010_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the MAS Reporting process During the review, Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Reporting process:
§ The validity of responsibilities assigned within the MAS template “Annex 1 – RCG SAR template Responsibilities” could not be verified due to absence of a formal tracking mechanism for the assigned responsibilities of the respective units or business areas.
§ The evidence of the validation control performed, on the information provided by the involved areas to ensure accuracy, consistency with Eurex Frankfurt AG’s similar report to MAS, and alignment with the reports formerly submitted to MAS was not documented.
§ The business procedure mandated the inclusion of the functional email ccp-regulation@eurex.com in cc of the submission email for MAS Reports. However, the functional email was not included in cc in the submission email of 2024.

European and German regulation require that business activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines. This includes a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly define roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up systematically.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends CCP Regulation (CCD) to:
§ implement a formal tracking mechanism to document and monitor responsibilities assigned with the MAS reporting process. This mechanism should clearly define roles and responsibilities for each section of the report, ensuring complete coverage and accountability.
§ develop and implement documented process steps for validating data within the MAS reporting process. Additionally, ensure that the validity control is documented.
§ reinforce adherence to the established business procedure, specifically ensuring that ccp-regulation@eurex.com email address is included in the cc of all MAS report submission emails		 16.05.2025 09.02.2027 09.02.2027 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Jenny Poschmann Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Regulation (U) CCP Regulation (CCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the MAS Reporting process increases the risk of incomplete, inaccurate or inconsistent data being reported to MAS. This may lead to material violation of internal and external provisions, such as minor breach of regulatory requirements. Jenny Poschmann MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Process and/or Controls Other framework
2025-010_F04 2025 2025-010 CCP Regulation (ECAG) 2025-010_F04-A01 Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditee S1 Weaknesses in the Recovery & Resolution Planning process Internal Audit (IA) identified weaknesses in the Recovery & Resolution planning process, specifically in the Recovery Plan Maintenance & Update and Maintenance of Resolution Planning documents subprocesses.

For the Recovery Plan Maintenance & Update subprocess, IA noted that:
§ Section 4.1 “Overview of chapters and owners” of the business procedure was not exhaustive and created confusion regarding the appropriate ownership of chapters and sub-chapters.
§ The unit maintained a regularly reviewed and updated tracking sheet for the process, which also included the mailing list. Further, the unit also included a detailed overview of chapters and their owners within the business procedure. Comparison on the tracking sheet, business procedure and the overview included in unit’s L1 review email, obtained by IA as sample evidence, revealed several discrepancies. These discrepancies included outdated unit names, chapter owners, and point of contacts. Furthermore, certain chapter owners were missing from the mailing list maintained within the tracking sheet, while some were listed incorrectly.

For the Maintenance of Resolution Planning documents, IA noted that:
§ The process steps for granting access to new user to the MVP tool for BaFin resolution document submission were currently embedded within the “Reporting and Submission” section of the business procedure. However, during the review of the process, IA noted that these process steps were only performed in case a new user was to be added to the MVP tool for submission.
§ The business procedure required a review of the resolution planning documents by the Head of Unit of CCP Regulation (CCD), however the evidence of this review was not documented for 2023 and 2024.

European and German regulation require that business activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines. This includes a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly define the relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up systematically.		 Control Environment Internal Audit recommends CCP Regulation (CCD) to:
§ remove Section 4.1 “Overview of chapters and owners” of the business procedure, as Section 4.2 provides the detailed and adequate overview necessary
§ rectify the misalignment between the tracking sheet, business procedure, mailing list and the overview attached in the L1 review email evidence of the samples selected, to ensure accuracy and consistency of ownership and communication throughout the maintained documents
§ create a dedicated and clearly defined section within the business procedure specifically addressing the new user access provisioning to the MVP tool
§ implement a mechanism to document the review of the Head of Unit of CCP Regulation (CCD), such as documented email confirmation. Ensure all reviews are consistently documented going forward		 16.05.2025 12.11.2025 12.11.2025 28.10.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Jenny Poschmann Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Regulation (U) CCP Regulation (CCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the Recovery & Resolution Planning documents process represents a minor breach of regulatory requirements and internal provisions with a negligible financial impact. Jenny Poschmann MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission Other framework
2025-012_F01 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Inadequate Frankfurt data centres failover and disaster recovery testing Internal Audit (IA) identified the annual Disaster Recovery (DR) testing (for DBG data centres in Frankfurt) did not include complete full data centre failover - at least since 2022. This was visible again in DBG’s 2024 annual DR report. Thus, critical processes and relevant IT services remained untested and might not work as expected in case of a complete DC failure. The available IT Resiliency Management procedure did not include a detailed data centre failover scenario to ensure the participation of all IT product areas and their sufficient testing.

Further, no DR scenario had been defined at the time of the audit review   , to test the IT infrastructure and system capacity as part of a complete data centre failover, neither during dedicated testing window, nor during long lasting test exercise running at least all business-critical processes and services in a failover mode during regular business hours.

DORA article 25 (2) requires financial entities to test their ICT business continuity plans and assess whether they can ensure the financial entity’s critical or important functions’ continuity. Testing shall be based on test scenarios that simulate potential disruptions, including an adequate set of severe but plausible scenarios; and contain scenarios of switchover from primary ICT infrastructure to the redundant capacity, backups and redundant facilities. The Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 Articles 12, 18 and 19 define similar or further operational continuity requirements, including assessing the overall recovery capacity.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Networks, Data Center & Virtualization (ZFI) design and implement a disaster recovery (DR) plan for full data centre failover testing.    The DR plan and its testing shall, at least annually, include all IT services to recover all business processes and sufficient capacity testing.
The DR scenario testing shall include the following but not be limited to:
§ Data centre isolation to perform a full failover
§ Duration of the data centre isolation shall be aligned with requirements of the IT services		 28.05.2025 31.03.2026 31.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Eric Reding Frank Ackermann Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Networks, Data Center & Virtualizati (S) Networks, Data Center & Virtualization (ZFI) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate Frankfurt   data centres failover and disaster recovery (DR) testing may expose the company to severe IT system and service unavailability of critical and important business functions through unknown shortcomings or unanticipated dependencies, preventing a proper and timely service restoration. Further, the secondary data centre’s full production load capabilities in case of a disaster cannot be demonstrated, which may significantly impact DR measures in case they are required. The increased geopolitical instability is also leading to additional cyberthreat and physical security threat. As a consequence of operational unavailability risk, these DR plan weaknesses may lead to major financial loss and severe regulatory fines, overall resulting in material reputational damage. Eric Reding CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions BCM framework CSDR 2017/392,CSDR L1 909/2014
2025-012_F01 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Inadequate Frankfurt data centres failover and disaster recovery testing Internal Audit (IA) identified the annual Disaster Recovery (DR) testing (for DBG data centres in Frankfurt) did not include complete full data centre failover - at least since 2022. This was visible again in DBG’s 2024 annual DR report. Thus, critical processes and relevant IT services remained untested and might not work as expected in case of a complete DC failure. The available IT Resiliency Management procedure did not include a detailed data centre failover scenario to ensure the participation of all IT product areas and their sufficient testing.

Further, no DR scenario had been defined at the time of the audit review   , to test the IT infrastructure and system capacity as part of a complete data centre failover, neither during dedicated testing window, nor during long lasting test exercise running at least all business-critical processes and services in a failover mode during regular business hours.

DORA article 25 (2) requires financial entities to test their ICT business continuity plans and assess whether they can ensure the financial entity’s critical or important functions’ continuity. Testing shall be based on test scenarios that simulate potential disruptions, including an adequate set of severe but plausible scenarios; and contain scenarios of switchover from primary ICT infrastructure to the redundant capacity, backups and redundant facilities. The Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 Articles 12, 18 and 19 define similar or further operational continuity requirements, including assessing the overall recovery capacity.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends that IT Governance & Resilience (GEM) revise the IT Resiliency Management Procedure by explicitly requiring regular execution of full data centre failover testing including mandatory participation of all shared and product IT teams. Reporting of the test participation and results of all critical applications (including relevant dependencies as outlined in P1) will follow the defined resilience governance and reporting structure. 28.05.2025 31.03.2026 31.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Nanjiao Wilhelms-Wang Frank Ackermann Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance & Resilience (U) Governance & Execution Management (GEM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate Frankfurt   data centres failover and disaster recovery (DR) testing may expose the company to severe IT system and service unavailability of critical and important business functions through unknown shortcomings or unanticipated dependencies, preventing a proper and timely service restoration. Further, the secondary data centre’s full production load capabilities in case of a disaster cannot be demonstrated, which may significantly impact DR measures in case they are required. The increased geopolitical instability is also leading to additional cyberthreat and physical security threat. As a consequence of operational unavailability risk, these DR plan weaknesses may lead to major financial loss and severe regulatory fines, overall resulting in material reputational damage. Nanjiao Wilhelms-Wang CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions BCM framework CSDR 2017/392,CSDR L1 909/2014
2025-012_F02 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls Internal Audit’s (IA) March 2025 inspections and walkthrough of the Frankfurt Rödelheim/Germany NTT and Contern/Luxembourg Verizon data centres (DCs), assisted by Data Centre Management (ICV), identified the following physical security and access control deficiencies:

§ DBG DC room video monitoring – The DCs’ closed-circuit television (CCTV) video monitoring of the DBG-rented DC rooms only covered entry and exit points. Other DC room areas were not CCTV-monitored, creating blind areas particularly for the critical IT infrastructure aisles with business-critical data. These DC rooms are technical rooms facilitating operation of DBG’s IT infrastructure. Any unescorted and escorted person could cause intentional or unintentional damage to unmonitored ICT systems. IA was informed the same video monitoring approach was in place in all DBG DCs, including those not inspected (Equinix in Frankfurt Seckbach/Germany and CBL-owned in Kirchberg/Luxembourg).

§ NTT DC video monitoring – NTT’s video monitoring covered the entry and exit doors, gates and the direct fence areas. NTT did not cover the generators, fire suppression, uninterruptible power supply (UPS), and air-conditioning systems critical areas. The auditors observed onsite that these critical infrastructure components were also left without further monitoring during maintenance activity. NTT confirmed the compliance to their common standards which would include CCTV monitoring and escorting of maintenance work, which remained in contradiction to the auditors’ observations.

§ DC pool-badge (visitor) management process – DBG’s NTT DC physical security concept for authorised staff relied on three-step authentication: electronic key (badge), unique pin-code and biometric authentication (hand scan). However, for Physical Security (FSE)-issued pool-badges, used for third-party access to secure areas, the pin-code was written directly on each badge for life-time usage. Further, these pool-badges were active permanently and under NTT custody. Therefore, the established pool-badge management process between Data Centre Management (ICV) and NTT would not prevent unauthorized badge usage. The pool-badge usage did not generate any alarm or notification, and NTT shared the usage report once per month. Regular data correlation between access requests and badge reader log data was not performed as a mitigation measure.

§ Anti-ram protection – The NTT DC area perimeter and physical barrier inspection identified a vulnerability resulting from the neighbouring area, a car park and garages close to DC rooms. The NTT DC was built very close to the neighbouring area, only leaving 3-4 metres between the building and the fence, allowing no further safeguard distance. As a result, instead of e.g. concrete barriers, pollards or rocks to stop vehicles, the only protection was a simple metal chain-link fence. IA’s interview of NTT confirmed their risk assessment did not include this area. NTT confirmed later they did not see the need for anti-ram protection in the absence of related incidents in the past and would only install such protections for DIN EN 50600 certified DCs, which DBG had not required.

DORA article 28 and the EBA Guidelines on ICT and security risk management (EBA/GL/2019/04) ask financial institutions identify and manage their ICT and security risks. The ICT function(s) should manage all risks identified within the financial institution’s risk appetite limits and in compliance with external and internal requirements. Policies, procedures and controls shall limit physical or logical access to information assets and ICT assets.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Physical Security (FSE) mitigate the data centre physical security risk by:
§ setting up video monitoring for each DBG data centre suites’ aisle at the Frankfurt Seckbach and Rödelheim, Luxembourg Kirchberg and Contern locations, and include it in the existing CCTV system		 28.05.2025 31.03.2026 31.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG David Krüger Lasha Shishniashvili Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Physical Security (U) Physical Security (FSE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls raise concerns about the integrity and availability of critical organisational services in case of physical security threats. Resulting vulnerabilities increase the likelihood of IT service disruptions, data loss, and service outages. Such incidents could lead to significant financial losses, regulatory penalties, and severe reputational damage. David Krüger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Physical security/accesses CSDR L1 909/2014,CSSF Circular 20/750
2025-012_F02 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls Internal Audit’s (IA) March 2025 inspections and walkthrough of the Frankfurt Rödelheim/Germany NTT and Contern/Luxembourg Verizon data centres (DCs), assisted by Data Centre Management (ICV), identified the following physical security and access control deficiencies:

§ DBG DC room video monitoring – The DCs’ closed-circuit television (CCTV) video monitoring of the DBG-rented DC rooms only covered entry and exit points. Other DC room areas were not CCTV-monitored, creating blind areas particularly for the critical IT infrastructure aisles with business-critical data. These DC rooms are technical rooms facilitating operation of DBG’s IT infrastructure. Any unescorted and escorted person could cause intentional or unintentional damage to unmonitored ICT systems. IA was informed the same video monitoring approach was in place in all DBG DCs, including those not inspected (Equinix in Frankfurt Seckbach/Germany and CBL-owned in Kirchberg/Luxembourg).

§ NTT DC video monitoring – NTT’s video monitoring covered the entry and exit doors, gates and the direct fence areas. NTT did not cover the generators, fire suppression, uninterruptible power supply (UPS), and air-conditioning systems critical areas. The auditors observed onsite that these critical infrastructure components were also left without further monitoring during maintenance activity. NTT confirmed the compliance to their common standards which would include CCTV monitoring and escorting of maintenance work, which remained in contradiction to the auditors’ observations.

§ DC pool-badge (visitor) management process – DBG’s NTT DC physical security concept for authorised staff relied on three-step authentication: electronic key (badge), unique pin-code and biometric authentication (hand scan). However, for Physical Security (FSE)-issued pool-badges, used for third-party access to secure areas, the pin-code was written directly on each badge for life-time usage. Further, these pool-badges were active permanently and under NTT custody. Therefore, the established pool-badge management process between Data Centre Management (ICV) and NTT would not prevent unauthorized badge usage. The pool-badge usage did not generate any alarm or notification, and NTT shared the usage report once per month. Regular data correlation between access requests and badge reader log data was not performed as a mitigation measure.

§ Anti-ram protection – The NTT DC area perimeter and physical barrier inspection identified a vulnerability resulting from the neighbouring area, a car park and garages close to DC rooms. The NTT DC was built very close to the neighbouring area, only leaving 3-4 metres between the building and the fence, allowing no further safeguard distance. As a result, instead of e.g. concrete barriers, pollards or rocks to stop vehicles, the only protection was a simple metal chain-link fence. IA’s interview of NTT confirmed their risk assessment did not include this area. NTT confirmed later they did not see the need for anti-ram protection in the absence of related incidents in the past and would only install such protections for DIN EN 50600 certified DCs, which DBG had not required.

DORA article 28 and the EBA Guidelines on ICT and security risk management (EBA/GL/2019/04) ask financial institutions identify and manage their ICT and security risks. The ICT function(s) should manage all risks identified within the financial institution’s risk appetite limits and in compliance with external and internal requirements. Policies, procedures and controls shall limit physical or logical access to information assets and ICT assets.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Data Centre Management (ICV) mitigate the identified NTT data centre’s DBG area security risks, including:
§ defining a secure procedure to manage the NTT data centre Frankfurt Rödelheim visitor badges, reducing the identified risk in liasion with Physical Security (FSE)
§ align with the NTT data centre provider on options to mitigate the data centre area’s risk of terrorism and physical attack from the unprotected neighbouring areas, and take a risk-based decision on mitigation
§ align with the NTT data centre provider on options to implement video monitoring of all critical exterior areas including generators, fire suppression systems, UPS systems, and air-conditioning systems and take a risk-based decision on mitigation
§ obtain formal risk acceptance for risks that will not be mitigated		 28.05.2025 31.03.2026 31.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Dominik Matzanke, Andreas Tabbert, Moritz Steinbach Lasha Shishniashvili Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Data Centre Management (U) Data Centre Management (ICV) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls raise concerns about the integrity and availability of critical organisational services in case of physical security threats. Resulting vulnerabilities increase the likelihood of IT service disruptions, data loss, and service outages. Such incidents could lead to significant financial losses, regulatory penalties, and severe reputational damage. Dominik Matzanke CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Physical security/accesses CSDR L1 909/2014,CSSF Circular 20/750
2025-016_F01 2025 2025-016 Default Management (ECAG) 2025-016_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in Default Management test plan Internal Audit (IA) observed that the Credit Risk & Default Management (DCZ) team independently determined the scope of the annual default management test plan. Given the nature of the default management process, many teams within the company are involved in the process in various capacities, particularly in the liquidation of the inherited portfolio, such as executing and settling trade instructions. Since the default of a clearing member is an uncommon event, many of the corresponding procedures triggered only in a default event have not been executed or tested. Without this coordination, operational readiness in case of a clearing member default cannot be ensured. 

 

EU regulations mandate that central counterparties regularly conduct simulations (tests) of clearing member default scenarios. These tests are crucial to ensure the CCP’s and its clearing members’ operational readiness, identify bottlenecks and improve procedures for liquidating defaulted portfolios. 		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends that the yearly test plan is circulated to the process owners of all processes related to Default Management. The process owners’ review should be integrated into the approval of the annual test plan and ensure that all processes related to the Default Management process, i.e., all process considered as interface processes according to the most up-to-date DMP checklists , should be included in scope of the test plan on a regular basis. 18.06.2025 13.03.2026 13.03.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Hannes Hauenschild, Vincent Prepin Robert Pardikes Robert Pardikes THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Credit Risk & Default Management (S) Credit Risk & Default Management (DCZ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Weaknesses in Default Management test plan could lead to inadequate operational readiness in the event of a clearing member default due to undetected operational weaknesses resulting in uncoordinated or delayed responses during an actual default event. The identified weakness could result in minor financial and material adverse regulatory impact.  Hannes Hauenschild DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Lack of Awareness
2025-020_F01 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Ineffective purchasing processes and controls The audit of the Purchasing process revealed a range of weaknesses related to inconsistencies in process and control design, gaps in control execution and process inefficiencies. These issues mostly affect core purchasing processes including the Source-to-Contract, Purchase-to-Pay and Car Fleet Management processes. Minor gaps were noted in the Supplier Management process. Internal Audit (IA) noted that purchasing process documentation lacks overall clarity, completeness and accuracy, further impacting operational consistency and effectiveness.

IA noted the following key issues related to control design and operating effectiveness:

§ Weaknesses in the control framework related to inconsistent frequency and allocation of controls in the Purchasing Manual, SAP GRC ICS and control documentation, leading to misalignment with actual practices. The majority of controls were executed at least twice, ad hoc and periodically as “compliance check”. Further, clear guidelines for sample-based purchasing controls including responsibilities, segregation of duties and follow-up activities, were lacking. This approach, combined with a high volume of purchasing operations, limited process efficiency.
§ Unclear instructions on specific process steps and control applicability in different purchasing tools, dispersed across the Purchasing Manual and related tool-specific guidelines. This led to misunderstanding of the process flow and associated controls.
§ Other minor deficiencies in the Purchasing Manual regarding inaccurate and outdated flow-charts, unclear descriptions of contract call-offs applicability, goods receipt confirmation and inaccuracies concerning access right checks conducted for internally managed catalogues. Inaccuracies related to Supplier Governance Committee existing for ECAG, CBF, Eurex Repo, and DBAG, but not Clearstream Holding. Also, there were gaps in SAP GRC ICS as the Car Fleet Management process was not included in the Process Map and there were no entries for issue management and escalation, relating to supplier management.
§ Inadequate controls over Waivers of Competitive Bid (Bid Waiver) as Corporate Purchasing (FPU) did not ensure completeness and accuracy of all Bid Waiver requests prior to approval. In addition, there was a lack of automated controls disabling submission of incomplete digital Bid Waiver request forms and ensuring approval solely by Board Members in specific cases.
§ Limited effectiveness of Source-to-Contract and Purchase-to-Pay process caused by lack of operational consistency, missing process and control documentation. On a sample of 18 Purchase Orders with 24 transactions IA Identified gaps related to lack of sourcing documentation in one case, unclear rules regarding quantitative evaluations of bids and savings calculation. Also, one control over Purchase Order Modifications was not implemented.
Lastly, IA noted that only one fully trained FTE possessed the necessary expertise to perform complex data analytics and reporting tasks. There was no risk identified in relation to the continuation of the core purchasing processes, however, this lead to Internal Audit experiencing delays in receiving the requested data and performing timely audit testing. This resource constraint further highlights the need for increased knowledge transfer and resource resilience in FPU.
Overall, redundant and repetitive controls created confusion, with negative impact on the control environment, process efficiency and availability of accurate audit evidence.
In line with external and internal provisions, an institution should maintain adequate arrangements, safeguards and controls to ensure an effective internal control system and risk management. Business activities must be conducted based on up-to-date written procedures, with clearly defined roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls. Moreover, control activities need to be defined, documented and presented in a way that is understandable by third parties.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Corporate Purchasing (FPU):
§ undertake a comprehensive review and streamlining of the end-to-end purchasing process and control framework. The objective should be simplification and clarification of the process execution ensuring that necessary controls are applied, while eliminating duplication and inefficiencies. Specifically, IA recommends that FPU holistically reviews and updates the process and control framework, including SAP GRC ICS, with focus on identification of key controls, frequency of implementation, adequate segregation of duties and remediation measures.
§ ensure that all controls are implemented as designed with sufficient audit trail
§ implement appropriate automated controls to ensure that bid waivers are approved based on complete and accurate information and with necessary Board Member approvals, in line with the process requirements
§ reduce key person dependency by training team members, and documenting work instructions regarding data analytics and related reporting tasks
§ correct the identified deficiencies and inaccuracies in the Purchasing Manual		 25.04.2025 27.03.2026 27.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lars Juretzko, Stefan Schwind Ourania Androulaki Petya Dimitrova Pencheva JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Purchasing (S) Corporate Purchasing (FPU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Ineffective purchasing processes and controls increase the risk of noncompliance with procurement rules, material operational errors and inefficiencies. The lack of proper documentation, justifications and segregation of duties further reduces transparency in purchasing decisions, limits auditability and weakens internal oversight.  Stefan Schwind ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Process and/or Controls Purchasing framework
2025-020_F02 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in credit card management and controls Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in credit card management process:
§ Inconsistent control frequency between relevant credit card procedures and SAP GRC ICS.
§ Lack of record keeping and audit trail on approved and revoked credit cards prior to new process implementation and prior to AirPlus Portal (AID2144) update and migration.
§ Lack of and gaps in control execution including lack of audit trail on performed ad hoc and periodic controls.

Further, IA noted that data on credit cards in the AirPlus Portal was incomplete and inaccurate. Specifically, the population of active and revoked credit cards for the period under review was lacking data on several active credit cards identified in control evidence. In addition, IA identified a card holder that did not register in AirPlus Portal as the card was issued during the portal migration.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that General & IT Purchasing (FIG):
§ review and align controls frequency in credit card procedures and SAP GRC ICS
§ perform all controls as defined in relevant credit cards procedures
§ ensure sufficient audit trail and complete records on all credit cards, process execution and implemented controls
§ ensure complete and accurate data on all credit cards in relevant tool		 25.04.2025 16.03.2026 16.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG David Crompton, Lars Juretzko Ana Kosela Petya Dimitrova Pencheva JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer General & IT Purchasing (U) General & IT Purchasing (FIG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in credit card management and controls could lead to inadequate process risk identification and assessment as well as operational errors.  Incomplete records and data pose the risk of insufficient assessment of control effectiveness that may result in inadequate identification of systematic issues. This represents material breach of external and internal requirements.  David Crompton ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Lack of Awareness of Own Process Purchasing framework
2025-020_F03 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F03-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over Third Party Management (TPM) framework agreements There was no defined or documented framework specifying the conditions under which Third Party Management (TPM) framework agreements for professional services should be established. Guidance available in the Purchasing Manual inadequately addressed the governance of these agreements leading to inconsistent practices in the initiation, approval and monitoring. A framework agreement sets out the general terms and conditions which apply to subsequent individual contracts and program agreements.

In particular, Internal Audit noted the following:
§ Description of the Framework Purchase Order (PO) buying channel in the Purchasing Manual was inaccurate and unclear, particularly regarding ownership, exemptions, and the sign-off process.
§ The supplier identification and selection criteria as well as triggers for concluding a TPM framework agreement were not formally set out.
§ Inadequate segregation of duties as Corporate Purchasing (FPU) performed a dual role acting as both the Business Owner (BO) of TPM framework agreements and as support function ensuring compliance with the purchasing procedures. In addition, there were no clear authorisation rules requiring line management involvement, leading to inconsistencies in framework agreements sign-off and insufficient management oversight.
§ There was no defined and established independent monitoring of these agreements and risks stemming from FPUs dual role

German, and Luxembourg regulations and guidance require an institution to maintain robust internal governance and risk management systems. This includes ensuring proper segregation of duties and establishing clear criteria for triggering specific agreements to enhance operational transparency. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Corporate Purchasing (FPU) establish appropriate governance over TPM framework agreements. In particular, IA recommends that FPU:
§ update the Framework PO buying channel description to accurately reflect applicability, exemptions and ownership of framework agreements
§ define clear criteria, conditions and triggers for supplier identification and conclusion of framework agreements
§ standardise roles and responsibilities for initiation, review and authorisation of framework agreements with mandatory line management involvement
§ ensure independent oversight over framework agreements with related individual contracts and program agreements, by regular status reporting to senior management		 25.04.2025 20.11.2025 20.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lars Juretzko, Stefan Schwind Ana Kosela Petya Dimitrova Pencheva JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Purchasing (S) Corporate Purchasing (FPU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate governance over TPM framework agreements can result in inconsistent and non-compliant procurement practices and insufficient oversight. Together with lack of segregation of duties, inadequate governance may lead to biased decision-making, limited objectivity and transparency when evaluating agreements. Ultimately, this may hinder DBG’s ability to effectively monitor procurement spend and manage supplier agreements and relationships.  Stefan Schwind ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Purchasing framework
