2025-020_F04 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F04-A01 Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditee S2 Weaknesses in the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) In 2021, the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) was established as an advisory body for the selection of supplier relationships and review of supplier risks for Corporate Purchasing and the corresponding Terms of Reference (ToR) for DBAG, CBF, ECAG and ExR were prepared. These were last updated in the context of the introduction of the Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (LkSG) effective January 2023. No specific internal requirements for voluntary committees exist.
As Committee members, the Terms of Reference (ToR) defines several function takers of first and second Lines of Defense (LoD) in Chapter 6.1. Each Committee member has one vote and thus has a direct influence on supplier onboarding decisions. Internal Audit is nominated as a non-voting guest on a permanent basis. Overall guests have no voting rights.

Internal Audit noticed that the ToR for the SGC was lacking:
§ clear policies and mechanisms to avoid conflicts of interest
§ a regular rotation of committee members
§ verification and disclosure of members regarding direct financial or personal interests in the supplier
In addition, the distribution/participants list for the Legal entity specific Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) was outdated and did not comply with the defined function takers of first and second LoD (e.g. the Human Rights Officer as responsible under LkSG for monitoring risk management within the company was not part of any of the distribution list for DBAG, CBF, ECAG or ExR).

The DBG Business Code of Conduct defines DBG's conduct and ethical principles. As "tone at the top", they form the benchmark for entrepreneurial decisions and entrepreneurial action. Together, with internal compliance guidelines, particularly the DBG Policy on Conflicts of Interest, the expectations of the behavior of all managers and employees as well as business practices are addressed to ensure compliance with the values and principles of the DBG.  		 Control Environment Internal Audit recommend that Supplier Governance & Control (SGC) review and update the Terms of Reference for Supplier Governance Committee with regards to the identified deficiencies and include:
§ clear policies and mechanisms to avoid conflicts of interest to ensure that decisions are made in the best interest of the company
§ a regulation to promote the independence of the Committee through the possibility of a regular and gradual rotation of the voting members or their representatives, for example, every 3-4 years to minimise the likelihood of long-term conflicts of interest
§ a regulation to regular/annually obtain self-disclosures from members regarding direct financial or personal interests in the supplier and prompt disclosure to ensure the objectivity and fairness of the committee and to preserve the integrity of supplier relationships
In addition, to review and update the distribution/participants list for the LE-specific SGCs and to monitor and question long-term representation of nominated function holders with voting rights.		 25.04.2025 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 27.10.2025 0 Clearstream Europe AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH Clearstream Europe AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH Deutsche Börse AG Lars Juretzko Sandra Schwarz Petya Dimitrova Pencheva JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Supplier Governance & Control (U) Supplier Governance & Control (SGC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) can lead to conflicts of interest, resulting in inefficient supplier decisions, higher costs, and lower quality of goods or services. This may cause mistrust and tensions within the SGC and internally if decisions are perceived as unfair. Additionally, it could expose DBG to material reputational risk if violations of the Business Code of Conduct become public, impairing trust and potentially leading to loss of business relationships with minor financial impact. Lars Juretzko GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Purchasing framework
2025-020_F05 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lacking definition and action for identified supplier issues or incidents The Purchasing Manual contained mitigating actions based on the risk score for identified issues or incidents with a supplier. If the risk score was yellow, a remote audit should be conducted.

Internal Audit noted that this remote audit requirement was not fulfilled. The reporting for the second half of 2024 contained five suppliers with a yellow risk score and no related remote audits had been conducted.

In addition, the Purchasing Manual stated that the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) decides about measures for red risk scores. SGC exists for ECAG, CBF, Eurex Repo, and DBAG. IA noted that for all other legal entities without an SGC, the procedure related to red risk scores was not defined.

In this context, Corporate Purchasing (FPU) represented that so far, a red classification had never occurred.

In line with German and Luxembourg regulation and DBG policy, business activities must be conducted based on organizational guidelines. They should include a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and controls. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Supplier Governance & Control (SGC):
§ define in the Purchasing Manual the required measures for red risk scores for legal entities without an SGC.
§ apply the measures as defined for the suppliers with yellow and red risk scores. This could imply changing the existing definitions (e.g., remote audits for yellow risk scores) and/or defining a reporting procedure in case of non-compliance		 25.04.2025 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lars Juretzko Randi Montgomery Petya Dimitrova Pencheva JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Supplier Governance & Control (U) Supplier Governance & Control (SGC unit) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lacking definition and action for identified supplier issues or incidents represent a minor breach of regulatory requirements and violations of internal and external provisions. Unclearly defined roles and responsibilities and failure to conduct defined mitigating action may lead to inadequate handling of issues and/or incidents. Examples are that certain required individuals are not involved, or nobody takes responsibility and action.  Lars Juretzko ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Purchasing framework
2025-023_F01 2025 2025-023 Branch ECAG Prague (ECAG) 2025-023_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Deficiencies in the Foreign Permanent Establishment CZ procedure Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Foreign Permanent Establishments
(Compliance)_v.1.5_draft_CZ procedure which describes how Value
Added Tax (VAT) and Corporate Income Tax (CIT) are filed for Czech
entities. The following deficiencies were noted:
▪ Business procedure was not approved by the line manager and it
was in a draft form since June 2022.
▪ Outdated 4EP controls: Step 11 of the VAT business procedure and
step 12 of the CIT were still existing in the business procedure.
▪ The business procedure does not mention how or where the
electronic submission of VAT Tax return is performed.		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit (IA) recommends that International Taxes, Tax Reporting and M&A (ZGY) review and update the description of the website where the final tax report will be filed, ensuring outdated controls are removed.
Subsequently, publish the Foreign Permanent Establishments CZ procedure after obtaining approval from the line manager		 29.04.2025 29.08.2025 01.04.2026 29.08.2025 1 CS Luxembourg,Deutsche Börse AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG CS Luxembourg,Deutsche Börse AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Deutsche Börse AG Ralph Kielmann Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Group Tax (A) Nancy Eva Schanda International Taxes, Tax Reporting and M International Taxes, Tax Reporting and M&A (ZGY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. The deficiencies in the Foreign Permanent Establishment CZ procedure
represent a minor violation of internal provisions that may lead to
negligible regulatory and/or financial impacts. Outdated or incorrect
procedure document could result in regulatory non-compliance,
operational inefficiencies, financial inaccuracies, and cause potential
reputational damage. 2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE):
- establishes adequate requirements for DBAG’s regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in Process Maps and Risk Control Matrices of legal entities under ZHE supervision – DBAG (except for DBAG IT).		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Thomas Heinze Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Group Risk Governance & ICS (U) Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Thomas Heinze ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for CBF’s, CBL’s, CH’s, CI’s and CS’s regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under ZFE supervision - CBF, CBL, CH, CI and CS.
- reviews Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CH, CI and CS.		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Europe AG Federico Miranda Fonseca Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) UDO HENKELMANN Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Controls Assurance & Monitoring (U) Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Federico Miranda Fonseca ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for DBAG CIO/COO Division’s regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under IRT supervision – DBAG IT.		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Boris Link, Johannes Hugo Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Boris Link ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2

- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes.

It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for ECAG’s (as a legal entity) regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under FRB supervision – ECAG.		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Eurex Clearing AG Oussama Fakih Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (U) Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Oussama Fakih ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A06 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Corporate and Outsourcing Monitoring (XMZ):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and implements adequate requirements for LuxCSD’s (as a legal entity) regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entity under XMZ supervision – LuxCSD.		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD LUXCSD Carolyn Linnevers Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO CALIGARIS Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Corporate and Outsourcing Monitoring (U) Corporate and Outsourcing Monitoring (XMZ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Carolyn Linnevers ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A07 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Outsourcing & Controls (KOU):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and CFCL Risk Management (KMA) to operationalize adequate requirements for CFCL’s, CFCS’s and CFCHK’s (as a legal entity) regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under KOU supervision – CFCL, CFCHK and CFCS. 		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Adriaan Bemelmans Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO STEEG Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll Outsourcing & Controls (U) Outsourcing & Controls (KOU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. The second part of the recommendation was implemented before the audit report issuance date. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Adriaan Bemelmans ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A08 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Regulatory Framework and Implementation (RGL):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for EFAG’s, ExR’s and Cash Market’s (as a virtual entity) regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under RGL supervision – EFAG, ExR and Cash Market (as a virtual entity).		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Eurex Frankfurt AG Aleksandra Golon Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) MELANIE DANNHEIMER Trading & Clearing (Div) Cash Market (A) Eric Leupold Regulatory Framework & Implementatio (U) Regulatory Framework and Implementation (RGL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes.
