It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Corporate (CPT):
- establishes adequate requirements for the regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting to the CAL management.
- closely aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE), working on DBG’s minimum requirements for the regular evaluation of key internal controls; ensures that individual legal entity requirements align with the DBG minimum requirements and regulatory specifications.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entity under CPT supervision – CAL.		 04.07.2025 10.12.2026 10.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Warren Peter Morton Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) BERNARD TANCRÉ Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll Corporate (U) Corporate (CPT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Warren Peter Morton ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE):
* revises the ICS framework (including the ICS Guideline) to outline minimum requirements for the regular evaluation of key internal controls by the individual legal entities’ ICS experts.
Among other, the minimum requirements should:
- define clear criteria for internal control key or standard classification;
- outline measures for maintaining consistency and alignment of key vs standard controls;
- define a specific assurance protocols/control assessments by Control Owners around key controls;
- specify existing ICS testing teams’ testing responsibilities (e.g. Risk & Control Assurance team (LOD)) around key internal controls;
- specify the mandatory fields in the different ICS components.
* specifies requirements for the legal entity ICS Experts’ ICS Effectiveness Report to management: the report shall give detail on effectiveness of key controls, including measures taken to conclude, results, identified deficiencies and mitigating actions.
* defines and communicates measures to ensure internal consistency checks on the formal quality of the documentation, in particular with regards to the redefined mandatory field of the ICS components. 		 04.07.2025 21.11.2025 21.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Thomas Heinze Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Group Risk Governance & ICS (U) Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Thomas Heinze ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/552,MaRisk AT 4.3.2
2025-024_F02 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Misalignment of CIFs identified with processes requiring BCP coverage and incomplete BCM framework. Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

The following CIF-relevant processes without BCP were identified per Legal Entity:
§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. Moreover, the CIF Identification Procedure has not offered any further clarification for inclusion and documentation regarding CIF relevant processes and considerations given during the CIF identification process		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB):
§ Updates the current BCM framework for ECAG and amend relevant processes and procedures to clarify the handling of essential, necessary or desirable CIF-relevant processes and how they should be considered and treated in terms of business continuity.
§ Ensure that the relevant processes under CIF have a BCP in place or assess and document the root cause for the deviation resulting from the Business Impact Analysis (BIA) and the CIF classification.		 04.07.2025 10.11.2025 10.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Oussama Fakih Iryna Neurath Elizaveta Veselova HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (U) Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Misalignment of Critical or Important Functions identified with processes requiring Business Continuity Plan coverage and incomplete BCM framework may lead to non-compliance with regulations, which may further lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage and regulatory scrutiny. Additionally, the potential lack of appropriate business continuity measures might expose the organisation to business continuity risks. As Internal Audit did not assess the identified processes without a BCP as critical, their absence does not pose a significant risk to the organisation’s continuity objectives.  Oussama Fakih ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls

Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. Moreover, the CIF Identification Procedure has not offered any further clarification for inclusion and documentation regarding CIF relevant processes and considerations given during the CIF identification process		 Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-024_F02 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F02-A04 Multi-Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditee S2 Misalignment of CIFs identified with processes requiring BCP coverage and incomplete BCM framework. Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. 2025-024_F04 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weakness in controls for timely termination and recertification of external employees Internal Audit (IA) identified weaknesses in the external employees’ identity and access management’s request and change processes regarding timely offboarding and termination in SAP Mini-master and recertification of external employees.

SAP S/4HANA (AID489) Human Capital Management (HCM) module’s Mini-master process is used to manage on- and offboarding data for external employees. During an external employee’s onboarding, the “valid until” date field is populated in SAP Mini-master. Once this date is reached, SailPoint IIQ (AID760) automatically blocks both physical and system access.

However, when the contract ends or if an external employee leaves earlier than expected, termination must be manually initiated in SAP Mini-master by entering the new effective leave date. Termination ensures the employee is marked as “inactive”, and their access is blocked in a timely manner. IA noted that due to delays by line managers, 263 external employees who had already left before 2024 were only terminated in SAP Mini-master in 2024.

IA acknowledges that the following controls were in place:
§ a "Dead Man Lock" is automatically applied to deactivate user accounts after 28 days of inactivity.
§ a quarterly awareness information campaign is published through DBG communication channels (e.g. Intranet, Viva Engage), and End User Trainings are provided on SAP Mini-master system maintenance.
§ a new initiative is being introduced, which will result in automatic termination of the Mini-master record when the “valid until” date arrives.
However, this initiative does not cover scenarios where an external employee leaves before the “valid until” date. In such cases, manual termination is still required.

Furthermore, IA identified recertification process weaknesses. Based on the “contact person” data field, SAP Mini-master sent regularly, in the middle of the month, an automated notification to the respective contact persons/ordering party (line or project managers) to recertify active external employees or initiate offboarding. If the contact person took no action, two more notifications were sent before the month end, with the line manager in copy of the final reminder. However, Purchasing (FPU) had no additional controls in place if recertification was not conducted even after these notifications.

In line with European, German, Luxembourg regulation and internal requirements, an entity should establish controls to identify and manage unauthorised user access to the applications.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Purchasing (FPU) establish additional controls to ensure:
§ timely offboarding and termination in SAP Mini-master
§ recertification of external employees by respective line managers		 04.07.2025 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Stefan Schwind Trupti Thakur Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Purchasing (S) Purchasing (FPU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Delay in termination of external employees may:
§ lead to former external employees retaining access after leaving the organisation, potentially enabling them to still access IT systems and misuse their access rights for unauthorised activity.
§ result in a material violation of internal and external provisions related to the Information Security framework.		 Stefan Schwind ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),PHILIPPE SEYLL(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-025_F01 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in the AI Governance Framework Deutsche Börse Group (DBG) has named Artificial intelligence (AI) as a key driver of digital leadership as part of its Horizon 2026 strategy. DBG aims to transition from the status of Observer to Practitioner of AI. It has created a Governance Framework around AI to achieve this objective and to be compliant to internal and external regulatory requirements.

 

The current AI Governance Framework included the following shortcomings:

 

Missing procedures for High-Risk AI Systems:The guideline on IT Compliance, Artificial Intelligence and Segregation of Duties required the creation of ‘additional procedures’ for High-Risk AI use cases. These ‘additional procedures’ had not been designed or documented so far. The AI Use Case Inventory in JIRA did not present any use case classified as “High-Risk” according to risk assessment performed. Furthermore, our test noted that classifying a use case as “High-Risk” triggered a notification to the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and put the use case in an “Approval block”, although not rejecting it.

The ICT Risk Framework was not adapted to include AI-related risks. Risks arising from the use of AI were not analysed, identified and captured in the framework. Respective ICT guidelines and ICT procedures were not established to estimate and mitigate the ICT AI risks. As a result, these risks were not considered within risk assessments of the systems with AI Usage.

 

The Material Change Committee for DBAG (MCC) and Material Change Working Group (MCWG) for CBL, CBF, CFCL (hereinafter referred to as the Material Change Committees) have been tasked with ensuring adequate governance regarding material changes including proposed AI use cases. As part of the decision-making in the Material Change Process, the AI CoE has acted as the 1LOD Control Function providing advice to the Material Change Committees regarding risks and efficacy of the proposed control measures with respect to AI use cases. Although a documented AI Governance Framework and defined roles were in place, no criteria were documented beyond the AI Use Case Inventory questionnaire to guide the AI CoE’s assessment of proposed AI use cases, to allow suitable challenge by the Material Change Commitees, and consequently to ensure adherence to the necessary guardrails and principles of the EU AI Act in line with DBG’s risk appetite. The Material Change Guideline for DBG did not describe the role of the AI COE control function in the MCP process for AI related changes.

 

 

According to EU AI Act and DBG written rules, require organization to develop and implement robust AI governance structure and AI Literacy. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that AI Center of Excellence (ACE) to design and implement written rules for “High-Risk” use cases.  04.06.2025 15.06.2026 15.06.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Melinda Bajai, Benjamin Möller Anvay Walavalkar Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski AI Center of Excellence (U) AI Center of Excellence (ACE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of clearly defined AI Governance Framework can lead to operational failures, loss of trust, privacy and ethical issues, and non-compliance with the regulatory requirements. Absence of documented criteria and guidance for the AI CoE and MCC may impede their decision-making process in terms of compliance and consistency.  Melinda Bajai CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),REITZ PETER(European Energy Exchange),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework
2025-025_F01 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in the AI Governance Framework Deutsche Börse Group (DBG) has named Artificial intelligence (AI) as a key driver of digital leadership as part of its Horizon 2026 strategy. DBG aims to transition from the status of Observer to Practitioner of AI. It has created a Governance Framework around AI to achieve this objective and to be compliant to internal and external regulatory requirements.

 

The current AI Governance Framework included the following shortcomings:

 

Missing procedures for High-Risk AI Systems:The guideline on IT Compliance, Artificial Intelligence and Segregation of Duties required the creation of ‘additional procedures’ for High-Risk AI use cases. These ‘additional procedures’ had not been designed or documented so far. The AI Use Case Inventory in JIRA did not present any use case classified as “High-Risk” according to risk assessment performed. Furthermore, our test noted that classifying a use case as “High-Risk” triggered a notification to the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and put the use case in an “Approval block”, although not rejecting it.

The ICT Risk Framework was not adapted to include AI-related risks. Risks arising from the use of AI were not analysed, identified and captured in the framework. Respective ICT guidelines and ICT procedures were not established to estimate and mitigate the ICT AI risks. As a result, these risks were not considered within risk assessments of the systems with AI Usage.

 

The Material Change Committee for DBAG (MCC) and Material Change Working Group (MCWG) for CBL, CBF, CFCL (hereinafter referred to as the Material Change Committees) have been tasked with ensuring adequate governance regarding material changes including proposed AI use cases. As part of the decision-making in the Material Change Process, the AI CoE has acted as the 1LOD Control Function providing advice to the Material Change Committees regarding risks and efficacy of the proposed control measures with respect to AI use cases. Although a documented AI Governance Framework and defined roles were in place, no criteria were documented beyond the AI Use Case Inventory questionnaire to guide the AI CoE’s assessment of proposed AI use cases, to allow suitable challenge by the Material Change Commitees, and consequently to ensure adherence to the necessary guardrails and principles of the EU AI Act in line with DBG’s risk appetite. The Material Change Guideline for DBG did not describe the role of the AI COE control function in the MCP process for AI related changes.

 

 

According to EU AI Act and DBG written rules, require organization to develop and implement robust AI governance structure and AI Literacy. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that ICT Risk Framework (KJU) creates and implements the ICT Risk AI guideline based on identified risks related to AI and trigger the following processes in cooperation with respect to departments  04.06.2025 15.03.2026 15.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sarah Ahmad Jahn Olga Braitsev Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of clearly defined AI Governance Framework can lead to operational failures, loss of trust, privacy and ethical issues, and non-compliance with the regulatory requirements. Absence of documented criteria and guidance for the AI CoE and MCC may impede their decision-making process in terms of compliance and consistency.  Sarah Ahmad Jahn CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),REITZ PETER(European Energy Exchange),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework
2025-025_F01 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in the AI Governance Framework Deutsche Börse Group (DBG) has named Artificial intelligence (AI) as a key driver of digital leadership as part of its Horizon 2026 strategy. DBG aims to transition from the status of Observer to Practitioner of AI. It has created a Governance Framework around AI to achieve this objective and to be compliant to internal and external regulatory requirements.

 

The current AI Governance Framework included the following shortcomings:

 

Missing procedures for High-Risk AI Systems:The guideline on IT Compliance, Artificial Intelligence and Segregation of Duties required the creation of ‘additional procedures’ for High-Risk AI use cases. These ‘additional procedures’ had not been designed or documented so far. The AI Use Case Inventory in JIRA did not present any use case classified as “High-Risk” according to risk assessment performed. Furthermore, our test noted that classifying a use case as “High-Risk” triggered a notification to the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and put the use case in an “Approval block”, although not rejecting it.

The ICT Risk Framework was not adapted to include AI-related risks. Risks arising from the use of AI were not analysed, identified and captured in the framework. Respective ICT guidelines and ICT procedures were not established to estimate and mitigate the ICT AI risks. As a result, these risks were not considered within risk assessments of the systems with AI Usage.

 

The Material Change Committee for DBAG (MCC) and Material Change Working Group (MCWG) for CBL, CBF, CFCL (hereinafter referred to as the Material Change Committees) have been tasked with ensuring adequate governance regarding material changes including proposed AI use cases. As part of the decision-making in the Material Change Process, the AI CoE has acted as the 1LOD Control Function providing advice to the Material Change Committees regarding risks and efficacy of the proposed control measures with respect to AI use cases. Although a documented AI Governance Framework and defined roles were in place, no criteria were documented beyond the AI Use Case Inventory questionnaire to guide the AI CoE’s assessment of proposed AI use cases, to allow suitable challenge by the Material Change Commitees, and consequently to ensure adherence to the necessary guardrails and principles of the EU AI Act in line with DBG’s risk appetite. The Material Change Guideline for DBG did not describe the role of the AI COE control function in the MCP process for AI related changes.

 

 

According to EU AI Act and DBG written rules, require organization to develop and implement robust AI governance structure and AI Literacy. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Group Compliance (SCG) 

 

Define clear criteria and / or provide additional trainings as applicable, which act as the basis for the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and Material Change Committee (MCC) / Material Change Working Group (MCWG), to provide them with the notions to challenge the assessments on the AI use cases, thereby ensuring the necessary guardrails are consistently applied during AI use case implementation.

Amend the Material Change Guideline to define Key tasks and responsibilities of AI Centre of Excellence as a control function in the MCP Process 		 04.06.2025 14.11.2025 14.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Marco Popp Shravankumar Mohankumar Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Group Compliance Strategy (S) Group Compliance (SCG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of clearly defined AI Governance Framework can lead to operational failures, loss of trust, privacy and ethical issues, and non-compliance with the regulatory requirements. Absence of documented criteria and guidance for the AI CoE and MCC may impede their decision-making process in terms of compliance and consistency.  Marco Popp CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),REITZ PETER(European Energy Exchange),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework
2025-025_F02 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate Inventory and Classification of AI use cases Internal Audit recommends AI Center of Excellence (ACE) to review and update the AI System Management Process and the AI Use Case Inventory to ensure alignment between the documented process, the system’s attributes, and relevant internal and external requirements. This should include but not be limited to:

Re-assessing all AI use cases previously evaluated based on the shortened list of questions.

Defining and implementing a control to verify the accuracy of each use case’s classification. 

Defining all implemented attributes within the AI Use Case Inventory to eliminate ambiguity and ensure consistent data capture by use case submitters.

Implementing and enforcing all mandatory attributes within the system as necessary during the process, e.g. when the Use Case is submitted to the MCC and/or once the use case is adopted “In Production” or put in place effective controls to prevent incomplete data.

Establishing clear governance and maintenance procedures for the AI Use Case Inventory, including regular reviews and updates by process owners and system maintainers, to ensure ongoing alignment of the inventory with evolving requirements and to address any future discrepancies. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends AI Center of Excellence (ACE) to review and update the AI System Management Process and the AI Use Case Inventory to ensure alignment between the documented process, the system’s attributes, and relevant internal and external requirements. This should include but not be limited to:

Re-assessing all AI use cases previously evaluated based on the shortened list of questions.

Defining and implementing a control to verify the accuracy of each use case’s classification. 

Defining all implemented attributes within the AI Use Case Inventory to eliminate ambiguity and ensure consistent data capture by use case submitters.

Implementing and enforcing all mandatory attributes within the system as necessary during the process, e.g. when the Use Case is submitted to the MCC and/or once the use case is adopted “In Production” or put in place effective controls to prevent incomplete data.

Establishing clear governance and maintenance procedures for the AI Use Case Inventory, including regular reviews and updates by process owners and system maintainers, to ensure ongoing alignment of the inventory with evolving requirements and to address any future discrepancies. 		 04.06.2025 15.03.2026 15.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Melinda Bajai, Benjamin Möller Fabrice Emanuel Campas Moreira Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski AI Center of Excellence (U) AI Center of Excellence (ACE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation  The JIRA-based AI Use Case Inventory tool serves as a repository for AI use cases and provides the functionality to classify them. The classification relies on a questionnaire (Red Flag Check) designed to evaluate the risk level of each use case according to the EU AI Act. 

 

The audit revealed the existence of two different questionnaires within the JIRA tool: an older, shorter version with only two use case categories (prohibited and high-risk) and a newer, longer version with four categories (prohibited, high-risk, General Purpose AI [GPAI] and GPAI with system risk). In addition to the different set of categories, the high-risk use case characteristics were expanded with further questions. 

 

Many use cases (up to AIUC-54), some of which are already in production, were classified using the shorter questionnaire. However, the shorter version did not cover all relevant categories (e.g. GPAI) or the characteristics of specific use case categories defined in the EU AI Act. Despite the changes in the classification questionnaire, existing use cases were not reassessed. Furthermore, controls were missing to verify the accuracy of the use case classification. 

 

The AI Use Case Inventory tool utilised in the AI Use Case Initiation[3], a sub-process of the AI System Management Process[4], contained attributes that were not defined within the user documentation linked in the process documentation (specifically in the AI Use Case Inventory attributes appendix). The user documentation was outdated and marked mandatory attributes that were not enforced by the system or by defined controls. This can be exemplified by the sub-process Check AI UC information for completion, which relied on accurate and complete information for its assessment.

 

According to the EU AI Act text note 26 as of June 13, 2024, organisations shall establish, implement, and maintain a risk management system adequately. To introduce a proportionate and effective set of binding rules for AI systems, a clearly defined risk-based approach should be followed.  		 Melinda Bajai CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Other framework
2025-025_F03 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F03-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Incompleteness in the AI system management process Internal Audit recommends that the AI Center of Excellence (ACE) update the AI System Management Process. The following steps should be implemented regarding the AI-related inventories:

The AI Initiation Process requires approved and implemented AI Use Cases to be part of APMS.

If necessary, implement the AI System Change form.

Update status of AI Use Cases in order to measure KPIs, as described in the AI System Management Process.

Include the AI use case change process into AI System Change Process. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that the AI Center of Excellence (ACE) update the AI System Management Process. The following steps should be implemented regarding the AI-related inventories:

The AI Initiation Process requires approved and implemented AI Use Cases to be part of APMS.

If necessary, implement the AI System Change form.

Update status of AI Use Cases in order to measure KPIs, as described in the AI System Management Process.

Include the AI use case change process into AI System Change Process. 		 04.06.2025 14.11.2025 14.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Melinda Bajai, Benjamin Möller Olga Braitsev Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski AI Center of Excellence (U) AI Center of Excellence (ACE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incompleteness in the AI system management process, and in particular the lack of clear rules for system flagging as AI Usage can lead to misunderstanding and as a result, to incorrect handling of components using AI and inadvertent omission of crucial process steps. It could further lead to an under- or overestimation of the overall risks for DBG.  Melinda Bajai CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework

Include the AI use case change process into AI System Change Process. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that IT Core Process Design and Operations (ÜPÜ) update the Application Portfolio Management System User Manual based on the following points:

The application owner/business owner should initiate the AI use case lifecycle process upon identifying AI embedded in the application. 

The logical or technical connection between JIRA and APMS must be described and published to users. 		 04.06.2025 14.11.2025 14.11.2025 27.10.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sean Mc Taggart Olga Braitsev Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Core Process Governance (U) IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. It could further lead to an under- or overestimation of the overall risks for DBG.  Sean Mc Taggart CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Other framework
2025-030_F01 2025 2025-030 Risk Model Development (ECAG) 2025-030_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S1 Insufficiently documented controls Internal Audit observed that a control activity within the Risk Model Development process was not formally documented. Prior to the launch of a model change, internal approval of setup notes was obtained. However, this control activity was not defined within the Model Change Framework and related process documents. Currently setup notes were only referenced as part of implementation documentation within Model Change & Product Introduction Process.

Furthermore, control description within the Risk Control Matrix (RCM) for the subprocess SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development reflects only the key first line and second line controls. The actual control extends beyond what is currently documented, including approvals that must be obtained from internal and regulatory bodies.

MaRisk AT 4.3.1 requires that processes as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels shall be clearly defined and coordinated. Additionally, MaRisk AT 6 stipulates that documentation related to business, control and monitoring shall be kept up to date and complete.		 Control Design Effectiveness Recommendation 1: Internal Audit recommends the control activities to be performed in accordance with the Model Change Framework and/or related process documentation to ensure consistent and effective application of the controls. If additional approvals are required on an ongoing basis, they should be documented accordingly.

Recommendation 2: Internal Audit recommends that the control description for subprocess SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development in the RCM be updated to reference the Model Change Framework in its entirety.		 25.06.2025 31.12.2025 31.12.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Adam Olszewski Emirhan Uysal Markus Messerer THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Models & Analytics (S) Management Response 1: Management agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.

Management Response 2: Management agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.		 Misalignment between process related documentation and actual control
activities may result in inconsistent application or oversight of the control.
Inadequate description of control in the RCM may lead to gaps in control
monitoring and assurance. These could expose the company to limited
regulatory impact.		 Adam Olszewski DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-030_F02 2025 2025-030 Risk Model Development (ECAG) 2025-030_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in General Controls Internal Audit (IA) noted following weaknesses in the general controls:
 
1. Inconsistent references in documentation
IA identified inconsistencies and outdated references across several documents.

1.1 Model Development Framework v4.0
• Footnote 2 refers to the 2023 version of the CCP Model Risk Management Policy.
• Both the CCP Model Development Framework v4.0 and CCP Model Change Framework v1.4 still refer to MaRisk 09/2017.

1.2 Model Development Guidelines – Margin Models v2.0
• On page 7, an error message appears under Chapter 2.2 Data quality: “Fehler! Verweisquelle konnte nicht gefunden werden”.

1.3 Model Change & Product Introduction Process v1.1
• References for sections 2, 3 and 4 on page 4/15 are inaccurate.
• References to sections 3.2.1, 3.2.2, and 3.3 on page 9/15 are inaccurate.
• References to sections 3.3 on page 10/15 and section 3.1 on page 11/15 are inaccurate.
• Following discrepancies are identified in Section 2.3.1:
(i) New Product Committee is not referenced as an approver, although it is included in the Model Change Framework as a required approver,
(ii) Process document states that a non-objection from BaFin will be sought, whereas the Model Change Framework requires formal approval from BaFin.

According to Section 25 (a) of the German Banking Act (KWG), business activities should be conducted based on organizational guidelines.

Additionally, according to MaRisk AT 5 and AT 6, the institution shall ensure that business activities are conducted on the basis of organizational guidelines (e.g., manuals, work instructions or workflow descriptions). The guidelines shall be swiftly amended in the event of changes to the activities and processes. Business, control and monitoring documentation shall be systematic and written in a manner that is readily comprehensible for expert third parties.


2. Legal Inventory
IA identified deficiencies in the Legal Inventory maintained within the Regulatory Monitoring Dashboard:

• The subprocess SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development is not linked to Articles 40 (Valuing Collateral) and 41 (Haircuts) of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 153/2013, although these articles are relevant to the Risk Model Development Process,
• An obsolete subprocess, SP_ECAG_CO_12.1_product introduction in risk framework, which was merged into SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development in October 2022, is still linked to Legal Inventory entries LIE-1418, LIE-1415, LIE-1414, LIE-1413.

According to AT 4.4.2 MaRisk No 1 “each institution shall have a compliance function in place in order to counteract the risks that may arise from non-compliance with legal rules and regulations. The compliance function shall ensure the implementation of effective procedures for complying with the legal rules and regulations that are material to the institution, and of corresponding controls.” No 2 states that “The compliance function shall regularly identify the material legal rules and regulations, non-compliance with which might jeopardize the institution's assets, in the light of risk factors.” 

The DBG Group Compliance MaRisk Compliance Monitoring Handbook Chapter 2 explains that notwithstanding the duties of the Compliance function, the management board members and the business areas remain fully responsible for complying with laws and regulations.

According to Chapter 6.3 of DBG Group Guideline on enabling compliance with material laws and regulations, the business areas are;

• Required to conduct the analysis on new and/ or amended laws and regulations as communicated and requested by Group Compliance and provide feedback regarding the applicability, risk of non-compliance and implementation by mapping of processes or other forms of documented measures,
• Responsible to ensure that all laws and regulations applicable to their service provision are mapped in a sufficient and granular way in the Legal Inventory. Subsequently, the business Area should proactively add missing laws and regulations to the Legal Inventory when becoming aware of any laws and regulations not mapped in the Legal Inventory. 		 Control Operating Effectiveness Recommendation 1: Internal Audit recommends that all Risk Model Development related documentation, including but not limited to the documents highlighted above in the finding, be reviewed and updated to ensure consistency, accuracy, and alignment with current internal frameworks and external regulatory requirements.

Recommendation 2: Internal Audit recommends reviewing and updating the Legal Inventory to ensure accurate mapping of all relevant legal and regulatory requirements to the applicable subprocesses.		 25.06.2025 31.12.2025 31.12.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Adam Olszewski Emirhan Uysal Markus Messerer THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Models & Analytics (S) Management Response 1: Management agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.

Management Response 2: The management agrees with the recommendation and is already acting upon it. The respective entries in Legal Inventory are being updated.		 1. Inconsistent references in documentation
Inconsistent and outdated references across key documentation may lead to
misinterpretation of governance requirements, incorrect application of
regulatory standards, and confusion among stakeholders. This increases the
risk of non-compliance with internal policies and external regulations,
weakens the reliability of model governance processes, and may result in
delays or errors in model development, validation, or approval. This represents
a minor violation of internal and external provisions and could expose the
company to limited regulatory impact.
2. Legal Inventory
Incomplete mapping of regulatory requirements in the Legal Inventory may
result in gaps in compliance oversight. This increases the risk that relevant legal
obligations are not adequately considered in the Risk Model Development
Process. This represents a minor gap in internal and external provisions and a limited breach of regulatory requirements, which could lead to limited
regulatory impact. 		 Adam Olszewski DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-031_F02 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditor S2 Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) is designed to serve as a central inventory of all relevant applications used across DBG and its subsidiaries.

Internal Audit noted that the inventory was incomplete:
§ CUBE Reg-Track is an external web interface owned by Reg-Room LLC and used across DBG entities through associated software licenses to identify and monitor applicable regulations as part of the Legal Inventory process. It was not captured in APMS as a standalone application. Consequently, the ownership, governance for oversight purposes, criticality assessment and information classification were not defined.
§ RegMon (AID886) did not contain in the Legal Entity pane the “Using” legal entity Clearstream Banking S.A. (CBL), despite the use of the application by CBL. Additionally, LuxCSD S.A., and Clearstream International S.A. (CI) were using RegMon through CBL. At the time of the audit, only German-based entities were listed.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Group Compliance Oversight (COG), in consultation with IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) and ICT Risk Framework (KJU):
§ ensure that all external web interfaces   used within the scope of DBAG Compliance Legal Inventory-related processes, including CUBE Reg-Track, are captured in APMS
§ in its role of Business Owner, support the review and update of the legal entity pane in APMS to accurately reflect all entities actively using RegMon (AID886)		 25.06.2025 17.11.2025 17.11.2025 06.10.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Miriam Schmitz Johan Luc Palix Randi Montgomery HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Group Compliance Oversight (S) Group Compliance Oversight (COG) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) may expose the company to inaccurate IT asset tracking, reduced visibility over regulatory-relevant tools, and weakened governance over application ownership and accountability. This could lead to minor financial losses and material reputational, regulatory and internal provisions, resulting from compliance gaps, operational inefficiencies, and auditability issues. Miriam Schmitz ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines
2025-031_F02 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditee S2 Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) is designed to serve as a central inventory of all relevant applications used across DBG and its subsidiaries.

Internal Audit noted that the inventory was incomplete:
§ CUBE Reg-Track is an external web interface owned by Reg-Room LLC and used across DBG entities through associated software licenses to identify and monitor applicable regulations as part of the Legal Inventory process. It was not captured in APMS as a standalone application. Consequently, the ownership, governance for oversight purposes, criticality assessment and information classification were not defined.
§ RegMon (AID886) did not contain in the Legal Entity pane the “Using” legal entity Clearstream Banking S.A. (CBL), despite the use of the application by CBL. Additionally, LuxCSD S.A., and Clearstream International S.A. (CI) were using RegMon through CBL. At the time of the audit, only German-based entities were listed.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets.
