Laura Mendez Rodriguez ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines
2025-031_F05 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in controls related to the creation of the annual reporting to the CFTC Since December 2018, Eurex Clearing AG (ECAG) has been permitted to clear futures commission merchant customer positions as well as continue clearing proprietary positions for US Clearing Members. For this purpose, annually, the US Chief Compliance Officer (US CCO) is required to prepare and sign a written report that covers the most recently completed fiscal year of ECAG. This ECAG Year End Derivatives Clearing Organization (DCO) Annual Report (Annual Report) is designed to ensure compliance with Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) Regulation 39.10(c)(3) and filed with the CFTC.

Among the duties of the US CCO is reviewing the DCO’s compliance with the Core Principles set forth in section 5b of the Dodd-Frank Act, and the CFTC’s regulations thereunder. Further, it is CCP Compliance’s responsibility to detect any risk of failure by ECAG and its employees to comply with applicable laws and regulations.

The filed Annual Report 2024 contained reference to relevant policy/procedure documents designed to ensure compliance with each DCO Core Principle and corresponding CFTC regulation. For each policy or procedure, there was a brief description, mention of the responsible person(s) and the latest version.

For facilitating work around the Annual Report and for internal tracking purposes, the US CCO had created a SharePoint folder for collecting copies of the latest relevant policy/procedure documents as mentioned in the Annual Report 2024. Moreover, there was an internal checklist listing in each tab one DCO Core Principle and the following entry fields:
§ the related policy/procedure documents designed to ensure compliance
§ responsible person(s) for these documents
§ a certification requirement (either ensuring compliance or stating areas for improvement)

Prior  to finalizing the Annual Report 2024, the US CCO sent an email to a distribution list requiring the upload of most recent version of policies/procedures and that the responsible person for a policy/procedure in the provided excel sheet write that the policy/procedure was effective in ensuring compliance with that Core Principle and, if applicable, accompanying CFTC rule, or if not, why not. The internal certification requirement was repeated in the checklist, which stated: Please certify and initial or state areas for improvement.

Based on sampling, Internal Audit noted several entries in the checklist that did not explicitly fulfil the above-mentioned certification requirement. Instead, there were the following entries:
§ some contained only the name of a document
§ some contained the information that a document was valid
§ some made reference to specific pages and contents of The IT Strategy 2024 relating to CFTC Rules
§ some lines stated annual review finalized - no areas for improvement identified for continued compliance (only editorial changes)

In addition, the following inaccuracies were identified related to the filed Annual Report 2024:
§ There was a mention of Eurex Clearing AG Policy and Procedure for Reporting to the CFTC in the Annual Report 2024, although this document was obsolete.
§ The filed Annual Report 2024 referred to v1.8 of the Eurex Clearing DCO Compliance Manual. The cover page of this Manual, as provided to IA, stated v2.0, whereas the further pages stated v1.5.
§ The person responsible for DBG IT Service Continuity Management Guideline was not the same in the Annual Report 2024 as in the checklist.
§ The physical security policy was removed from the Annual Report 2024, however, it was provided and also contained in the checklist.

Moreover, SAP Governance, Risk and Compliance Internal Control System (GRC ICS) contained no risk entry related to policies/procedures not being compliant with CFTC requirements. This was despite the existence of a key control related to the certifications, as described above. Further, there was a mismatch in GRC ICS mainly between risk, control and evidence.

German regulation and DBG policy require that financial institutions implement an effective Internal Control System and the Supervisory Board to monitor the effectiveness of the ICS.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that CCP Compliance (CPC):
§ ensure strict adherence to the internally requested certification requirement, including a procedure for the handling of exceptions
§ introduce a 4EP control on the accuracy of the contents of the annual report, in particular section 2.1 DCO Core Principle compliance chart
§ in GRC ICS, include entries for the existing key control related to internal certifications and make corrections to the documented risk, control and evidence to remove the mismatch		 25.06.2025 23.03.2026 23.03.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Bianca Sahrholz Randi Montgomery Randi Montgomery THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Compliance (U) CCP Compliance (CPC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in controls related to the creation of the annual reporting to the CFTC may undermine DCO’s compliance with rules and regulations. The partial absence of the internally requested explicit certification that existing policy/procedure documents are effective in ensuring compliance with certain rules and regulations may indicate instances of non-compliance. The weaknesses represent a material gap in internal provisions and may have a material adverse regulatory impact. Key controls not contained in GRC ICS may not be designed and/or performed adequately. Bianca Sahrholz MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-031_F06 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses related to internal outsourcing relationships Internal Audit identified that:
§ no signed version of the ECAG (supplier) – DBAG (customer) SDS for Compliance Services effective 1 January 2024 was available
§ the Compliance section of the ECAG process map contained the following weakness: The outsourcing and insourcer fields were not reflecting the related outsourcing relationships, which existed between on the one hand ECAG and on the other hand DBAG, EFAG and DBS Inc., respectively

European and German regulation require robust governance arrangements including clear organizational structures with well-defined lines of responsibility. In case of outsourcings, the outsourcer remains fully responsible for any outsourced activities. Internal requirements state that each third-party service needs to be based on a written contract that specifies the services and details specific arrangements such as rules and modalities for sub-contracting.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that CCP Compliance (CPC):
§ finalize an SDS between ECAG (supplier) – DBAG (customer) SDS for Compliance Services, and make required arrangements that consider that the related services became effective as of 1 January 2024
§ make amendments to the ECAG process map to properly reflect the existing outsourcing arrangements

The last bullet of the recommendation has been adequately addressed before the issuance of the audit report.		 25.06.2025 10.12.2025 10.12.2025 0 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Bianca Sahrholz Randi Montgomery Randi Montgomery THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Compliance (U) CCP Compliance (CPC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses related to internal outsourcing relationships represent a minor breach of regulatory requirements and non-compliance with internal policies. This may lead to deviations in service quality and/or erroneous intercompany billing with minor financial impact. Bianca Sahrholz HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission
2025-032_F01 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F01-A01 Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditee S2 Inconsistences in Risk Management governance documents after reorganization Prior to the reorganization of the Risk Management Department, the Risk Analytics unit was responsible for subprocesses related to Credit Risk, Concentration Risk, and Wrong-Way Risk monitoring. Following the departmental restructuring effective 1 January 2025, these responsibilities were redistributed between the Reporting & Quality Data Management (RDQ) team and the Credit Risk Management & Governance (DMD) unit.
However, Internal Audit (IA) noted that the updated roles and responsibilities resulting from this reorganization have not been reflected in key governance documents, including:
§ Exposure, Entity, Aggregation & Classification Concept
§ Credit Risk Concept
§ Additionally Monitored Risk Framework
Despite the absence of updated documentation, IA did not identify any deficiencies in the execution or performance of the relevant subprocesses during the review period.
 
As per internal and external requirements, the roles and responsibilities of the organization should be clearly established.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Internal Audit (IA) recommends Credit Risk Management & Governance (DMD) unit to initiate a formal review and update of all affected governance documents—specifically the Exposure, Entity, Aggregation & Classification Concept, Credit Risk Concept, and Additionally Monitored Risk Framework. These updates must incorporate the revised roles and responsibilities resulting from the departmental reorganization that took effect on 1 January 2025, ensuring that the documentation accurately reflects the current operational structure.  31.07.2025 07.11.2025 07.11.2025 29.10.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Vincent Prepin Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Credit Risk Management & Governance (U) Credit Risk Management & Governance (DMD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement/implemented the recommendation.  Inconsistencies in Risk Management governance documents after reorganization can lead to operational errors, ineffective risk oversight, miscommunication, and non-compliance with internal policies or regulatory expectations.  Vincent Prepin DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities
2025-032_F02 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate process controls for credit rating triggers Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the additional risk monitoring process and identified 13 credit rating-related triggers that occur on an ad hoc basis. The 13 identified triggers span across onboarding, rating changes, counterpart terminations, mergers, and data quality updates. Each trigger initiates a specific task by Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) to ensure that internal credit ratings are accurate, current, and properly reflected in the CESAR system. These triggers are critical for ensuring timely and accurate updates to reference data, which directly impact risk assessments. The review highlighted the following gaps in the current process design and control environment:
§ Lack of centralized oversight: There is no centralized mechanism to monitor the status or progress of actions taken, resulting in limited transparency and control over process execution. Additionally, responsibilities are assigned only at the unit level, with no individual accountability for specific triggers.
§ Absence of Structured Documentation: Actions taken in response to triggers are not consistently recorded. Without a formal documentation framework, audit trail integrity is compromised, and the ability to trace or reconstruct activities—especially in cases of staff turnover or downstream errors—is hindered.		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit (IA) recommends Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) to implement a centralized oversight mechanism to monitor and track the status and completion of credit rating-related triggers, ensuring timely and consistent execution. Additionally, a structured documentation process should be established to record all actions taken in response to these triggers, supporting traceability and auditability.  31.07.2025 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Peter Linß Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Reporting & Data Quality Management (U) Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement/implemented the recommendation.  Inadequate process controls for credit rating triggers—due to lack of centralized oversight and structured documentation—may lead to delayed or inaccurate risk data updates. This increases the risk of regulatory non-compliance, financial misstatements, and material reputational damage, particularly if incorrect data informs key risk decisions or is reported externally  Peter Linß DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-032_F03 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Lack of business description of the quarterly credit benchmarking process The quarterly credit benchmarking process was conducted in collaboration with the Credit Risk Monitoring Unit – CBL until Q1 2025. Following this period, the process was decommissioned and transitioned to be performed directly by the Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) team, utilizing input from external data sources. However, Internal Audit (IA) observed that no formal business procedure has been established to define the new methodology for executing this process. 

As described in the MAN60 Member Monitoring Manual (Section 3.5), the purpose of the quarterly credit benchmarking is to compare Eurex Clearing’s internal credit ratings with external benchmark ratings. Discrepancies greater than two notches must be reviewed by Credit Analysts to assess whether internal ratings require adjustment. For example, if a counterparty is rated A- internally but external benchmark data indicates a BBB- rating, this three-notch difference would trigger a review to determine whether the internal rating remains appropriate or needs to be revised based on updated financials or market signals.
This process is essential for maintaining the quality, consistency, and credibility of internal credit assessments and supports the integrity of the credit risk framework.		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit (IA) recommends Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) to formally document a business procedure for the revised quarterly credit benchmarking process. This should include a clear description of the methodology, data sources, execution steps, control points, and responsible functions.  31.07.2025 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Peter Linß Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Reporting & Data Quality Management (U) Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement/ the recommendation.  Lack of business description of the quarterly credit benchmarking process leads to operational errors and minor violation of internal provisions that may lead to negligible regulatory and/or financial impacts.   Peter Linß DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission
2025-032_F04 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inconsistency between OpRisk scenario and ICS process map Internal Audit (IA) observed that the process P_ECAG_8.3_STP shortfall/surpl calc is not currently documented in the GRC ICS process map. However, this process continues to be referenced in the operational risk scenario 50000284_EFAG_002 – Clearing Risk Sys. O., where it remains relevant due to its associated risk exposure.

The absence of this process from the ICS process map results in a misalignment between the internal control system and the operational risk framework. This may lead to incomplete control documentation and reduced transparency regarding the control environment for risk-relevant processes.		 Control Environment Internal Audit (IA) recommends Equity Risk (DDB) to update the ICS process map to include STP shortfall/surplus calculation process. 31.07.2025 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Ivan Kulis Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Equity Risk (U) Equity Risk (DDB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Inconsistency between the OpRisk scenario and the ICS process map represents a minor violation of internal provisions. It may lead to incomplete documentation of risk-relevant processes and reduced transparency within the control environment, with negligible regulatory or financial impact. Ivan Kulis DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission
2025-033_F01 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance Various financial industry regulations demand a consistent and coherent approach that spans the entire lifecycle of third-party relationships, from initial risk assessment and onboarding through contract management, operational oversight, incident handling, and exit strategies. An effective third-party risk management requires clear traceability of responsibilities, harmonized documentation and IT applications as well as integrated risk controls across all relevant functions and DBG legal entities.

The DBG outsourcing framework has recently been updated to include ICT third-party risk management. This extended the already complex outsourcing and third-party management processes, which were already fragmented, siloed and lacked alignment and harmonization. DBG’s third-party management activities were spread across many legal entities, departments as well as multitudinous Contract- and Business Owners. Impact could be exemplified by inconsistently applied third-party management, not aligned roles and responsibilities, inconsistent and decentralized due diligence, risk assessment and monitoring across the 1st LoD, e.g. ownership for third-party management or contract management, ineffective third-party oversight or missing data governance. Illustrative risk drivers include:
a) Multiple teams within DBG (Purchasing, Business Owners, Ecosystem Partner Risk Management, IT Strategic Provider Management) conducted due diligence, risk assessment, and monitoring activities using different tools and methodologies. This led to redundancy, inefficiency and inconsistent results. Central oversight and consolidation of inputs from different internal stakeholders were not established.
b) Lack of robust data governance for contract and third-party data resulted in inconsistent, incomplete or inaccurate entries across multiple tools and repositories for contract and third-party data. Third parties were not timely, unambiguous and reliably identifiable. Comprehensive controls to ensure the completeness and accuracy of the contract inventory and other third-party data did not exist.
c) DBG legal entities did not establish roles and processes to provide coordinated management of and communication with third parties. The relationship management was set up contract based, resulting in hundreds of contract Business Owners across the organization performing duplicated tasks and actions, leading to unstructured and fragmented third-party documentation. Consequently, the missing coordination resulted in third parties like SAP and Microsoft complaining about repeated and uncoordinated information requests in 2025.
d) A detailed vendor management review of a sample of six major ICT third parties (Google, Tata, Bottomline, Equinix, NTT and Appway) revealed that DBG had not implemented a fully aligned third-party governance, risk or control framework according to the obligations laid down in contracts, including the DORA contractual annex. As DBG works with several hundred ICT third parties plus more than ten third parties supporting CIF, DBG’s internal deadline for implementation and operationalization by December 2025 might be unfeasible in this regard.
e) Although deficiencies in the operationalization of the third-party risk management frameworks were self-identified (see SII-1 below), specific support has not been received by Contract/ Business Owners. Assurance was missing that DORA third-party risk management and vendor management specific expertise were available at the Business Owners.

A full list of supporting examples from 2025-033 and 2025-026 audits’ fieldwork is included in Appendix B.

A comprehensive, end-to-end governance approach for Third-parties management is a regulatory imperative. Fragmented, unaligned and siloed processes, particularly at the 1st LoD, impact 2LoD oversight and are explicitly discouraged, as they undermine the resilience, transparency, consistency and accountability that, particularly, DORA seeks to enforce across the financial sector.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. § Define and implement the Target Operating Model (TOM) for 1LoD and 2LoD third- party management that covers current overlaps, critical gaps and dependencies
§ Define and implement the Target Operating Model (TOM) for 1LoD and 2LoD governance of third- party and contract data, considering current tools and processes.
§ Set up a plan to ensure operationalization in DBG.
§ Set up a plan for third-party and contract data clean up.		 01.10.2025 30.09.2026 30.09.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jens Schulte Desiree Ramirez Desiree Ramirez JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (Div) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (FFO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Particularly significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance expose the company to critical regulatory, reputational, and operational risks. Failure to fulfill regulatory requirements constitute severe regulatory non-compliance and can lead to ad-hoc regulatory examinations, financial penalties, administrative orders, remedial measures, and operational restrictions. Penalties are determined by national supervisory authorities, with fines potentially reaching up to 2% of a company's global annual turnover. In addition, lack of accountability and poor contractual and third-party data governance may lead to underestimation of risks and financial losses. Uncoordinated relationship management and communication with third parties may result in reputational damage.
A limited oversight on third-party operational resilience, robustness, and compliance with internal and external requirements, may lead to security deficiencies and operational risks remaining undetected until they materialize.		 Jens Schulte ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),PHILIPPE SEYLL(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy CSDR Art.25,CSSF 20/750,CSSF 25/881,DORA,MaRisk AT 4
2025-033_F01 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance Various financial industry regulations demand a consistent and coherent approach that spans the entire lifecycle of third-party relationships, from initial risk assessment and onboarding through contract management, operational oversight, incident handling, and exit strategies. An effective third-party risk management requires clear traceability of responsibilities, harmonized documentation and IT applications as well as integrated risk controls across all relevant functions and DBG legal entities.

The DBG outsourcing framework has recently been updated to include ICT third-party risk management. This extended the already complex outsourcing and third-party management processes, which were already fragmented, siloed and lacked alignment and harmonization. DBG’s third-party management activities were spread across many legal entities, departments as well as multitudinous Contract- and Business Owners. Impact could be exemplified by inconsistently applied third-party management, not aligned roles and responsibilities, inconsistent and decentralized due diligence, risk assessment and monitoring across the 1st LoD, e.g. ownership for third-party management or contract management, ineffective third-party oversight or missing data governance. Illustrative risk drivers include:
a) Multiple teams within DBG (Purchasing, Business Owners, Ecosystem Partner Risk Management, IT Strategic Provider Management) conducted due diligence, risk assessment, and monitoring activities using different tools and methodologies. This led to redundancy, inefficiency and inconsistent results. Central oversight and consolidation of inputs from different internal stakeholders were not established.
b) Lack of robust data governance for contract and third-party data resulted in inconsistent, incomplete or inaccurate entries across multiple tools and repositories for contract and third-party data. Third parties were not timely, unambiguous and reliably identifiable. Comprehensive controls to ensure the completeness and accuracy of the contract inventory and other third-party data did not exist.
c) DBG legal entities did not establish roles and processes to provide coordinated management of and communication with third parties. The relationship management was set up contract based, resulting in hundreds of contract Business Owners across the organization performing duplicated tasks and actions, leading to unstructured and fragmented third-party documentation. Consequently, the missing coordination resulted in third parties like SAP and Microsoft complaining about repeated and uncoordinated information requests in 2025.
d) A detailed vendor management review of a sample of six major ICT third parties (Google, Tata, Bottomline, Equinix, NTT and Appway) revealed that DBG had not implemented a fully aligned third-party governance, risk or control framework according to the obligations laid down in contracts, including the DORA contractual annex. As DBG works with several hundred ICT third parties plus more than ten third parties supporting CIF, DBG’s internal deadline for implementation and operationalization by December 2025 might be unfeasible in this regard.
e) Although deficiencies in the operationalization of the third-party risk management frameworks were self-identified (see SII-1 below), specific support has not been received by Contract/ Business Owners. Assurance was missing that DORA third-party risk management and vendor management specific expertise were available at the Business Owners.

A full list of supporting examples from 2025-033 and 2025-026 audits’ fieldwork is included in Appendix B.

A comprehensive, end-to-end governance approach for Third-parties management is a regulatory imperative. Fragmented, unaligned and siloed processes, particularly at the 1st LoD, impact 2LoD oversight and are explicitly discouraged, as they undermine the resilience, transparency, consistency and accountability that, particularly, DORA seeks to enforce across the financial sector.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. § Set up a project, with relevant 1LoD and 2LoD representatives, to address the weaknesses identified in the third-party lifecycle management and data governance, including details from Appendix B of the Internal Audit report
§ Involve all relevant legal entities as appropriate.
§ Set up a project plan defining milestones and deliverables.		 01.10.2025 28.02.2026 28.02.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jens Schulte Desiree Ramirez Desiree Ramirez JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (Div) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (FFO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Particularly significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance expose the company to critical regulatory, reputational, and operational risks. Failure to fulfill regulatory requirements constitute severe regulatory non-compliance and can lead to ad-hoc regulatory examinations, financial penalties, administrative orders, remedial measures, and operational restrictions. Penalties are determined by national supervisory authorities, with fines potentially reaching up to 2% of a company's global annual turnover. In addition, lack of accountability and poor contractual and third-party data governance may lead to underestimation of risks and financial losses. Uncoordinated relationship management and communication with third parties may result in reputational damage.
A limited oversight on third-party operational resilience, robustness, and compliance with internal and external requirements, may lead to security deficiencies and operational risks remaining undetected until they materialize.		 Jens Schulte ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),PHILIPPE SEYLL(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy CSDR Art.25,CSSF 20/750,CSSF 25/881,DORA,MaRisk AT 4
2025-033_F02 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F02-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components Internal Audit (IA) observed that the Third-Party Risk Management applications, Spice and the Register of Information (ROI), were not registered as applications in the APMS application inventory. Instead, they were recorded as IT components and used in the production environment to process live data.

These IT components were developed and clustered as components of the IT Application Office 365 (AID551). However, they were not defined or managed as standalone IT/ ICT assets.

IA also identified a lack of clear definition and governance for IT components as IT/ICT assets within both the 1LoD and 2LoD Frameworks. The ICT Frameworks, owned by Enterprise Architecture & Digital Innovation (ENA) and ICT Risk Framework (KJU), did not address the definition, classification, registration, or treatment of IT components and IT/ICT assets.

According to the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.0, all primary and secondary assets must be inventoried and subject to appropriate management controls. IA found that IT components were not defined as either primary or secondary assets, nor were they assigned any asset type classification.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require an up-to-date IT Application Repository that indicates the applications in use and assigns risks and responsibilities. Additionally, clear documentation and governance structures and controls around IT applications must be implemented.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Analyse the situation regarding IT Components for Office 365 (AID551) and act according to the definition received from IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT). 01.10.2025 30.03.2026 30.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Benoit Krier Daniel Hart Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Microsoft 365 Operations (U) Microsoft 365 Operations (ZFR) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components may lead to inconsistent, inaccurate and incomplete asset categorization which may result in the following shortcomings for the whole Group of having IT components that are not designed, documented, implemented, managed, assessed, or controlled according to internal written rules. Furthermore, it may lead to a lack of corresponding controls execution, management and reporting for the IT Components considered as possible IT Application. In addition, risk assessments on component-level are not performed. 
The components are not defined and are considered standalone applications with a dedicated Application ID (AID), lacking transparency on IT Applications in the Group.
Furthermore, a wrong categorization of critical production- related tools/ applications might lead to severe weaknesses in processes such as software license management, application security compliance and governance and the governance of the application portfolios
Not inventorying and managing IT/ICT assets correctly may result in serious adverse regulatory impact or serious reputational damage. It may also hinder existing external regulator's finding closures.		 Benoit Krier CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls

Sarah Ahmad Jahn CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-033_F03 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F03-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in monitoring and reporting of ICT third party risks Internal Audit (IA) identified that the ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not sufficiently monitor the risks related to ICT service providers and overall risk exposure. ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not define risk appetite thresholds or establish monitoring activities related to ICT vendor concentration risk, leading to potential non-compliance with the organization's risk appetite.

In addition, there was a lack of ICT risk reporting mechanisms for ICT third-party risks. The ICT risk management framework did not specify how these risks should be communicated to the Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO, and there was no evidence of these risks being incorporated into the DBAG or Group Risk reporting.

Finally, it was not clearly defined how the existing ICT risk assessment framework, which focuses on ICT assets, considers ICT third-party service providers. The only document describing the framework specifically for ICT service providers was not reviewed by the ICT Risk Officer / CISO. Additionally, the Information Security Policy v1.7 has not been updated since December 2023 and has not been officially decommissioned from the policy database for several legal entities.

Regulation requires ICT functions have appropriate processes and controls to ensure all risks are identified, analyzed, measured, monitored, managed, reported, and kept within the financial institution's risk appetite. The management body should set clear roles and responsibilities for effective risk management, including ICT risks.		 Control Design Effectiveness § Conducts a workshop with Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) and Third-Party Risk Management (ROM) to identify potential of further clarification in ICT Guidelines on how to apply existing risk assessment framework to ICT third- party service providers.
§ Perform an update of ICT Guidelines based on the conducted workshop, if necessary		 01.10.2025 07.08.2026 07.08.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sarah Ahmad Jahn Natalia Saltanovich Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in monitoring and reporting of ICT third party risks represent material violation of external and internal provisions, which can result in operational ambiguity, unforeseen risks and blind spots for overall security posture. Without complete risk monitoring and accurate reporting, identified risks might not be properly addressed. Lack of appropriate ICT third-party risk management may also lead to reputational damage. Sarah Ahmad Jahn BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities CSSF circular 25/881,MaRisk Art. 4 and 9
2025-033_F03 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F03-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in monitoring and reporting of ICT third party risks Internal Audit (IA) identified that the ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not sufficiently monitor the risks related to ICT service providers and overall risk exposure. ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not define risk appetite thresholds or establish monitoring activities related to ICT vendor concentration risk, leading to potential non-compliance with the organization's risk appetite.

In addition, there was a lack of ICT risk reporting mechanisms for ICT third-party risks. The ICT risk management framework did not specify how these risks should be communicated to the Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO, and there was no evidence of these risks being incorporated into the DBAG or Group Risk reporting.

Finally, it was not clearly defined how the existing ICT risk assessment framework, which focuses on ICT assets, considers ICT third-party service providers. The only document describing the framework specifically for ICT service providers was not reviewed by the ICT Risk Officer / CISO. Additionally, the Information Security Policy v1.7 has not been updated since December 2023 and has not been officially decommissioned from the policy database for several legal entities.

Regulation requires ICT functions have appropriate processes and controls to ensure all risks are identified, analyzed, measured, monitored, managed, reported, and kept within the financial institution's risk appetite. The management body should set clear roles and responsibilities for effective risk management, including ICT risks.		 Control Design Effectiveness § Define thresholds to monitor compliance with DOR Strategy and Outsourcing and Third-Party Risk Management Strategy v1.0.
§ Define reporting lines and frequency for third- party ICT risk reporting.
§ Integrate identified ICT third- party risks into Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (ICT) reporting.
§ Monitor the overall risk exposure, particularly related to the accepted residual risks of ICT third- parties.
§ Align with Third Party Risk Management (ROM) regarding roles and responsibilities on reporting of concentration risk.		 01.10.2025 31.12.2025 31.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Martin Madry Natalia Saltanovich Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Monitoring & Reporting (U) ICT Risk Monitoring & Reporting (IRR) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in monitoring and reporting of ICT third party risks represent material violation of external and internal provisions, which can result in operational ambiguity, unforeseen risks and blind spots for overall security posture. Martin Madry BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities CSSF circular 25/881,MaRisk Art. 4 and 9
2025-033_F04 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of methodology for exit plan testing for ICT services supporting CIF. The Exit Management Concept is a Group-level concept designed and owned by Third Party Risk Management (ROM) to ensure maintenance of business continuity in the event of exiting current outsourcing arrangements and/or ICT services supporting critical and important functions (CIFs).

Internal Audit (IA) identified that the Exit Management Concept lacked a methodology for conducting exit plan testing for ICT services supporting CIF’s:
§ The testing steps and scenarios were not defined, hindering effective assessment of exit plan resilience and demonstrable DORA compliance.
§ The concept mentioned the tests were conducted by means of ‘tabletop testing’ but did not define roles and responsibilities for conducting, reviewing, and approving tests and test results.
§ IA’s inquiry noted ‘updated exit plan’ was considered the test outcome, with no defined success criteria or documented results.
§ No defined storage location for documenting testing activities (steps, outcomes, reviews). This hindered access to test results, analysis of testing effectiveness, and weakened the audit trail.

As per Article 28(8) under Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), exit plans concerning ICT services supporting CIF’s need to be ‘sufficiently tested and reviewed periodically’.		 Control Design Effectiveness Create a Group-wide exit plan testing methodology that, at a minimum, defines testing steps and scenarios, allocates roles and responsibilities, specifies testing outcomes and follow-up actions, and outlines the process for documenting and storing testing results. 01.10.2025 15.02.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Faina West-Friesen Sakshi Shanavaspur Ashok Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of methodology for exit plan testing increases the risk of inadequate testing, exposing to regulatory scrutiny and hindering the ability to identify and remediate weaknesses in exit plans. This could lead to business disruption, non-compliance with DORA requirements and financial losses if an actual exit is required. Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines
2025-033_F05 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Outdated written rules used for Ecosystem Partner risk assessments Internal Audit (IA) identified that the current and latest version of the internal written rules, developed and published by ICT Risk Framework (KJU) in January 2025, were not incorporated in the Prevalent application (AID2040). Therefore, supplier risk assessments were based on the outdated IS Standards from 2024.

Further, DORA-specific terms such as Critical and Important Functions (CIF) were not integrated in the Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management assessments.

During the audit timeframe, ICT Risk Framework (KJU) transferred the current company demands and control requirements in the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF) v5.0, released in May 2025. By the end of fieldwork, the latest MCF was, however, not yet incorporated in Prevalent. Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) confirmed operationalization would begin in Q4 2025.

European regulations require that organizations implement and maintain effective compliance monitoring controls and risk assessments.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Integrate and operationalize the latest and current written rules in Prevalent and introduce DORA-specific terms such as Critical and Important Functions (CIF). 01.10.2025 16.01.2026 16.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH Deutsche Börse AG Florian Rodeit, Markus Peter Schaufler, Valentina Klemperova Frank Ackermann Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Mana (U) Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) agrees with the finding and the first part of the recommendation. The recommendation regarding CIFs is to the extent possible already implemented at EPS. Outdated written rules used for ecosystem partner risk assessments lead to incomplete risk management and oversight, resulting in minor (non-public) sanctions or a minor breach of regulatory requirements. Valentina Klemperova CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Circular CSSF 20/750
2025-033_F06 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F06-A01 Recommendation Submitted New Deadline by Auditee S2 No information labeling in the Prevalent (AID2040) application Internal Audit identified that the Prevalent (AID2040) application’s uploaded Ecosystem Partner risk assessment information and supporting evidence, as well as generated reports and profiles, were not classified and labeled. Prevalent did not support document labels such as ‘public’, ‘internal’ or ‘confidential’.

This contradicted Prevalent’s ISO27001 certification applicability statement and confirmation that Prevalent’s ISMS meets the objective “To limit access to information and information processing facilities”.

European regulation requires information be classified and labeled.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Implement information labeling for information uploaded to and extracted from Prevalent (AID2040). The implementation must consider the above-listed criteria. 01.10.2025 15.12.2025 15.12.2025 01.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Martin Krnac, François Leveling, Markus Peter Schaufler Frank Ackermann Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Cloud Application Operations (S) Cloud Application Operations (CAO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. No information labeling in Prevalent may result in information processed and exported by users, who may disclose these details beyond the authorized audience or confidential data may be misused. This may lead to a minor breach of regulatory requirements and material reputational impact. CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness
2025-033_F07 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F07-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in the contract life cycle management tool’s exemption framework Internal Audit identified that there was no control mechanism to verify the use of valid Exemption IDs on Sirion (AID2129), allowing contract owners to add invalid exception IDs without detection. Additionally, the process for the periodic review of general exemptions was not formally documented.

European regulations and Internal requirements require that organizations implement and maintain effective processes and controls.		 Control Design Effectiveness Establish a documented process for the periodic review of exemptions incl. controls to ensure a valid exemption ID is used for exempted contracts. 01.10.2025 30.11.2025 30.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Teodora Paul Desiree Ramirez Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Contract Support & Tooling (U) Contract Support & Tooling (FPO) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in the contract life cycle management tool’s exemption framework may result in contracts being improperly approved through the exception processes, potentially leading to material breaches of regulatory requirements. Teodora Paul ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls CSSF Circular 12/522,MaRisk Art 4.3.1,§
2025-033_F08 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of a Sirion issue management framework and procedure Sirion (AID2129) was introduced as the Group-wide contract lifecycle management system during the audit period, superseding SAP CLM (AID214).

Internal Audit noted that there was no:
§ framework and procedure for managing incidents or bugs in Sirion, detailing e.g. how issues are prioritized, how issues are allocated to IT supporters, how long the team has to respond, etc.
§ formal approval/control to ensure all issues reported via the mailbox/ other applicable channels are transferred to the internal tracking list
§ comprehensive analysis performed e.g., on the basis of the issue overview such as response time tracking, particularly from Sirion, or repeated issues that reflect the service quality delivered from Sirion and consistency checks

European, German and Luxembourg regulation require robust governance arrangements including clear organisational structures with well-defined lines of responsibility.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. § Establish a Sirion issue management framework and procedure, including -but not limited to- clearly assigned ownership and accountability for issue management activities, and defining how issues are prioritized, logged, assigned, tracked and resolved by means of a definition concept supported by clear workflows created in the chosen tool.
§ Implement a control to ensure all issues reported via the mailbox and other applicable channels are transferred to the internal tracking list, in case a ticket tool is chosen but not effective until the target date by documenting the control and/or providing a procedure for transferring the issues to the tool supported by operational effectiveness evidence of the ticket tool.
§ Perform a comprehensive analysis and establish team internal key performance indicators (KPIs) such as tracking of response times, repeated issues that reflect the service quality delivered from Sirion and consistency checks by definition of KPIs and their internal reporting.

Assess and document which ticket management system is appropriate to ensure completeness and correctness of issue management including an evaluation of the risks via documented evaluation and decision taken including the reasoning.		 01.10.2025 17.12.2025 17.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Teodora Paul Jessica Dominey Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Contract Support & Tooling (U) Contract Support & Tooling (FPO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of a Sirion issue management framework and procedure represents a material violation of external and internal provisions. That may lead to weak or inconsistent controls over issue tracking and remediation and thus increasing the likelihood of errors and inefficiencies with potential financial losses. Teodora Paul ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines CSSF Circular 12/522,MaRisk Art 4.3.1, 5
2025-033_F09 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F09-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Incomplete Legal Inventory regarding DORA Internal Audit identified that Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) did not perform a comprehensive mapping of Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) articles to the Legal Inventory for their processes.

Regulatory requirements and internal provisions require robust compliance arrangements including the identification and documentation of legal obligations and integration into the control and governance frameworks.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Update the Legal Inventory to ensure that all relevant DORA requirements are accurately reflected and maintained. 01.10.2025 14.11.2025 14.11.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Florian Rodeit, Markus Peter Schaufler, Valentina Klemperova Desiree Ramirez Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Mana (U) Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete Legal Inventory regarding DORA may lead to non-compliance with external and internal provisions. It represents a minor violation of regulatory requirements. This may lead to key regulatory obligations to be unintentionally overlooked, which may result in a lack of or inadequate control implementation. Valentina Klemperova CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness CSSF circular 12/552,MaRisk Art. 4.4.2
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Control Environment Review the content of the CFCL Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 01.10.2025 14.01.2026 14.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Adriaan Bemelmans Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO STEEG Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll Outsourcing & Controls (U) Outsourcing & Controls (KOU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Adriaan Bemelmans ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Human Error/ Omission CSSF Circular 22/806

These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability.
