2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Control Environment Review the content of the DBAG/EFAG Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 01.10.2025 14.01.2026 14.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Faina West-Friesen Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Human Error/ Omission CSSF Circular 22/806
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Control Environment Review the content of the CBL/CEU/CI/CS/CH Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed.

IA acknowledges that the recommendation was partially addressed at the time of audit report issuance, particularly in relation to the process breakdown.		 01.10.2025 14.01.2026 14.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Clearstream Europe AG Gianna Kore Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) UDO HENKELMANN Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ZFF) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Gianna Kore ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Human Error/ Omission CSSF Circular 22/806
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A05 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Control Environment Review the content of the ExR Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 01.10.2025 14.01.2026 14.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Eurex Repo GmbH Frank Odendall Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) FRANK ODENDALL Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Funding & Financing Products & Marke (U) Funding & Financing Products & Markets (DVS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Frank Odendall ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Human Error/ Omission CSSF Circular 22/806
2025-033_F12 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F12-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of ICT-specific questions in pre-assessment questionnaire for non-IT business process initiativ Internal Audit noted that, while there were established controls in place for the pre-assessment by Outsourcing Coordinators (OC), there was a gap in the pre-assessment process for services categorized as business process (BPO) non-IT. Specifically, the pre-assessment questionnaire (PAQ) lacked targeted ICT-related questions to ensure that the requested service was independent form ICT systems or infrastructures.

The initial classification of services is determined by the Service Requestor (SR) during the PAQ process. For BPO (non-IT), reliance is placed on information from the service description, product group, and ICT category defined in the pre-assessment master data. However, there were no additional targeted ICT questions within the PAQ workflow for this service, such as “Does this service involve software“ or “data processing cloud storage”, or “remote access to the outsourcer system?”, to substantiate that the service was non-IT related in nature.

Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) mandates financial institution to clearly identify and manage Information and Communication Technology (ICT) dependencies to ensure digital operational resilience.		 Control Design Effectiveness Update the Pre Assessment Questionnaire (PRA) for non-IT Business Processes initiative to include targeted ICT-related questions. 01.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Faina West-Friesen Alba Kajtazi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of ICT-specific questions in pre-assessment questionnaire for non-IT business process initiative presents the risk of misclassification, whereby ICT-reliant services could be incorrectly treated as non-ICT. Consequently, such services may circumvent ICT risk assessments, leading to potential minor non-compliance with DORA requirements. Additionally, high volume of assessment and manual controls from Outsourcing Coordinators (OC) makes the process prone to human error.  Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Human Error/ Omission CSSF 22/806, Ch. 4,MaRisk – Art. 9
2025-033_F14 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F14-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inconsistent terminology and documentation in Exit Action Plan Internal Audit (IA) noted that DBG's Exit Action Plan (EAP) template included the topics required under 'Exit Strategy' as per the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA). However, the template did not explicitly reference the term 'Exit Strategy'. The elements of the 'Exit Strategy' (e.g., contractual transfer information, impacted business areas, exit options) were included within the EAP's 'Exit Plan' section, and the 'Action Plan' section contained implementation details that align with DORA's understanding of an 'Exit Plan'. The exclusion of the term ‘Exit Strategy’ could lead regulators to believe that DBG lacks such a strategy.

IA also observed documentation inconsistencies. Appway referred to 'Exit Strategy', but its content corresponded to the information in the EAP's 'Exit Plan' section. This inconsistency could create confusion during regulatory reviews and audits. The inconsistency further contributed to broader issues in mapping information between the procedures, Appway, and the Register of Information. IA required several interactions to understand and map this information, highlighting the difficulty a third party would face.

As per DORA, ‘For ICT services supporting critical or important functions, financial entities shall put in place exit strategies’.		 Control Design Effectiveness Add an explanation to the Exit Action Plan template demonstrating how DBG's current template addresses the DORA exit strategy requirement, mapping existing practices to specific DORA elements for clarity during regulatory reviews and audits. 01.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Faina West-Friesen Sakshi Shanavaspur Ashok Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inconsistent Terminology and Documentation in Exit Action Plan might lead to misinterpretation by regulators regarding the existence of such a strategy within DBG. Inconsistencies between procedural documents and the Appway system could further complicate the clear understanding of this area during regulatory reviews. This might expose the company to limited regulatory or operational risk. Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Human Error/ Omission
2025-034_F02 2025 2025-034 Securities Processing (ECAG) 2025-034_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Insufficiently documented controls within Securities Processing process Internal Audit (IA) noted insufficiently documented controls and steps
done within:
§ Regarding the C7 SCS Balance Check – Imbalance Clean-Up subprocess, on the 5 months sample:
- In 1 tested month, step 7 was not fully performed on entering the details of all ECAXX cash movements in the Daily Cash Reco Reporting Sheet (Cash Reco daily reporting.xlsx) although check was assessed as completed in Checklist. The excel file was updated during audit with missing information in the sheet Sonstige Cash-Details.
- In 1 tested month, step 10 to inform relevant departments about the extraordinary settlement was not fully performed, although check was assessed as completed in Checklist. Namely, Eurex COO & CRO were not informed. The risk is partially mitigated as they were informed at later stage when DMP requested the activation of ECAXX.

§ Regarding the Coupon Compensation – Net-Gross Tax Correction subprocess, on the population of 5 cases:
- In 2 tested cases, step 3 member notifications were prepared and sent based on outdated notification templates (outdated contacts on the template). Risk is mitigated as template is no longer in use.

§ Regarding the Cash Settlement Equities subprocess, on the 5 months sample:
- In all 5 tested months, calculation of Cash Settlement amount signed, Announcement of Cash Settlement to CM and Cash Settlement Fee recording was not documented under Organizational 4 eyes-principle, although it was designed.
§ Regarding the Eurex Fixed Income Futures expiry handling subprocess, on sample of 3 quarters:
- In 2 tested quarters, Checklist tasks were not fully marked as complete.

Internal business procedures 7.2.5.3.3 C7 SCS Balance Check – Imbalance Clean-Up defined excel sheet and tabs to be updated and , relevant departments to be informed. 7.2.1.3.12 Coupon Compensation – Net-Gross Tax Correction defined notification templated to be used. 7.2.1.1.7 Cash Settlement Equities defined organizational 4 eyes-principle controls to be followed, 7.2.1.2.6 Eurex Fixed Income Futures expiry handling defined usage of checklists for subprocess execution accuracy.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends that Securities Clearing Operations (ZQY) perform controls based on the designed 7.2.5.3.3 C7 SCS Balance Check – Imbalance Clean-Up, 7.2.1.3.12 Coupon Compensation – Net-Gross Tax Correction, 7.2.1.1.7 Cash Settlement Equities and 7.2.1.2.6 Eurex Fixed Income Futures expiry handling subprocesses. 17.06.2025 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Janine Roszak, Nadezhda Ermakova, Daniela Prestino-Rühl Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Securities Clearing Operations (U) Securities Clearing Operations (ZQY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficiently documented controls within Securities Processing process bears the risk of inability to prove control efficiency. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions and could have material adverse regulatory impact in terms of regulatory examinations in case control performance could not be completely proved. Nadezhda Ermakova JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-037_F02 2025 2025-037 Corporate Tax (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-037_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in Corporate Tax services outsourcing agreements and KPI reports Internal Audit (IA) assessed 16 Service Definition Statements (SDS) and Intra Service Definition Statements for the legal entities in scope of this audit. The assessment identified several deficiencies in the outsourcing agreements related to Corporate Tax services:
§ Eight SDS  contained incorrect references to the Tax Service Catalogue, which outlines and specifies the outsourced tax services.
§ Five SDS  were incomplete and inaccurate concerning the sub-outsourcing of tax services from DBAG to Clearstream Services (CS) for Luxembourg legal entities. The referenced 'Outsourcing Hub' was not consistently reflected across all relevant outsourcing agreements. IA also identified missing annexes and an unclear scope definition for the Luxembourg entities.
§ Financial Reporting was an agreed-upon service between several Luxembourg entities (CI, CBL, LuxCSD, and CS) and DBAG. However, this service was not reflected in the downstream SDS between DBAG and Clearstream Services (CS), resulting in a break in the documented outsourcing chain.

Additionally, IA identified weaknesses in the Key Performance Indicator (KPI) reports for Corporate Tax services. Specifically, the reports were incomplete in relation to the services defined in the SDS, and discrepancies were noted between the defined KPI metrics and the actual reported figures. For example, while the SDS specified a KPI target of 1 (reflecting the number of annual reports), a KPI of 300 was reported to the outsourcing legal entity.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations and guidance require that outsourcing arrangements be formalized through a service contract. These contracts must be complete, up to date, and accurately reflect all the services agreed upon between the outsourcing legal entity and the service provider. In addition, outsourced services must be subject to robust risk monitoring and management mechanisms to ensure regulatory compliance and maintain operational resilience.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (ZGW):
§ Review and update all existing outsourcing agreements to ensure complete and correct representation of agreed Corporate Tax services in line with the Tax Service Catalogue.
§ Review and update all outsourcing contracts with regard to correct representation of tax services sub-outsourcing from DBAG to Clearstream Services (CS) for Luxembourg legal entities.
§ Revise the outsourcing agreement between CS and DBAG to ensure accurate representation of financial reporting responsibilities.
§ Review and align KPI reports with the KPIs defined in the respective outsourcing agreements.
§ Verify and correct the KPI reporting metrics to ensure consistency with contractual definitions.		 28.08.2025 31.03.2026 31.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Marc Seedorf Elena Krause Elena Krause JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Group Tax (A) Nancy Eva Schanda Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (U) Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (ZGW) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in Corporate Tax services outsourcing agreements and KPI reports represent a material violation of external provisions and internal policies. This may lead to deviations in service quality or erroneous intercompany billing with minor financial impact and minor regulatory sanctions. Marc Seedorf ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Europe AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG) Lack of Awareness CSSF 22/806,MaRisk 06/2024
2025-037_F06 2025 2025-037 Corporate Tax (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-037_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Lack of documented decision on non-execution of EU VAT refund process Internal Audit (IA) identified that the EU VAT refund process for Clearstream legal entities in Luxembourg was initiated but not finalized as per the documented procedure. Although recurring cost-benefit assessments indicated limited justification for pursuing refunds, no formal decision was taken to classify the process as dormant. Nonetheless, it remained dormant within the Clearstream process landscape.

A similar issue was observed for EU VAT refund process applicable to German entities in addition to a lack of process description.

In accordance with European, German, and Luxembourg regulatory requirements, financial institutions are expected to establish and maintain a clearly defined process landscape that outlines the roles and responsibilities of each functional unit. This process landscape must be regularly reviewed and promptly updated to reflect any organizational changes or decisions impacting process execution.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Group Tax (ZFC):
§ Conduct a one-off comprehensive cost-benefit analysis of the EU VAT refund process to determine whether EU VAT refund process should be continued or formally discontinued.
§ Ensure that the decision is properly documented with clear rationale and supporting evidence.
§ Assess whether Group Tax holds the authority to make this decision independently or if escalation to a higher governance level (e.g., DBAG Executive Board) is necessary.
§ Following the decision, update the Luxembourg and German process landscapes to accurately reflect the current execution status.		 28.08.2025 27.03.2026 27.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Nancy Eva Schanda Séverine Michel-Degueurce Elena Krause JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Group Tax (A) Nancy Eva Schanda Group Tax (A) Group Tax (ZFC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of documented decision on non-execution of EU VAT refund process leads to an inaccurate representation of active processes. This might result in a minor violation of internal and external provisions, such as negligible breach of regulatory requirements. Nancy Eva Schanda ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Europe AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy CSSF 12/522,MaRisk 06/2024
2025-042_F04 2025 2025-042 Trading (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-042_F04-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 ECAG audit limitations for outsourced services  Derivatives Trading Operations (DTO), as part of Eurex Frankfurt AG (EFAG), performed processes both on behalf of Eurex Deutschland (ED) under public law and for EFAG as the exchange operator under private law.
Under contracts MA-002016-2020 (Daily Support and Product Data Maintenance Risk Services) and MA-001894-2020 (Daily Settlement Price Determination services), EFAG provided operational services to Eurex Clearing AG (ECAG). These outsourcing contracts also provided IA ECAG with unlimited audit rights.

Internal Audit (IA) observed that these services included activities that were also marked as carried out on behalf of ED under public law, such as the settlement process. IA ECAG did not have a general mandate to audit those service components governed by public law, as access is generally restricted by ED as a public exchange. The current situation does not fully reflect the contractually agreed audit rights without a specific mandate of ED.		 Control Design Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends Clearing Delivery & Control (DDF) to:
- assess the associated risks in collaboration with the insourcing party considering relevant governance decisions on audit rights from the insourcer’s side. Evaluate whether these decisions affect the existing contractual framework and prepare a set of actionable options for presentation to the ECAG Executive Board
- implement measures to remediate audit limitations following the decision of the ECAG Executive Board (for example, adjusting the underlying service contract)		 19.08.2025 16.07.2026 16.07.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Markus Holecz Praveen Venkatachalam Andreas Seifert THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Clearing Delivery & Control (S) Clearing Delivery & Control (DDF) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Audit restrictions could occur in future audits if this mandate is not granted by ED as it exceptionally was for 2025, potentially limiting IA ECAG’s ability to exercise effective oversight over the full scope of outsourced services. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions related to auditability and oversight responsibilities. It may also lead to significant regulatory impact and reputational damage. Markus Holecz JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Lack of Awareness

2025-043_F04 2025 2025-043 IT Platform Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-043_F04-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over MySQL database baseline configuration A security baseline defines the minimum required security level, prescribing the technical measures and configurations for a given infrastructure asset type.

Security configurations based on the respective security baseline documents for MySQL databases were largely performed manually; hence continuous scanning of database security baseline configurations was essential to timely detect misconfigurations.

Internal Audit noted that the MySQL databases were excluded from automated baseline security scans performed by Rapid7 Nexpose due to technical non-compatibility and resolution of the issue was currently in discussion with the vendor. However, for 21 out of 24 sampled database servers, even annual manual compliance reviews had not been performed as defined in Baseline Security Guideline version 1.6.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation require that systems are configured with applicable security baselines and monitored to identify and timely remediate any deficiencies.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Work in close cooperation with VM – Scan Services (VMS), and Security IT – Digitize, Evolve, Innovate (SAO) to ensure that MySQL databases are onboarded to the Rapid7 Nexpose baseline scanning platform to perform a scalable and sustainable review of database security based on central database baselines. 13.10.2025 01.12.2026 01.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Vaclav Sulc Shravankumar Mohankumar Volker Scheer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Infrastructure Operations (U) Infrastructure Operations (ZFB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete onboarding of MySQL databases to baseline security scanning platforms could lead to undetected security gaps in the database system settings, thereby increasing the risk of cyber-attacks, data breaches and unauthorized access, thus materially violating various applicable internal and external provisions. Vaclav Sulc CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness
2025-043_F04 2025 2025-043 IT Platform Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-043_F04-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over MySQL database baseline configuration A security baseline defines the minimum required security level, prescribing the technical measures and configurations for a given infrastructure asset type.

Security configurations based on the respective security baseline documents for MySQL databases were largely performed manually; hence continuous scanning of database security baseline configurations was essential to timely detect misconfigurations.

Internal Audit noted that the MySQL databases were excluded from automated baseline security scans performed by Rapid7 Nexpose due to technical non-compatibility and resolution of the issue was currently in discussion with the vendor. However, for 21 out of 24 sampled database servers, even annual manual compliance reviews had not been performed as defined in Baseline Security Guideline version 1.6.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation require that systems are configured with applicable security baselines and monitored to identify and timely remediate any deficiencies.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Work in close cooperation with VM – Scan Services (VMS), and Security IT – Digitize, Evolve, Innovate (SAO) to onboard MySQL databases to the Rapid7 Nexpose baseline scanning platform and perform a scalable and sustainable review of database security based on central database baselines.  13.10.2025 01.12.2026 01.12.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Eurex Frankfurt AG Helge Harren, Jens Hoffmann Shravankumar Mohankumar Volker Scheer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) QUINTEN KOEKENBIER CIO / COO (Div) Derivatives & Cash Trading IT (Dpt) Quinten Koekenbier Xetra/Eurex Operations (Dpt) Xetra / Eurex Operations (ZJK) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete onboarding of MySQL databases to baseline security scanning platforms could lead to undetected security gaps in the database system settings, thereby increasing the risk of cyber-attacks, data breaches and unauthorized access, thus materially violating various applicable internal and external provisions. Helge Harren CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness
2025-043_F04 2025 2025-043 IT Platform Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-043_F04-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over MySQL database baseline configuration A security baseline defines the minimum required security level, prescribing the technical measures and configurations for a given infrastructure asset type.

Security configurations based on the respective security baseline documents for MySQL databases were largely performed manually; hence continuous scanning of database security baseline configurations was essential to timely detect misconfigurations.

Internal Audit noted that the MySQL databases were excluded from automated baseline security scans performed by Rapid7 Nexpose due to technical non-compatibility and resolution of the issue was currently in discussion with the vendor. However, for 21 out of 24 sampled database servers, even annual manual compliance reviews had not been performed as defined in Baseline Security Guideline version 1.6.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation require that systems are configured with applicable security baselines and monitored to identify and timely remediate any deficiencies. 2025-043_F04 2025 2025-043 IT Platform Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-043_F04-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over MySQL database baseline configuration A security baseline defines the minimum required security level, prescribing the technical measures and configurations for a given infrastructure asset type.

Security configurations based on the respective security baseline documents for MySQL databases were largely performed manually; hence continuous scanning of database security baseline configurations was essential to timely detect misconfigurations.

Internal Audit noted that the MySQL databases were excluded from automated baseline security scans performed by Rapid7 Nexpose due to technical non-compatibility and resolution of the issue was currently in discussion with the vendor. However, for 21 out of 24 sampled database servers, even annual manual compliance reviews had not been performed as defined in Baseline Security Guideline version 1.6.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation require that systems are configured with applicable security baselines and monitored to identify and timely remediate any deficiencies. Vaclav Sulc CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness
2025-043_F05 2025 2025-043 IT Platform Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-043_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over baseline configuration for Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization platform Virtualization platform XEOPs Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization (RHEV) (AID1059) comprises a so-called hypervisor, used to abstract and allocate shared computing resources like Central Processing Unit (CPU) and memory to virtual machines.

As per Baseline Security Guideline version 1.6, security settings on the hypervisors must be configured in line with the respective hypervisor security baseline provided by Group Security.

Internal Audit (IA) noted that a RHEV security baseline did not exist. As a result, RHEV requirements, to allow mapping of Hypervisor configuration settings against them, were not defined. IA also noted that support for RHEV was valid until May 2026, and work was underway to decommission RHEV by this date.

European and German regulation require that systems are configured with applicable security baselines and monitored to identify and timely remediate any deficiencies.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Initiate a formal risk acceptance to acknowledge the non-existence of a RHEV security baseline and outlining a respective mitigation plan. 13.10.2025 27.11.2025 27.11.2025 0 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Group IT Audit Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Group IT Audit Eurex Frankfurt AG Helge Harren, Jens Hoffmann Shravankumar Mohankumar Volker Scheer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) QUINTEN KOEKENBIER CIO / COO (Div) Derivatives & Cash Trading IT (Dpt) Quinten Koekenbier Xetra/Eurex Operations (Dpt) Xetra / Eurex Operations (ZJK) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Potential Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization hypervisor misconfiguration due to inadequate baseline security governance could lead to undetected security gaps in the system settings, thereby increasing the risk of cyber-attacks, data breaches and unauthorized access, thus materially violating various applicable internal and external provisions. Helge Harren CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-043_F06 2025 2025-043 IT Platform Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-043_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of central ownership and inadequate governance for Red Hat Enterprise Linux Deutsche Börse Group used Red Hat Enterprise Linux as operating system platform across various business and infrastructure domains. Approximately 2,500 productive Linux installations with different Linux versions and distributions were inconsistently maintained by twelve different support groups.

Despite internal requirements, these Linux installations were neither managed, accordingly documented nor controlled as an asset in the CMS master inventory tool. CMS did not have fields for documenting mandatory information about assets in the “Software” category, in which Linux must be recorded. Internal Audit acknowledged that the Asset Owner for Linux was nominated in a different tool, CMS_to_RAP (AID210, part of SAP CRM). However, the criticality of identical operating systems (OS) in the same version was different depending on the applications running on the corresponding OS and also the internal requirements as per ICT Asset Management Guideline ID:4 were not fulfilled, e.g.:
§ comprehensive asset lifecycle history, including change logs (user, timestamp) and review cycles
§ Tagging of KRITIS-relevant assets
§ Tagging of CIF / DORA-relevant assets
§ Network exposure details (e.g. internet exposure)
§ ICT business continuity requirements (RTO and RPO)

CMS did not provide information about relationships between Linux Assets and IT Product Line owners.

Additionally, some asset owner IDs listed in CMS_to_RAP could not be mapped to an individual person.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. § Enable mandatory data fields (e.g. Asset Owner) in CMS for OS Asset types considering ICT Asset Management Guideline
§ The process to regularly check the accuracy of the data Information should be updated.
§ Ensure that the new mandatory data fields are populated and centrally control their maintenance		 13.10.2025 30.04.2026 30.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Volker Potworowski Olga Braitsev Volker Scheer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Advanced Innovation Operations (U) IT Core Process Governance (ÜPÜ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of central ownership and inadequate governance for Red Hat Enterprise Linux can lead to a lack of accountability for security and proper lifecycle management of the Linux distributions and may violate internal and external requirements that every asset must be inventoried and assigned to a dedicated asset owner. This could result in gaps in external provisions such as a minor breach of regulatory requirements. Volker Potworowski CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-045_F01 2025 2025-045 Cyber- and Information Security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-045_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiency in Cryptography Key Management documentation, Process Governance for multiple application Internal Audit recommends that Security IT – Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO):
§ classify and update the “Audit Document” and the contents of the SAO SharePoint site according to the DBG Written Rules Framework Guideline
§ determine the key relevance of the internal documentation (working instructions, procedures) and its possible shared usage, to consider transferring them into DBG’s official IT written rules database in coordination with IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT)		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Security IT – Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO):
§ classify and update the “Audit Document” and the contents of the SAO SharePoint site according to the DBG Written Rules Framework Guideline
§ determine the key relevance of the internal documentation (working instructions, procedures) and its possible shared usage, to consider transferring them into DBG’s official IT written rules database in coordination with IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT)		 08.09.2025 24.04.2026 24.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Geoffrey Saint-Alary, Ana-Simona Pop Kevin Gregory Floro Yezad Wadia CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Inn (U) Security IT – Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  The PKI DBAG (AID1064) and PKI Clearstream (1066) applications are internal Certificate Authorities used to digitally sign certificates for internal applications and servers that are requested by other teams within DBAG and Clearstream legal entities. PKI MSCA (AID1065) is a Certificate Authority used to digitally sign certificates that are requested regarding Skype and Outlook S/MIME  certificates and Microsoft Windows Hello for Business.

During an inspection of the PKI DBAG, PKI Clearstream and PKI MSCA cryptography key management processes primarily managed by Security IT’s - Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO) unit, they referenced an internal operational procedure as “Audit Document” instead of a formally approved procedure. The document didn’t include essential elements (i.e., purpose, scope, management approval) as defined by the overarching Written Rules Framework Guideline. Despite its informal nature and not being published in the central written rules repository, SAO acknowledged the Audit Document was possibly used by multiple IT Operations/Production Support teams as a key reference for the structure of their own key management procedures, to support and further operationalize the requirements laid down in the primary document, the Encryption and Key Management Guideline published centrally by the Chief Risk Officer (FOC) area.

Further inspection of the SAO SharePoint site revealed that 19 out of 37 cryptography-related operating procedures and work instructions had not been reviewed and approved in several years (between 2020-2023) and did not state whether they were active or decommissioned. While a yearly review control exists in a JIRA task (SECPKII-1063), it lacked detailed execution steps, as well as evidence of its performance.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require precise and clear procedures manual which is accessible and up to date must be maintained. Business activities are conducted based on organizational guidelines. Related business, control and monitoring documentation should be written in a manner that is readily comprehensible to expert third parties.		 Geoffrey Saint-Alary CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines

§ complete the review, approval and publishing of the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.1
§ update the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF) for new asset-type and its control requirements

§ update the ‘APMS_User Manual’ and ‘APMS Process Description’ documents with detailed criteria / guidance and their rollout
§ update APMS application functionality to include new asset type
§ impart awareness across DBG on the new asset type		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) -
§ update the ‘APMS_User Manual’ and ‘APMS Process Description’ documents with detailed criteria / guidance and their rollout
§ update APMS application functionality to include new asset type
§ impart awareness across DBG on the new asset type		 08.09.2025 03.04.2026 03.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sean Mc Taggart Anvay Walavalkar Yezad Wadia JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Core Process Governance (U) IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  An audit comment 5.3 raised in 2024-063 Technology Governance noted Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) was incomplete regarding external web assets/services, which IA provisionally designated as “Partner Services”. A feasibility assessment about introducing Partner Services as a new asset type was to be completed by December 2024, its definition included within the ICT Asset Management Guideline v1.0 and control requirements established in the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF).

IA noted that DBG’s APMS inventory did not yet include Partner Services. 2nd LoD - ICT Risk Framework (KJU) and 1st LoD - IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) were still developing clear definition, control requirements and process descriptions. KJU plans to put in force a fully revised ICT Asset Management Guideline v1.1, including the definition of Partner Services, by end of Q3 2025.

German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets. Olga Wenge CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness
2025-045_F08 2025 2025-045 Cyber- and Information Security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-045_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Lack of details in vulnerability management procedures in respect to timelines of involved teams Internal Audit recommends that Plan & Design Services (VLM) propose an adequate solution agreed between relevant stakeholders and implemented in related procedures. Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Plan & Design Services (VLM) propose an adequate solution agreed between relevant stakeholders and implemented in related procedures. 08.09.2025 18.02.2026 18.02.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Rahul Choubey, Teut Noeske Milos Medrik Yezad Wadia CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker VM - Plan & Design Services (U) Plan & Design Services (VLM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. When assessing DBG’s vulnerability management solution Rapid7 Nexpose (NXP), Internal Audit (IA) identified around 2500 NXP tickets with status ‘Fix Claimed’ that were overdue, out of which 45 were critical or high. Addressing vulnerabilities until closure is the IT Asset Owner’s/Application Owner’s (IT teams) responsibility, and the vulnerability management team – Plan & Design Services (VLM) – acts as a control function, by confirming/rejecting the IT teams ‘Fix claimed’ and ‘False Positive’ status claims. Such tickets statuses are being reported as part of the Digital Security Committee (DSC) KPIs, however these should have been treated and set to ‘close’ by the VLM team or by the automated re-test.

Deadlines for treatment of vulnerabilities are set in the ICT Patch and Vulnerabilities Management Guideline, however multiple teams need to be involved – teams treating the fix (IT teams) and validating the fix (VLM), who all need a certain time to perform their tasks. The underlying procedures were not detailed enough to be able to respect jointly the timelines set by the guidelines. In case the IT team submitted the ticket as ‘Fix Claimed’ just before the overall deadline, the ticket was already in ‘overdue’ status when treated by VLM.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires organizations to establish a structured process for identifying, assessing, remediating, and reporting vulnerabilities.		 Rahul Choubey CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines
2025-046_F01 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the control of duplicate invoices Internal Audit (IA) noted a weakness in the control framework over duplicate invoices. Those with a purchase order (PO) were subject to a three-way match in SAP, acting as a preventive control to block potential duplicate or erroneous payments. However, non-PO invoices relied solely on embedded system rules functioning as a detective control. The rules flagged potential duplicates, but did not prevent them at source.

IA analyzed all invoices processed in VIM for the period under review using data analytics to flag entries which matched across different records and identified two instances (both below EUR 2K) where duplicate invoices were processed and paid, demonstrating that current controls over non-PO invoices were not sufficiently robust.

In line with external and internal provisions, management should maintain and enhance adequate and effective internal control mechanisms and risk management practices to address such risks.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) provide refresher training to all staff involved in the invoice processing and approval workflow. The training should cover updated procedures, the importance of adhering to established controls (including duplicate payments checks), and any recent process changes or enhancements. 15.08.2025 16.12.2025 16.12.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Martin Kotula Ourania Androulaki Denise Weigelt JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Pr (U) Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Weaknesses in the control of duplicate invoices expose the company to the risk of material operational errors and financial losses due to duplicate or erroneous payments. This can also result in additional effort for reversals and reconciliations, impacting the efficiency of the company’s operations. Martin Kotula ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Europe AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-046_F02 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Incomplete Facility Management Frankfurt asset database Internal Audit (IA) noted that the tool Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF) utilized to manage assets was incomplete: the Excel file did not comply with the DBG Asset Management Policy as it lacked mandatory information necessary to reconcile assets against the SAP S4 database for the Asset Inventory year-end process.

Specifically, IA’s data analytics on FMF’s total 11,533-asset inventory identified the following:
§ 3,899 cases had no company code, only an asset number.
§ 2,723 cases had neither a company code nor an asset number.
§ 3,538 cases belonged to the outdated company code “0000”.

Accounting Germany (FTD) relied on FMF’s data for the annual asset inventory preparation. This involved checking whether the SAP S4 assets under FMF responsibility were “in use”, “disposed”, and/or “transferred”. IA compared the FTD final inventory count with FMF inventory records and found that only 251 out of FMF’s 11,533 recorded assets matched FTD’s inventory.

IA acknowledges that several past changes, e.g. purchase order input generating the SAP Asset Number; SAP S4 migration; no SAP S4 to FMF database system link, made it difficult to maintain the FMF inventory and align with the DBG Asset Management Policy requirements.

In accordance with the International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the German Commercial Code (HGB), companies are required to disclose tangible assets, including inventories, in the financial statements. To ensure their accuracy and reliability, a physical inventory count must be conducted.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends that Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF):
§ clean up the current FMF database to ensure compliance with the DBG Asset Management Policy requirements and match the SAP Asset Number with the unique FMF identifier
§ reconcile the FMF database assets against SAP S/4 and communicate the results whether the assets are “disposed”, “in use”, or “transferred to another company code” to Accounting Germany (FTD)
§ in case of identified gaps, investigate together with FTD to understand the rationale behind the noted differences. Upon review, update the internal Excel file accordingly for future reference 		 15.08.2025 16.01.2026 16.01.2026 0 Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Deutsche Börse AG Stephan Schmidt Alba Kajtazi Denise Weigelt JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Facility Management Frankfurt (U) Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF) asset management database may expose the company to operational risk due to incomplete and inaccurate asset information in the financial ledger. Therefore, it could lead to over- or underestimated balance sheet positions and result in material financial or reputational damage. Stephan Schmidt DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG) Obsolete - Complexity/ Volume of operations/ Pressure
2025-046_F13 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F13-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S1 Missing APMS registration of legal entities using PwC Connect (AID1053) PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) used a PwC IT solution (PwC Connect, AID1053) for a secure exchange of data with customers, particularly for the annual audit process. Thus, this external tool was used by almost all DBG legal entities. 

Internal Audit identified the in-scope legal entities were not listed as users in the APMS IT asset management system, except LuxCSD. The missing registration through the local IT coordinators resulted in incomplete information security risk assessment and information classification by the legal entity information owners.

According to the external and internal requirements, the organization must have an overview of IT assets and include them in the regular risk management process.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Internal Audit recommends that CRIT Information Security Office (RIT) perform the IT application onboarding for PwC Connect (AID1053) for ECAG as using legal entity including the information classification. 15.08.2025 28.11.2025 30.04.2026 25.09.2025 1 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit Eurex Clearing AG Celia Hollbach Aleksandra Galaganova Denise Weigelt CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) MANFRED MATUSZA CIO / COO (Div) Clearing and Risk IT (Dpt) Manfred Matusza CRIT Information Security Office (U) CRIT Information Security Office (RIT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. This represents a minor violation of internal and/or external provisions and negligible breach of regulatory requirements.
