Daniel Besse CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness
2025-047_F01 2025 2025-047 Billing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-047_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the Billing process stemming from systematic ineffic and insuffic data quality Internal Audit (IA) identified recurring and systematic inefficiencies in billing processes within Revenue Management (ZHV), stemming from multiple operational factors. These patterns (e.g., data quality issues) were observed across three billing areas, Revenue Management Clearstream (FSS), Revenue Management Cash Market (BCM) and Revenue Management Derivatives Market (FCF), and aimed to be corrected on a monthly basis.

There were persistent quality issues in billing input data delivered to Revenue Management (ZHV) from various outsourcers’ delivery systems and business applications managed by different operational functions. Namely, 66% of all recorded billing errors during the audit period (972 out of 1,465 errors) were related to quality of delivered data (system data delivery, business data delivery and processing):
§ 46 errors in Revenue Management Cash Market (BCM).
§ 745 errors in Revenue Management Derivatives Market (FCF), out of which 316 errors were due to late data delivery followed by daily manual re-processing.
§ 181 errors in Revenue Management Clearstream (FSS).
The majority of these errors were detected by the internal control system of Revenue Management (ZHV) prior to invoice creation. Nevertheless, it was not always possible to avoid a negative impact on customer invoices. This holds especially true for wrong securities master data.

Persistent billing errors resulted in significant manual work in processing invoice and credit note reimbursements, and corrections were performed on a "best-efforts basis", once ZHV detected individual issues. However, this case-by-case approach did not address the root cause leading to persistent issues. Moreover, the billing cycle’s limited timeframe significantly constrained ZHV’s ability to effectively identify and correct detected underlying data errors. This resulted in the following:
§ Approximately 27% of Clearstream reimbursements from January 2024 to February 2025 stemmed from poor data quality, from either delivery systems/customer master data or implementation errors, specifically missed impact/assessments. Further, as of April 1, 2025, ZHV faced an eight-month and 1,212 invoice/credit note backlog. This was mostly caused by a revised fee reimbursement process taken over by ZHV. IA acknowledges that as of September 2025, the backlog had been resolved.
§ More than 90 Clearstream-related claims totaling EUR 20 m were paid during the audit period. Including a substantial Bundesbank claim of EUR 4 m and another significant single-client EUR 1.2 m claim.
§ EUR 22,000 undercharges and EUR 82,000 overcharges relevant only for Derivatives Market (ECAG).

To identify systematic errors and measure process effectiveness and efficiency in all three billing areas, ZHV implemented the error list-based monthly Billing Operations KPI reporting. With respect to this centrally prepared ZHV KPI reporting, IA noted that:
§ Process efficiency, as measured through the “Quality of Delivered Data” operational KPI, was impaired as the KPI was breached for 22 months during the 24-month audit period (18 months as Red and 4 months as Amber).
§ KPI reports did not fully reflect the extent and impact of inadequate data quality since reported breaches did not include all units, identified errors, sales organizations and financial impacts.
§ KPI reports served only as an internal tracking tool and were not used to increase senior management’s oversight over billing data issues and accompanying risks. Also, there was no holistic error analysis in place aimed at identifying recurring data quality issues with the highest impact and risks, their source, raising management’s awareness and ultimately defining comprehensive mitigation measures.

IA acknowledges that ZHV implemented the following:
§ ZHV follows the Group-wide Control over Financial Reporting (CoFR) policy by addressing errors to the business and/or IT owners, who are responsible for the delivered data, and requesting confirmation that they have internal controls over correctness, completeness and timeliness of data delivery. However, IA noted that this policy is only effective within the CFO area and does not entail any assessment of operating effectiveness of internal controls managed by Process Operators. Taking into account the known weaknesses in DBG’s current ICS Framework, the practical value of CoFR is very limited and does not significantly facilitate in enhancing the quality of data used by Revenue Management in billing processes.
§ Internal controls and regular communication (mostly IT tickets, emails and meetings) with responsible parties (delivery applications’ business and/or IT owners) to address identified billing errors.
§ JIRA-based error list creation, to harmonize error handling across ZHV and avoid double maintenance/reporting. Corporate IT was expected to deliver it in Q3 2025.
§ AI solution for anomalies detection of securities master data (an error which cannot be identified by a standard internal control system) in the Revenue Management Clearstream unit to support manual efforts in identifying data discrepancies since April 2025. However, while AI has improved error detection, it has also increased the volume of identified discrepancies — resulting in a higher workload and more corrections required.

External and internal provisions require that robust data management frameworks be established including data quality controls. Fees should also be fair and reasonable, calculations transparent and invoices based on accurate data. Institutions should maintain adequate arrangements, safeguards and controls to ensure an effective internal control system and risk management.		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. § Conduct a comprehensive analysis of billing errors across all three billing areas to identify high-impact recurring issues, tracking them to the primary business sourcesand impacted Legal Entities, with focus on quality of delivered data.
§ Explore digital solutions for error detection in Clearstream, Cash and Derivatives Market billing to improve efficiency and accuracy.
§ Strengthen governance and improve accountability by implementing cohesive oversight, timely senior management escalation of identified and recurring issues as well as transparent regular reporting via complete and accurate KPI and other targeted reports.		 21.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Wolfgang Gerstner Christine Twomey Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Revenue Management (S) Revenue Management (ZHV) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.

 

ZHV will implement the legal entity-specific reporting for Order-to-Cash process errors identified by the billing application, while emphasizing that the root cause analysis and resolution of errors originating from delivery applications remain the responsibility of the respective business and/or IT teams accountable for the data. Moreover, Finance Governance & Controls will activate their 2nd line of defense function in 2026 by reviewing the Internal Control System (ICS) of delivery applications. It is expected that weaknesses in the respective delivery applications’ ICS will be identified and mitigated, leading to improved data quality. The same is expected from the roll-out of the group wide data governance approach. 		 Weaknesses in the Billing process stemming from systematic inefficiencies and insufficient data quality lead to incorrect billing of customers and non-transparent fee calculations. This may cause material revenue losses, inaccurate financial reporting, inadequate VAT handling, both internal and external reporting as well as material reputational damage. These represent non-compliance with regulatory requirements potentially resulting in regulatory examinations and penalties.   Wolfgang Gerstner ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Europe AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Data Quality and IT Infrastructure CSDR 34
2025-047_F02 2025 2025-047 Billing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-047_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in the master data change process Internal Audit (IA) identified several internal control weaknesses in the execution and oversight of Master Data Maintenance (ZCD) processes across customer and product domains:

- Non-adherence to standardized request channels: relevant business teams must initiate Customer Master Data (CMD) and Clearstream Customer Master Data (CBI) change requests directly via the Master Data Governance (MDG) tool. IA was, however, informed that approximately 10% of CMD and CBI change requests were initiated via email rather than MDG. In these cases, ZCD receives email requests and subsequently creates the change requests in MDG on behalf of the business teams.

- Inadequate Review and Approval Workflows: IA identified deficiencies in how Product Master Data (PMD)change requests were handled. ZCD was only expected to implement changes after the request had been reviewed by another requesting team member. Upon original request modification, ZCD should request an additional four-eyes review from the requesting team. Out of a sample of 25 PMD change requests, 2 were not adequately reviewed upon amendment. 

- Lack of Oversight on IT-Executed Changes via Elevated Access: in exceptional cases, customer and product master data changes were executed by IT intervention using Firefighter IDs. While IT had a robust review process, ZCD lacked a formalized mechanism to track, review, or reconcile these changes and ensure no unauthorized changes have been made to master data.

External regulations and internal provisions require organizations to maintain transparent and controlled data governance processes, ensuring proper documentation and accountability for data changes. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Update relevant product master data internal procedures and manuals to explicitly define the criteria for valid four-eyes principle reviews, including handling of post-review amendments for master data from the requestor, investigate technical options to prevent post-review amendments;

Implement a formalized process to track, review and reconcile executed firefighter ID customer and product master data changes in production;

Establish a monitoring process to ensure no unauthorized changes took place using Firefighter IDs. 		 21.10.2025 15.06.2026 15.06.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Peter Bado Uzair Zubair Inamdar Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Master Data Maintenance (U) Master Data Maintenance (ZCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Deficiencies in the master data change process compromise the integrity, traceability, and governance of master data changes. These weaknesses increase the likelihood of inaccurate entries, unauthorized modifications, and undocumented actions. These systemic gaps in process discipline and control elevate the risk of data integrity breaches, regulatory non-compliance, and operational inefficiencies. Lack of robust documentation and oversight mechanisms creates latent vulnerabilities that could result in minor financial impact, reputational concerns, and difficulties in demonstrating control effectiveness during internal or external audits.  Peter Bado ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Europe AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities
2025-047_F02 2025 2025-047 Billing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-047_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in the master data change process Internal Audit (IA) identified several internal control weaknesses in the execution and oversight of Master Data Maintenance (ZCD) processes across customer and product domains:

- Non-adherence to standardized request channels: relevant business teams must initiate Customer Master Data (CMD) and Clearstream Customer Master Data (CBI) change requests directly via the Master Data Governance (MDG) tool. IA was, however, informed that approximately 10% of CMD and CBI change requests were initiated via email rather than MDG. In these cases, ZCD receives email requests and subsequently creates the change requests in MDG on behalf of the business teams.

- Inadequate Review and Approval Workflows: IA identified deficiencies in how Product Master Data (PMD)change requests were handled. ZCD was only expected to implement changes after the request had been reviewed by another requesting team member. Upon original request modification, ZCD should request an additional four-eyes review from the requesting team. Out of a sample of 25 PMD change requests, 2 were not adequately reviewed upon amendment. 

- Lack of Oversight on IT-Executed Changes via Elevated Access: in exceptional cases, customer and product master data changes were executed by IT intervention using Firefighter IDs. While IT had a robust review process, ZCD lacked a formalized mechanism to track, review, or reconcile these changes and ensure no unauthorized changes have been made to master data.

External regulations and internal provisions require organizations to maintain transparent and controlled data governance processes, ensuring proper documentation and accountability for data changes. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. - Revoke the requestor role for the Master Data Governance (MDG) tool from all ZCD team members to ensure only authorized business teams can initiate change requests;
- Update relevant internal procedures and manuals to define the ZCD team members’ roles and responsibilities in the MDG process;
- Implement an IIQ recertification process for ZCD team members.		 21.10.2025 15.05.2026 15.05.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Peter Bado Uzair Zubair Inamdar Elizaveta Veselova JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Master Data Maintenance (U) Master Data Maintenance (ZCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Deficiencies in the master data change process compromise the integrity, traceability, and governance of master data changes. These weaknesses increase the likelihood of inaccurate entries, unauthorized modifications, and undocumented actions. These systemic gaps in process discipline and control elevate the risk of data integrity breaches, regulatory non-compliance, and operational inefficiencies. Lack of robust documentation and oversight mechanisms creates latent vulnerabilities that could result in minor financial impact, reputational concerns, and difficulties in demonstrating control effectiveness during internal or external audits.  Peter Bado ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Europe AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities

2025-048_F01 2025 2025-048 IT Network Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-048_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Submitted for Completion by Auditor S2 Incomplete configuration of compliance checks in SolarWinds For the SolarWinds Orion4 (AID974), which checks network device configurations against the baseline, Internal Audit identified incomplete configuration of compliance checks as well as incomplete definition in the underlying baseline, namely:

The Network Security baseline for all network devices was last updated in December 2023 and therefore was outdated. The baseline-owner, Vulnerability Management (VLM), has already planned a review and update.

Mandatory (M) and Best Practices (BP) baselines for CheckPoint GAIA5 (GAIA baseline, chapter 5.1) were defined in the baseline document. According to auditee, IT Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) was not requested by the baseline owner to implement the SolarWinds’s PROD-compliance check for CheckPoint GAIA.

Some baseline requirements related to password expiration, e.g. FWCP1.5, FWCP1.7, were not implemented. According to auditee, the implementation would have caused operational issues.

Certain GAIA-related baselines were not marked as M or BP at all. Exceptions (GAIA baseline requirements not implemented) were not raised and therefore not managed as a risk.

The baseline did not clearly define and distinguish between “must”, “should”, “optional” and “best practice”.

According to the baseline, “all the criteria must be met, and a clear justification for any exceptions will have to be provided. This applied both to Mandatory criteria and to criteria marked as Best Practice”. BP baselines were understood only as optional, not implemented and not documented as an exception.

Even though some BP baselines were listed in the SolarWinds PROD-rules as a compliance-rule, the rule was empty and set as placeholder. This applied to several network assets listed in the Baseline document, such as CheckPoint, Cisco ASR, Cisco FTD, Hirschman Switch, Metamako Switch.

In the timeframe of the audit-closure, Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) removed all empty or placeholder rules in production.

A four-eyes control, implemented to remediate the S2 finding “2021-044_F02” in “2021-044 IT Infrastructure audit”, was designed, implemented, and operated by Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) as ‘Rule Implementer’ and involved the ‘Baseline Owner’ as counterpart. The control was only executed once by all parties involved. By now the process is implemented manually without automated interfaces.

Even though firewalls operating on GAIA-OS6 were not integrated in the compliance checks, baseline requirements were generally considered and implemented on production devices.

IA’s sample testing noted minor implementation deviations to baseline FWCP3.13 (Firewall_secure_settings), which could have been identified when properly integrated in the configuration compliance check. For example, device csffbu19-fo is set to issue an alert when disk is below 3000MB (local storage), and device cxfkxxd8 is set for an alert when disk is below 5% of local storage.

 

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require that organizations implement and maintain effective, continuous compliance monitoring controls – such as properly configured tools like SolarWinds – to detect, report, and respond to security and policy violations in a timely manner. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Based on the revised baseline document to be established in action A01, Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Corporate IT Tools (ZFL)
§ Implement requirements as per revised Baseline, in particular requirements focusing on CheckPoint devices.
§ Ensure the four-eyes control is performed as designed.		 25.06.2025 31.10.2025 31.10.2025 21.10.2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ralf Wießner Frank Ackermann Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Infrastructure Service Tools (U) Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Incomplete configuration of compliance checks in SolarWinds may lead to undetected policy violations and delayed response to security issues, increasing the risk of non-compliance and operational exposure, resulting in:

Minor breach of regulatory requirements (e.g. non-existent description/ documentation of processes and/ or control environment)

Incomplete or non-compliant security configurations and hardening settings of applications and underlying network devices protecting ICT assets

Not meeting regulatory and internal requirements. 		 Ralf Wießner CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-048_F06 2025 2025-048 IT Network Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-048_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Operating of end-of-support network devices Internal Audit recommends that Network Security & Services (INN) decommission the out-of-support device as scheduled.  Control Env. + Control Op.Eff. Internal Audit (IA) identified that two out of the twelve Cisco network models were out of vendor support. Throughout this audit, one of the Cisco models was fully decommissioned.

The remaining one, which was used internally for management purposes, was scheduled for decommissioning by the end of 2025. As a result of this audit, a risk was recorded in the VMT security risk inventory.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require that organizations maintain up-to-date and supported network infrastructure to ensure effective cybersecurity, minimize vulnerabilities and comply with operational resilience and risk management obligations.		 25.06.2025 16.01.2026 16.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Constantin Pop Volker Scheer Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Network Security & Services (U) Network Security & Services (INN) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Operating of end-of-support network devices carries the risk that, in the event of a security incident, no patches will be provided to address vulnerabilities. However, this risk is mitigated as the respective devices are located in a segregated Network Operations Center management network secured by firewalls and with very restricted access. This situation constitutes a minor non-compliance with both internal and external requirements. Constantin Pop CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Complexity/ Volume of operations/ Pressure
2025-049_F01 2025 2025-049 OTC Processing (ECAG) 2025-049_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of ongoing Sanctions Screening for OTC Trade Venues Internal Audit identified that OTC Trade Venues used by Eurex Clearing AG (ECAG) were not subject to daily economic and financial sanctions screening.
ECAG had ten OTC Trade Venues onboarded in order to clear Interest Rate Swaps, Overnight Index Swaps, Inflation Swaps and Forward Rate Agreements trades. The designed process did not include process steps and controls to enter the minimum necessary data on these venues (e.g. name, country of origin, address) into any IT application connected to STOP application (AID052).  Therefore, OTC Trade Venues were not subject to daily sanctions screening against up-to-date sanctions lists (e.g. Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC), European Union, United Nations).
The risk is partially mitigated as OTC Clearing Design (OCL) performed a biennially control (AML and Sanctions) over OTC Trade Venues via WebChecks (component within AID052 STOP application) in April 2025 with no triggered alert. Additionally, the number of OTC Trade Venues onboarded was limited and stable to only ten Trade Venues.

DBG Sanctions Policy defined in chapter 3 that DBG has a strict, conservative approach to sanctions compliance and sanctions risks.  DBG and its LEs will not engage in any transactions or dealings that are prohibited under applicable sanctions.		 Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Internal Audit recommends that OTC Clearing Design (OCL) to:
§ Define in business procedures Access Request Process - Trading Venues for OTC Business and Informal Access Request Process - Trading Venues for OTC Business the process of entering minimum required data regarding OTC Trade Venues in IT application.
§ For existing ten onboarded OTC Trade Venues enter minimum required data in IT application connected to STOP tool (AID052) in order to provide regular (daily) economic and financial sanctions screening.		 28.07.2025 15.10.2025 28.11.2025 12.09.2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Michael Hildebrand Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij OTC Clearing Design (U) OTC Clearing Design (OCL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of ongoing Sanctions Screening for OTC Trade Venues exposed the company to the risk of engaging with the trade venue that was sanctioned. As sanction packages are updated daily by different regulators and regimes, there is a risk that on a certain date a trade venue is added on a sanction list without ECAG being aware and capturing it. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions and could have material adverse regulatory and reputational impact in case ECAG engages with sanctioned parties. Michael Hildebrand JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Processes Dependency on other Team(s), SME, Consultants, External Find The finding will be addressed on a global level, rather than working on a manual fix for this particular case. Hence, we request some more time. 
2025-053_F01 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Incorrect reporting of thresholds for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” The risk metric value for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” reached 20.94% in Q3 2024, which is below the early warning threshold of 21% as reported within the quarterly risk management report for Q3 2024. Upon inquiries with the indicator owner Supervisory Reporting Germany (FCL), it was confirmed that the applicable early warning threshold was 19.44% when the risk metric value for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” reached 20.94%. Therefore, indicator breach did not occur.
Internal Audit (IA) noted that the thresholds were determined by Capital Planning Unit, and they can change over time due to the dynamic nature of certain components of the calculation. However, IA identified that the line of communication between Capital Planning (BLL) and Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) was not clear.
Although the thresholds were updated in Q2 2024, UIY did not reflect the updates in the quarterly risk reports, hence the thresholds used for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” in Q3 2024, Q4 2024 and Q1 2025 quarterly risk reporting were inaccurate.

MaRisk BT 3.1.1 refers that risk reports should be based on complete, precise and current data.		 Control Operating Effectiveness Establish and maintain a clear line of communication between the responsible units setting the risk appetite thresholds and Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) to ensure alignment and accuracy in the reporting of thresholds. 02.10.2025 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Cesar Matos Emirhan Uysal Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incorrect reporting of thresholds for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” may lead to misinformed risk oversight and decision-making, potentially undermining the accuracy of capital adequacy monitoring. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions in case there is unclear communication line which can cause incorrect reporting toward Executive Board. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-053_F02 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inconsistencies between the defined and reported Risk Appetite thresholds Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Risk Appetite Framework, and the thresholds defined for each relevant risk metric. The thresholds set within the Risk Appetite Framework were compared against the thresholds reported within Q1 2025 Risk Management Report (as the Risk Appetite Framework was approved in January 2025). The following inconsistencies were identified:
§ For the Risk Metric "Cover-2 stress test (ST) requirement to Default Fund (in %)" both the Amber Threshold and Red Threshold were presented as ">100%" within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025. Risk Appetite Framework determined the amber threshold level at ">90%". The thresholds reported within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025 were the latest approved thresholds at the time of the reporting. However, those latest approved thresholds were not reflected in the Risk Appetite Framework.
§ For the Risk Metric "Economic Liquidity Ratio", Amber Threshold and Red Thresholds were presented as <180% and <120%, respectively, within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025. The thresholds reported within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025 were the latest approved thresholds at the time of the reporting. However, those latest approved thresholds were not reflected in the Risk Appetite Framework. Such thresholds per Risk Appetite Framework were determined as <215% and <150%. Such inaccuracy in this ratio applied to all the following risk clusters: Funding/Refinancing Risk, Illiquidity Risk, Intraday Liquidity Risk. Furthermore, for “Economic Liquidity Ratio”, the limits in RAF not only differed from those in Q1 Risk Management Report but also from those in Liquidity Indicator Concept and ILAAP handbook.
§ Red threshold defined in Risk Appetite Framework for Risk Metric "Number of introduced operational tax-relevant products / services / functionalities which were not subject to upfront operational tax analysis" (equal or more than 2 topics identified before launch or 1 topic identified after launched service) was inconsistent with the red threshold defined in Q1 2025 Quarterly Risk Management Reporting for the risk (equal or more than 3 topics identified before launch or 1 topic identified after launched service).

UIY already identified other inconsistencies during the Quarterly Risk Report re-design in Q1 2025 in the transition phase and these were discussed and addressed to the ECAG Chief Risk Officer. However, the abovementioned inconsistencies identified by IA were not captured by UIY.

MaRisk AT 5 explains that the institution must ensure that its business activities are conducted based on organizational guidelines (e.g. manuals, work documentation or workflow procedures).		 Control Operating Effectiveness Ensure that the thresholds reported to the Executive Board are fully aligned with those defined in the Risk Appetite Framework. In cases where thresholds are revised during the year, promptly update the Risk Appetite Framework to reflect the most current values and maintain consistency across all reporting documents. 02.10.2025 15.06.2026 15.06.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Cesar Matos Emirhan Uysal Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inconsistencies between the Risk Appetite Framework and the quarterly Risk Management Reports pose a risk of misinformed decision-making, as inaccurate thresholds may lead to incorrect assessments of risk levels, delayed escalation, and potential breaches of the organization's defined risk appetite. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions in case there is inaccurate information presented to the Executive Board. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Data Quality and IT Infrastructure
2025-053_F03 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inconsistencies in the ECAG ILAAP process documentation Internal Audit (IA) identified the following inconsistencies within ECAG ILAAP Handbook:
§ In Chapter 1.3 “Regulatory Background” reference was made to an outdated version of MaRisk.
§ In Chapter 2.2 “ILAAP Governance and Responsibilities” the responsibility for the Liquidity Stress Test (LST) was wrongly allocated to Risk Analytics (DRA) in Models & Analytics (DCX) Section. As of the beginning of 2025 the responsibility lay with Financial Risk (FRM) Unit in Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) Section.
§ In Chapter 2.6 “ILAAP Documentation Framework” the use of the term “Liquidity Indicator Report” was outdated as it is now the “Liquidity Risk Report”. Furthermore, the Ownership of LST (documentation) was not correct anymore as the ownership was transferred from DCX to UIY at the beginning of 2025 (see above).
§ In Chapter 6.1 “Risk Identification at ECAG”, it was stated that the risk inventory implicitly defines the risk appetite. According to ERM, however, in the Risk Appetite Framework only all the material risk clusters from the Risk Inventory were considered, while no implication regarding the risk appetite per risk cluster was made.
§ In Chapter 7.1 “Funding Plan” the projection of balance sheet items was based on figures from the end of 2022.
§ In the Liquidity Indicator Concept the amber limit of “Own Funds” was defined as EMIR Capital Requirements + SITG + SSITG - 200mn. In Chapter 8.2 of the ECAG ILAAP Handbook, however, it was only stated EMIR Capital Requirements + SITG + SSITG, which is the correct calculation according to UIY. While the ECAG ILAAP Handbook referred to the Liquidity Indicator Concept for the newest limits, it showed the correct limit calculation, and the Liquidity Indicator Concept was outdated.
§ In Chapter 11, the listed monthly Stress Testing Report from DRA was canceled by the end of 2024 and is no longer in place. Information on the LST was now included in the monthly Liquidity Risk Report. Furthermore, within the list the new reporting duty of UIY in form of the quarterly Risk Management Report starting as of beginning of 2025 was missing.

However, UIY confirmed that changes in organizational structure of ECAG would not trigger ad-hoc review of business procedures but would rather trigger qualitative element of assessing if ad-hoc update is necessary.

The information in the ECAG ILAAP Handbook should be complete, up-to-date and correct. The defined regular review and update process, at least on an annual basis, and whenever the circumstances would require should be followed.		 Control Design Effectiveness Update the ILAAP Handbook so that it represents all aspects of ECAG’s ILAAP in a clear, up-to-date, and complete way. 02.10.2025 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Cesar Matos Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inconsistencies in the ECAG ILAAP process documentation exposed the company to the risk of operational errors in case of outdated/inaccurate business procedures.
This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions in case policies are not updated swiftly in the event of significant changes.		 Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines
2025-053_F04 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inadequate explanation of the risk materiality assessment Internal Audit (IA) noted, based on the explanation provided by the Enterprise Risk Management (UIY), that although the gross approach was applied in the determination of risk materiality for Wrong-Way Credit Risk, the explanation as provided within the Risk Materiality Assessment was not clear enough for an independent eye as it referred to mitigating factors which could be perceived as “net approach”.
Namely, IA noted that the qualitative materiality assessment carried out for Wrong-Way Credit Risk was referring to strong concentration and wrong way risk policies as mitigating factors for the risk, with the help of various limits which are continuously monitored and reported by the first line of defense.
Auditees also explained that the materiality assessment carried out for Wrong-Way Credit Risk stemmed from the “Additionally Monitored Risk Framework”, which essentially lays out Eurex Clearing’s framework to identify, assess, monitor, mitigate and report credit concentration and wrong way risks.
Upon inquiries, it was confirmed by the auditees that the Wrong-Way Credit Risk is already prevented at the level of 1st Line of Defense, given there is no appetite for taking the Wrong-Way Credit Risk. Therefore, by nature, mitigating factors were not considered in the materiality assessment for such risk.

DBG Group Risk Management Procedure notes that the materiality assessment should be performed on the gross approach. Therefore, risk mitigating measures should not be considered when assessing the materiality of the Risk Cluster. Application of gross approach is also explained within ECB Guide to the ICAAP as follows: “Under the gross approach, risks are first identified without considering specific techniques designed to mitigate them. A risk could be regarded as material if its materialization, omission or misstatement would significantly change or influence the capital adequacy, profitability, or continuity of the institution from an economic perspective, irrespective of the accounting treatment applied.”		 Control Operating Effectiveness Update the qualitative materiality assessment to remove references to mitigating measures, ensuring it clearly reflects that the assessment is based on the gross approach. 02.10.2025 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Cesar Matos Emirhan Uysal Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UYI) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate explanation of the risk materiality assessment may convey a misleading message, potentially resulting in the incorrect application of DBG Group Risk Management Procedure and the ECB Guide to the ICAAP. This represents a minor violation of internal provisions in case of insufficiently documenting the risk assessments. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-053_F05 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Incomplete ILAAP documentation of compliance with MaRisk requirements Although ILAAP is mostly in line with regulatory requirements, some MaRisk requirements have not been fully met.
In MaRisk BTR 3.1, paragraph 8, the determination of a survival horizon for stress scenarios was explicitly required. ECAG did not explicitly report the expected survival horizon, but it was indirectly calculated as part of the Liquidity Stress Testing application. All stress scenarios had a maximum forecast horizon of 6 days aligned with the duration of ECAG's Default Management process (maximum Margin Period of Risk (MPOR) = five plus one day as some liquidity flows would be due on the morning after the last day of the MPOR). As ECAG was not exposed to additional material risks from term-transformations, ECAG assumed the survival horizon was infinite in all cases where liquidity was sufficient to survive the first six days after a Clearing Member default. In the (theoretical) case that a stress testing scenario would result in a liquidity shortfall, the expected survival horizon was the first day within the six-day forecast horizon where the liquidity balance of his scenario sheet would show a gap. 
However, the aforementioned considerations regarding compliance with the regulatory requirements of MaRisk were not documented or formally recorded. Furthermore, although the information on the survival horizon could be derived and reported from the stress testing scenario output data, this was not done yet.		 Control Design Effectiveness Update documentation so that all considerations regarding compliance with the regulatory requirements of MaRisk are recorded. 02.10.2025 15.01.2026 15.01.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Melih Iyigün, Cesar Matos Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ILAAP documentation of compliance with MaRisk requirements exposed the company to the risk of inability to show compliance with regulatory requirements in case compliance was not formally documented.
This represents a minor violation of internal or external provisions in case business procedures are not updated to formally regulatory requirements.		 Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines
2025-060_F01 2025 2025-060 Collateral Services (ECAG) 2025-060_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inaccurate collateral fee allocation and outdated process documentation The Collateral Fee Report is prepared monthly by the Pricing (PCD) unit to provide a comprehensive overview of Total Collateral Income, Net Interest Income (NII), and Securities Collateral Fee revenues to the management. As part of this process, PCD allocates this collateral income to respective segments and products. This allocation data is then provided to the Group Reporting (ZCA) unit to enable the rebooking of collateral fee shares into SAP.

During the substantive testing of this process, Internal Audit (IA) noted that the collateral fees were incorrectly allocated to the respective segments/products and to the respective asset class since February 2024. This issue stemmed from a formula error where a static “OTC IRD Securities Collateral Fee Reallocation” percentage from January 2024 was incorrectly used for all subsequent monthly calculations, i.e., the formula was not updated to reflect the correct percentage for each respective month. This error was not detected during the established preventive control, herein the four-eyes principle, and as a result, incorrect allocations were sent each month to ZCA for rebooking in SAP. Specifically,
§ For the samples selected for testing (August 2024, December 2024, March 2025 and June 2025), the total collateral income and total security collateral fees were incorrectly allocated to the respective segments/products and to the respective asset class.
§ For March 2025 and June 2025, due to report restructuring, the incorrect calculation further led to incorrect allocation of total security collateral fees for Fixed Income Derivatives between STIR Derivatives and Credit Index Derivatives.
§ Within the Fee Allocation tab of the August 2024 Masterfile, the total collateral revenue was incorrectly stated and misallocated due to the underlying calculation errors.

Moreover, the following deficiencies were noted in the Monthly Collateral Fee Reporting procedure:
§ It was outdated and did not reflect the current and more comprehensive management report that was introduced in early 2025. It failed to describe the restructured report, which now included more detailed insights, comparisons, and additional data points.
§ It incorrectly stated “CB230” as the input file for Delta to Benchmark calculations, while the correct source was “CD230”.

In line with European and German regulations, all institutions must conduct their business activities based on the established organizational guidelines, such as manuals or work process descriptions. These organizational guidelines must be designed with sufficient clarity and detail to enable the Internal Audit department to perform its substantive audit procedures.		 Control Environment § update and rectify the formula error in the Collateral Fee Reporting model to ensure calculations and allocations are accurate for each reporting period
§ reinforce the four-eyes review process by implementing a mandatory checklist for the review, which shall include verifying critical formulas and input data
§ establish two distinct, comprehensive and updated business procedures for:
- collateral fee reporting to the management
- allocation of collateral income between segments/products for SAP Booking
§ reflect the two established business procedures as two distinct processes in the Governance, Risk & Compliance (GRC) Internal Control System (ICS) and the Risk Control Matrix		 31.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Philippe Schwarz Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Pricing (U) Pricing (PCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inaccurate collateral fee allocation and outdated process documentation could lead to inaccurate management reporting and potentially misstated financial records in SAP. This represents a material gap in internal and external provisions, such as minor breach of regulatory requirements. Philippe Schwarz JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-060_F03 2025 2025-060 Collateral Services (ECAG) 2025-060_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Omission of Security Eligibility Assessment process from Organization and Process Structure Report During the review of the Organization and Process Structure Report, Process Map and the Risk Control Matrix (RCM), Internal Audit noted that the “SP_ECAG_CO_7.15 Security Eligibility Assessment” subprocess, performed by the Default Management (DME) unit, was omitted from the organization and process structure report and process map. Consequently, the risks and controls for this subprocess were not documented in the RCM.

In line with internal provisions, business process maps should accurately document all key subprocesses, and the corresponding Risk Control Matrix should identify and define the risks and controls associated with each of these subprocesses to ensure a complete and effective control environment.		 Control Environment § update the relevant Organization and Process Structure Report and Process Map to include the “SP_ECAG_CO_7.15_Security Eligibility Assessment” subprocess
§ conduct a formal risk assessment of this subprocess to identify its inherent risks
§ update the corresponding Risk Control Matrix (RCM) to document these risks and the controls designed to mitigate them		 31.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Andreas Pistohl Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Default Management (U) Default Management (DME) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Omission of Security Eligibility Assessment process from Process Map and Risk Control Matrix could lead to inadequate documentation of risks and related controls, as these are not transparently captured. This represents a material gap in internal and external provisions, such as minor breach of regulatory requirements. Andreas Pistohl DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Lack of Awareness
2025-060_F04 2025 2025-060 Collateral Services (ECAG) 2025-060_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Deficiencies in the Collateral Clearing on Behalf business procedure During the review of 7.2.6.1.4 Collateral Clearing on Behalf business procedure, Internal Audit (IA) noted the following deficiencies:
§ Step 3 in the documented business procedure incorrectly referenced Step 7 for the process steps regarding requests related to LSOC functionalities. These were described in Step 10 and onwards.
§ The business procedure was outdated as Step 14 required retaining screenshots of the “C7 CMS Collateral Transaction Overview” or “Collateral Transaction Details” as evidence, but these were not necessary as the system records an audit trail with the necessary transaction information.
 
In line with European and German regulations, all institutions must conduct their business activities based on the established organizational guidelines, such as manuals or work process descriptions  		 Control Design Effectiveness § update the reference in Step 3 for the process steps regarding requests related to LSOC functionalities
§ update Step 14 to reflect the most updated documentation of relevant activities for collateral releases		 31.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Paul Lilwall Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Change Management (U) Change Management (DDL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in the Collateral Clearing on Behalf business procedure represent a minor breach of regulatory requirements and internal provisions with a negligible financial impact. Paul Lilwall JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission
2025-061_F01 2025 2025-061 Stress Testing (ECAG) 2025-061_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Clearing Member provided more than 25% of all committed credit lines Internal Audit (IA) noted that for the month of January 2025, capped amount for the committed credit lines from DZ Bank was €333m, which was 27% of the sum of committed credit lines of €1,228m. Therefore, the 25% limit was breached.

Upon inquiries, auditees confirmed that their calculation of the concentration also considered the available FX Swap lines with Toronto Dominion Bank, hence per their methodology, the credit line with DZ Bank remained below 25% limit. Given EMIR is not 100% clear on which kind of credit lines should be included, the FX swap lines were included in the concentration capping algorithm some years ago. However, the methodology applied is not consistent with the requirements set out within the Methodology Concept.

EMIR Article 44 defines that one Clearing Member (group) may only provide 25% of all committed credit lines considered in the regulatory required scenarios, in particular within the control relevant Cover-2 scenario. Thus, the amounts of the credit lines may need to be capped for Liquidity Stress Testing, depending on the overall amount of available committed credit lines provided by Clearing Members.

Liquidity Stress Testing – Methodology Concept Chapter 3.2.1 explains that “the maximum amount considered per single commercial bank is 25% of the total committed uncollateralized credit lines. If a single commercial bank provides more than 25% of the overall uncollateralized credit lines, the exceeding amount is excluded in the liquidity stress testing calculation”.		 Control Design Effectiveness Align the calculation methodology applied with the Methodology Concept documentation and exclude FX swap lines from the concentration capping.  30.10.2025 15.07.2026 15.07.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Ivan Madaras Emirhan Uysal Markus Messerer THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Financial Risk (U) Financial Risk Unit (FRM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. A Clearing Member providing more than 25% of all committed credit lines considered in regulatory stress testing scenarios contradicts both regulatory expectations and internal methodology requirements, which may compromise the reliability and integrity of Liquidity Stress Testing results. Ivan Madaras DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls
2025-061_F02 2025 2025-061 Stress Testing (ECAG) 2025-061_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in General Controls Internal Audit (IA) noted the following weaknesses in general controls:

1. Incomplete Legal Inventory
IA identified completeness gaps in the Legal Inventory maintained within the Regulatory Monitoring Dashboard for Liquidity Stress Testing and Credit Stress Testing as follows. The relevant Legal Inventory Entry (LIE) references are provided below.

The subprocess “SP_ECAG_CT_1.4.4_Liquidity Risk” in relation to Liquidity Stress Testing is not linked to;

• Principle 7 of the CPSS-IOSCO Principles for Financial Market Infrastructures (PFMI) within LIE-1589,
• Article 32 and Article 54 of the EU Commission delegated Regulation (EU) No 153/2013 (‘ESMA RTS’) within LIE-4809, LIE-1606 and LIE-1205.

The subprocess “SP_ECAG_CO_10.1.2_Monitoring” in relation to Credit Stress Testing is not linked to;

• Article 42 of the Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 4 July 2012 (‘EMIR’) within LIE-1413,
• No Legal Inventory Entry is created for Article 43 of EMIR,
• Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Title 17 (CFTC regulations – Commodity and Securities Exchanges), Part 39 (Derivatives Clearing Organizations), § 39.11 (Financial resources) within LIE-5703.

2. Inconsistent references in documentation
IA noted that “To Does” section within MAN20 – Liquidity Stress Testing Manual for “Alignment on mobilization assumptions with DMP Team" explains that an e-mail is sent to “dmp_inbox@deutsche-boerse.com“ with “ERM@eurex.com“ in copy, which does not reflect the actual process flow. It is confirmed that the key contacts for this alignment are now the colleagues in the Credit Risk Management & Governance Unit rather than the Default Management Team (DMP).

Moreover, IA also identified following points for alignment within the documents relevant for Credit Stress Testing. Credit Risk Management Policy (the “CRMP”) does not reflect the following changes resulting from the reorganization of CCP Risk Management division (the “reorganization”) effective as of 1 January 2025:

• Credit, concentration and wrong way risk related topics were moved from Risk Analytics Unit to Credit Risk Management & Governance Unit,
• Development, maintenance and operational aspects of Liquidity Stress Testing were moved from Risk Analytics Unit to Financial Risk Unit,
• Operational aspects of Credit Stress Testing were moved from Risk Analytics Unit to Reporting & Data Quality Management Unit.
• Default Management Section was renamed to “Credit Risk & Default Management”		 Control Environment Review and update the:
• Legal Inventory items concerning Liquidity Stress Testing to ensure accurate mapping of all relevant legal and regulatory requirements to the applicable subprocesses,
• MAN20 – Liquidity Stress Testing Manual to ensure consistency, accuracy, and alignment with current internal procedures.		 30.10.2025 15.07.2026 15.07.2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Ivan Madaras Emirhan Uysal Markus Messerer THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Financial Risk (U) Financial Risk Unit (FRM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. 1. Incomplete Legal Inventory
Incomplete mapping of legal requirements in the Legal Inventory may lead to non-compliance with regulatory obligations, exposing the institution to legal, financial, and reputational risks.

2. Inconsistent references in documentation
Outdated or inaccurate documentation may lead to misaligned responsibilities and ineffective execution of critical risk management processes, increasing the risk of regulatory non-compliance and operational inefficiencies.		 Ivan Madaras DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls

2025-061_F02 2025 2025-061 Stress Testing (ECAG) 2025-061_F02-A03 Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in General Controls Internal Audit (IA) noted the following weaknesses in general controls:

1. Incomplete Legal Inventory
IA identified completeness gaps in the Legal Inventory maintained within the Regulatory Monitoring Dashboard for Liquidity Stress Testing and Credit Stress Testing as follows. The relevant Legal Inventory Entry (LIE) references are provided below.

2025-099_F01 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Absence of a comprehensive DBG data leakage prevention concept to protect critical data assets DBG lacks a data leakage prevention  (DLP) concept as foundation for structured, comprehensive and risk-based protection against data leakage. As a consequence, the measures to reduce data leakage risk implemented at DBG have not been derived from a defined DLP concept and, in their entirety, do not form an effective DLP capability.

Specifically, DBG failed to:
§ Establish DLP-specific data classification, especially defining and identifying its most critical data (“data crown jewels”). The way application-level information classification was implemented does not enable and support identification of “data crown jewels” in DBG. Also, it does not consider multiple possible criteria such as critical and important functions and competition-critical importance. Furthermore, existing document classification (labeling) measures are independent from data criticality and are not consistently enforced for manual processes involving data extracts such as IDPs.
§ Conduct a risk assessment to comprehensively define and identify data exfiltration points and establish leakage scenarios against which this data needs protection.
§ Define risk metrics/requirements catalogue for safeguarding data from being leaked depending on its criticality.
§ Determine suitable technical preventive controls based on a comprehensive DLP concept.
§ Implement effective oversight measures to monitor control effectiveness and detect breaches.

In detail, Internal Audit identified several gaps in data classification, safeguarding and data leakage risk management:

Data classification and safeguarding
§ DBG has not defined, identified, or inventoried its most sensitive data assets ("data crown jewels"). Also, there is no comprehensive requirements catalogue for safeguarding data from leakage based on criticality. This lack of a top-down approach prevents focused controls on the highest risks associated with potential data leakage of the most critical data.
§ The implemented information classification (bottom-up approach) did not result in a manageable scope of IT systems containing the most critical data. The information classification is not consistently derived from considerations of key dimensions e.g., critical and important functions, personally identifiable information (PII) or data supporting strategic decisions. As of July 1, 2025, 279 IT applications were classified with the highest confidentiality level (“critical”), requiring the strictest data leakage controls across a broad scope of targets.
§ 2LoD ICT Risk Management has not defined the information classification risk levels (Critical/Major/Minor/Negligible). These were only defined in the 1LoD (Group Security) written rules.

Data leakage risk management
§ The DLP control system lacks a foundation in a comprehensive, systematic, and documented risk assessment, failing to adequately address two key aspects:
- Data leakage paths: The current IT application-based risk assessment lacks a strategic DLP approach, resulting in incomplete identification and management of key data leakage risks. For example, some file types in use (e.g., .csv) lack classification requirements; email blocking controls are limited to Excel and strictly confidential files only and can easily be circumvented. See also finding 2025-099_F04 for further details.
- Data processing risks outside dedicated IT tools: Due to limited system functionality or lacking customer/service/user features, many business processes rely on manual data handling outside of dedicated IT tools e.g., within IDP’s. This lack of system integration prevents effective data flow controls, increasing the risk of errors and malicious activity, especially when data is shared externally via email. Also, reliance on IDP solutions and manual activities introduces an additional risk layer. Recent data leakage incidents demonstrated this, with IDP malfunction identified as one of the root causes. This lack of resilience and scalability creates multiple points of failure in the business processes, particularly under pressure. Strategic DLP approaches and risk assessments must specifically address these vulnerabilities.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require financial entities continuously identify all ICT risk sources. In accordance with their ICT risk management framework, they shall minimize the ICT risk impact by deploying appropriate strategies, policies, procedures, protocols and tools. Appropriate technical and organizational measures shall be implemented to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk. The IT systems, the related processes and other information domain elements shall ensure data confidentiality.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. With support from 1LoD business and Group Security (ZZA):

§ Conduct an end-to-end DLP risk assessment including identification and documentation of data leakage paths and related impact of potential data leakage, to identify what new controls are needed for which protection need and what existing controls need to be improved. This should include automated processes sending out emails via technical mailboxes or directly from the backend applications.
§ Determine suitable processes and technical preventive controls based on business definitions.
§ Implement effective oversight measures to monitor control effectiveness and detect breaches.
§ Update the IT asset risk assessment process to include the results of the DLP risk assessment.
§ Define and support implementation of a plan for assessment of manual data handling and external sharing processes which create the most significant impact on DLP risks. The goal is to identify possible enhancements, ideally systemic IT solutions which can be offered within DBG.		 16.10.2025 31.07.2026 31.07.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lars Bolanca Thomas Kemmerer Thomas Kemmerer HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT (A) Corporate IT (ITH) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Absence of a comprehensive DBG data leakage prevention (DLP) concept to protect critical data assets results in particularly serious weaknesses in the DLP internal control system. Without identification of “data crown jewels” and a comprehensive DLP risk assessment, DBG cannot effectively prevent data leakage, especially considering the reliance on non-standard IT processes for handling critical data. Consequences of such a breach could lead to long lasting negative publicity in international media, ad-hoc regulatory examinations, as well as critical financial impact in case of fines related to data breaches. Ultimately, this could result in the loss of client trust in DBG. Lars Bolanca ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy ,45,CSDR 909/2014
2025-099_F01 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Absence of a comprehensive DBG data leakage prevention concept to protect critical data assets DBG lacks a data leakage prevention  (DLP) concept as foundation for structured, comprehensive and risk-based protection against data leakage. As a consequence, the measures to reduce data leakage risk implemented at DBG have not been derived from a defined DLP concept and, in their entirety, do not form an effective DLP capability.

Specifically, DBG failed to:
§ Establish DLP-specific data classification, especially defining and identifying its most critical data (“data crown jewels”). The way application-level information classification was implemented does not enable and support identification of “data crown jewels” in DBG. Also, it does not consider multiple possible criteria such as critical and important functions and competition-critical importance. Furthermore, existing document classification (labeling) measures are independent from data criticality and are not consistently enforced for manual processes involving data extracts such as IDPs.
§ Conduct a risk assessment to comprehensively define and identify data exfiltration points and establish leakage scenarios against which this data needs protection.
§ Define risk metrics/requirements catalogue for safeguarding data from being leaked depending on its criticality.
§ Determine suitable technical preventive controls based on a comprehensive DLP concept.
§ Implement effective oversight measures to monitor control effectiveness and detect breaches.

In detail, Internal Audit identified several gaps in data classification, safeguarding and data leakage risk management:

Data classification and safeguarding
§ DBG has not defined, identified, or inventoried its most sensitive data assets ("data crown jewels"). Also, there is no comprehensive requirements catalogue for safeguarding data from leakage based on criticality. This lack of a top-down approach prevents focused controls on the highest risks associated with potential data leakage of the most critical data.
§ The implemented information classification (bottom-up approach) did not result in a manageable scope of IT systems containing the most critical data. The information classification is not consistently derived from considerations of key dimensions e.g., critical and important functions, personally identifiable information (PII) or data supporting strategic decisions. As of July 1, 2025, 279 IT applications were classified with the highest confidentiality level (“critical”), requiring the strictest data leakage controls across a broad scope of targets.
§ 2LoD ICT Risk Management has not defined the information classification risk levels (Critical/Major/Minor/Negligible). These were only defined in the 1LoD (Group Security) written rules.

Data leakage risk management
§ The DLP control system lacks a foundation in a comprehensive, systematic, and documented risk assessment, failing to adequately address two key aspects:
- Data leakage paths: The current IT application-based risk assessment lacks a strategic DLP approach, resulting in incomplete identification and management of key data leakage risks. For example, some file types in use (e.g., .csv) lack classification requirements; email blocking controls are limited to Excel and strictly confidential files only and can easily be circumvented. See also finding 2025-099_F04 for further details.
- Data processing risks outside dedicated IT tools: Due to limited system functionality or lacking customer/service/user features, many business processes rely on manual data handling outside of dedicated IT tools e.g., within IDP’s. This lack of system integration prevents effective data flow controls, increasing the risk of errors and malicious activity, especially when data is shared externally via email. Also, reliance on IDP solutions and manual activities introduces an additional risk layer. Recent data leakage incidents demonstrated this, with IDP malfunction identified as one of the root causes. This lack of resilience and scalability creates multiple points of failure in the business processes, particularly under pressure. Strategic DLP approaches and risk assessments must specifically address these vulnerabilities.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require financial entities continuously identify all ICT risk sources. In accordance with their ICT risk management framework, they shall minimize the ICT risk impact by deploying appropriate strategies, policies, procedures, protocols and tools. Appropriate technical and organizational measures shall be implemented to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk. The IT systems, the related processes and other information domain elements shall ensure data confidentiality.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. With support from 1LoD business, coordinate the initial DBG-wide identification of critical data (“data crown jewels”) on business/entity line level. 16.10.2025 30.04.2026 30.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sebastian Wedeniwski Thomas Kemmerer Thomas Kemmerer HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Technology Officer (A) Chief Technology Officer (ZJS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Absence of a comprehensive DBG data leakage prevention (DLP) concept to protect critical data assets results in particularly serious weaknesses in the DLP internal control system. Without identification of “data crown jewels” and a comprehensive DLP risk assessment, DBG cannot effectively prevent data leakage, especially considering the reliance on non-standard IT processes for handling critical data.
