Ultimately, this could result in the loss of client trust in DBG. Sebastian Wedeniwski ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy ,45,CSDR 909/2014
2025-099_F01 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Absence of a comprehensive DBG data leakage prevention concept to protect critical data assets DBG lacks a data leakage prevention  (DLP) concept as foundation for structured, comprehensive and risk-based protection against data leakage. As a consequence, the measures to reduce data leakage risk implemented at DBG have not been derived from a defined DLP concept and, in their entirety, do not form an effective DLP capability.

Specifically, DBG failed to:
§ Establish DLP-specific data classification, especially defining and identifying its most critical data (“data crown jewels”). The way application-level information classification was implemented does not enable and support identification of “data crown jewels” in DBG. Also, it does not consider multiple possible criteria such as critical and important functions and competition-critical importance. Furthermore, existing document classification (labeling) measures are independent from data criticality and are not consistently enforced for manual processes involving data extracts such as IDPs.
§ Conduct a risk assessment to comprehensively define and identify data exfiltration points and establish leakage scenarios against which this data needs protection.
§ Define risk metrics/requirements catalogue for safeguarding data from being leaked depending on its criticality.
§ Determine suitable technical preventive controls based on a comprehensive DLP concept.
§ Implement effective oversight measures to monitor control effectiveness and detect breaches.

In detail, Internal Audit identified several gaps in data classification, safeguarding and data leakage risk management:

Data classification and safeguarding
§ DBG has not defined, identified, or inventoried its most sensitive data assets ("data crown jewels"). Also, there is no comprehensive requirements catalogue for safeguarding data from leakage based on criticality. This lack of a top-down approach prevents focused controls on the highest risks associated with potential data leakage of the most critical data.
§ The implemented information classification (bottom-up approach) did not result in a manageable scope of IT systems containing the most critical data. The information classification is not consistently derived from considerations of key dimensions e.g., critical and important functions, personally identifiable information (PII) or data supporting strategic decisions. As of July 1, 2025, 279 IT applications were classified with the highest confidentiality level (“critical”), requiring the strictest data leakage controls across a broad scope of targets.
§ 2LoD ICT Risk Management has not defined the information classification risk levels (Critical/Major/Minor/Negligible). These were only defined in the 1LoD (Group Security) written rules.

Data leakage risk management
§ The DLP control system lacks a foundation in a comprehensive, systematic, and documented risk assessment, failing to adequately address two key aspects:
- Data leakage paths: The current IT application-based risk assessment lacks a strategic DLP approach, resulting in incomplete identification and management of key data leakage risks. For example, some file types in use (e.g., .csv) lack classification requirements; email blocking controls are limited to Excel and strictly confidential files only and can easily be circumvented. See also finding 2025-099_F04 for further details.
- Data processing risks outside dedicated IT tools: Due to limited system functionality or lacking customer/service/user features, many business processes rely on manual data handling outside of dedicated IT tools e.g., within IDP’s. This lack of system integration prevents effective data flow controls, increasing the risk of errors and malicious activity, especially when data is shared externally via email. Also, reliance on IDP solutions and manual activities introduces an additional risk layer. Recent data leakage incidents demonstrated this, with IDP malfunction identified as one of the root causes. This lack of resilience and scalability creates multiple points of failure in the business processes, particularly under pressure. Strategic DLP approaches and risk assessments must specifically address these vulnerabilities.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require financial entities continuously identify all ICT risk sources. In accordance with their ICT risk management framework, they shall minimize the ICT risk impact by deploying appropriate strategies, policies, procedures, protocols and tools. Appropriate technical and organizational measures shall be implemented to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk. The IT systems, the related processes and other information domain elements shall ensure data confidentiality.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. In liaison with other stakeholders from the 2LoD and 1LoD, establish a comprehensive data leakage prevention (DLP) strategy to effectively manage the data leakage risk. In particular, this should include a staggered approach for mitigating the data leakage risk to accommodate tactical and strategic measures including:
§ Enhance 2LoD DLP written rules via:
- defining minimum control requirements for 1LoD depending on the data criticality and specific communication channel
- defining control requirements for assessing the data leakage risk by 1LoD.
§ Define information classification risk levels (Critical/Major/Minor/Negligible) in the 2LoD framework to ensure its consistent use throughout at least the relevant legal entities listed in this finding (2025-099_F01).
§ Evaluate possibilities to:
- reduce DBG’s risk surface e.g., limiting the personal use of business IT
- leverage on the possible communication channel scanning capabilities for e.g., email scanning
- prevent/detect circumvention of email DLP controls by renaming file extensions and changing labels.
§ Define a high-level guidance for identification and documenting of the most critical data (“data crown jewels”).
§ Establish the data flow registry as overview of all data flows related to data crown jewels in at least the relevant entities listed in this finding (2025-099_F01).		 16.10.2025 30.01.2026 30.01.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Christian Gorke Thomas Kemmerer Thomas Kemmerer HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (Dpt) Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (ICT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Absence of a comprehensive DBG data leakage prevention (DLP) concept to protect critical data assets results in particularly serious weaknesses in the DLP internal control system. Without identification of “data crown jewels” and a comprehensive DLP risk assessment, DBG cannot effectively prevent data leakage, especially considering the reliance on non-standard IT processes for handling critical data. Consequences of such a breach could lead to long lasting negative publicity in international media, ad-hoc regulatory examinations, as well as critical financial impact in case of fines related to data breaches. Ultimately, this could result in the loss of client trust in DBG. Christian Gorke ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy ,45,CSDR 909/2014
2025-099_F02 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S3 Serious gaps in awareness of data content and criticality Analysis of recent data leakage incidents across Clearstream entities revealed serious staff awareness gaps regarding the nature, sensitivity, and criticality of handled data. Such limited awareness – demonstrated by e.g., sharing extensive customer data with unauthorized recipients – may have contributed to these incidents, underscoring the importance of robust data classification and handling practices.

Due to insufficient data awareness and sensitivity, the current Data Leakage Prevention (DLP) trainings, as the key awareness measures, require enhancement. Specifically, the following elements have not yet been incorporated:

§ Targeted role-based data awareness and criticality training program, including:
- Mandatory training modules covering data types, handling procedures, and real-world company-specific examples of data misuse and consequences.
- Content customized for specific roles, particularly client-facing staff exposed to sensitive data.
§ Reinforced Data Leakage Prevention awareness by integration of DLP awareness into onboarding processes.
§ Reinforced Data Leakage Prevention as part of refresher training.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require all individuals working in financial entities continuously have a good understanding of the core principles of GDPR, including awareness of data subject rights, the importance of data minimization and purpose limitation, and the requirements for secure data processing. ESMA guidelines frequently refer to and build upon the GDPR principles and address specific requirements for financial institutions, such as reporting obligations, data sharing between market participants, and the handling of market data. Employees need to be aware of and comply with these sector-specific rules.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. In collaboration with Management & SMEs of relevant areas, especially Clearstream’s Chief Information Security Officer, enhance the current data training program by following measures:
§ Provide design and implementation roadmap of mandatory Data Leakage Prevention training module covering motivation, data types, data handling procedures, and real-world company-specific examples of data misuse and consequences.
§ Provide design and implementation roadmap of company-specific and role-based training program for specific roles, prioritizing client-facing staff.
§ Provide design and implementation roadmap of mandatory Data Leakage Prevention training as part of the onboarding process, including Data Leakage Prevention policies and their connection to daily tasks.
§ Ensure that Data Leakage Prevention trainings effectiveness is reflected in cybersecurity training metrics.		 16.10.2025 03.04.2026 03.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Christian Gorke Predrag Adamovic Thomas Kemmerer HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (Dpt) Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (ICT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious gaps in awareness of data content and criticality due to insufficient understanding among staff members about the sensitivity and importance of various data types handled within the organization represent a substantial vulnerability to data security and safeguarding. This lack of awareness increases the risk of unintentional data incidents, such as inadvertent disclosure, improper handling, or accidental deletion of sensitive information. Furthermore, it might impair ability to identify such incidents and prevent appropriate mitigation. This could lead to regulatory fines, reputational damage, and financial losses. The gaps in awareness of data content and criticality are particularly concerning, given the increasing regulatory scrutiny, the rise in data breaches across industries, and the organization’s reliance on data not only for operational and strategic decision-making but also as a core driver of revenue generation. Christian Gorke ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Europe AG) Inadequate Processes CSDR 909/2014, 44,45
2025-099_F03 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F03-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Fragmentation within the existing incident management coverage & operationalization for data leakage While the existence of the ICT incident management procedure is acknowledged, Internal Audit identified fragmentation within the existing incident management coverage and operationalization for data leakage, and therefore the need for enhancement and harmonization across the Group:
§ Incident scope definitions varied significantly between functions, with overlapping and sometimes conflicting categorizations that hindered a unified understanding of incident types. As a result, depending on the point where an incident is identified in the organization, the incident response may take a different route involving different stakeholders in the absence of a central single-entry point for all incident types
§ Roles and responsibilities, in particular the assignment and responsibility of the (business) incident manager, were not clearly defined across all domains. Partially, incident response and escalation paths lacked standardization, contributing to confusion in situations requiring both cross-functional and cross-legal-entity coordination.

Analysis of the recent Clearstream data leakage incidents identified a lack of clear ownership and responsibilities for managing such incidents across different business functions and legal entities. The process did not ensure that a person or function is formally designated to manage the aftermath of a data leakage incident from end to end. This led to the situation that responsibilities were individually discussed between various stakeholders with no predefined responsibility for coordinating the incident response, for timely and systematically involving other necessary stakeholders, and for informing relevant parties.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations address incident and crisis management, particularly regarding data leakage and operational resilience i.e., business continuity management, often building upon each other.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. In collaboration with Group Security (ZZA) and relevant business areas, extend the existing ICT incident management procedure:
§ Evaluate and expand coverage to further relevant incident types, especially data leakage i.e., also include non-ICT relevant incident types
§ Review the established RACI and call trees for ICT incident management to also include relevant contact persons / duty managers from businesses/functions/LEs, as well as central functions (e.g., Legal, Compliance, Data Protection, CISO and other key stakeholders), required for the management of the added incident types
§ Enhance RACI within the procedure for handover of relevant classified incidents to the predefined responsible business areas or individuals for end-to-end management and resolution (incident manager role and responsibilities must be clearly defined for each incident management process step), with the CERT maintaining an oversight role if needed
§ Include the central incident entry point / dispatcher role in the ICT incident procedure as and when defined		 16.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Boris Link, Sean Mc Taggart, Dafina Polloshka Vrenezi Simona Gaffarelli Thomas Kemmerer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Fragmentation within the existing incident management coverage and operationalization for data leakage leads to inconsistent incident response, resulting in potentially flawed handling of incidents. Without clear ownership and defined responsibilities for managing particularly data leakage incidents across different business functions and legal entities, communication paths can be unclear, hindering effective escalation, timely resolution and reporting across the different segments and stakeholders, and to authorities and customers when necessary. Finally, the absence of a central entry point for the incident management process makes it difficult to ensure identification and involvement of all relevant stakeholders, consistent application of incident management best practices and to identify systemic weaknesses. These combined issues increase the risk of significant negative impacts on business operations, reputation, and regulatory compliance. Boris Link CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inadequate Processes CSDR 909/2014,44,45
2025-099_F03 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F03-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Fragmentation within the existing incident management coverage & operationalization for data leakage While the existence of the ICT incident management procedure is acknowledged, Internal Audit identified fragmentation within the existing incident management coverage and operationalization for data leakage, and therefore the need for enhancement and harmonization across the Group:
§ Incident scope definitions varied significantly between functions, with overlapping and sometimes conflicting categorizations that hindered a unified understanding of incident types. As a result, depending on the point where an incident is identified in the organization, the incident response may take a different route involving different stakeholders in the absence of a central single-entry point for all incident types
§ Roles and responsibilities, in particular the assignment and responsibility of the (business) incident manager, were not clearly defined across all domains. Partially, incident response and escalation paths lacked standardization, contributing to confusion in situations requiring both cross-functional and cross-legal-entity coordination.

Analysis of the recent Clearstream data leakage incidents identified a lack of clear ownership and responsibilities for managing such incidents across different business functions and legal entities. The process did not ensure that a person or function is formally designated to manage the aftermath of a data leakage incident from end to end. This led to the situation that responsibilities were individually discussed between various stakeholders with no predefined responsibility for coordinating the incident response, for timely and systematically involving other necessary stakeholders, and for informing relevant parties.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations address incident and crisis management, particularly regarding data leakage and operational resilience i.e., business continuity management, often building upon each other.		 Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Establish a centralized incident management entry point:
§ Ensure a swift and organized initial response by designating the CERT (Cyber Emergency Response Team) as the central entry point (dispatcher) for all incident types according to the revised ICT incident management procedure (see recommendation F03-A01) to perform the initial track setting (assignment of incident manager and initial information of predefined stakeholders as provided by IT Governance, Risk and Transformation [IRT] depending on the type of the incident).
§ Promote the contact details of the CERT as entry point (dispatcher) for all relevant incident types.		 16.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Hinrich Völcker, Olga Wenge Simona Gaffarelli Thomas Kemmerer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Group Security (Dpt) Group Security (ZZA) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Fragmentation within the existing incident management coverage and operationalization for data leakage leads to inconsistent incident response, resulting in potentially flawed handling of incidents. Without clear ownership and defined responsibilities for managing particularly data leakage incidents across different business functions and legal entities, communication paths can be unclear, hindering effective escalation, timely resolution and reporting across the different segments and stakeholders, and to authorities and customers when necessary. Finally, the absence of a central entry point for the incident management process makes it difficult to ensure identification and involvement of all relevant stakeholders, consistent application of incident management best practices and to identify systemic weaknesses. These combined issues increase the risk of significant negative impacts on business operations, reputation, and regulatory compliance. Hinrich Völcker CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inadequate Processes CSDR 909/2014,44,45
2025-099_F04 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in DLP controls for blocking outbound emails with attachments Internal Audit (IA) specifically reviewed the data leakage prevention (DLP) environment for email as the most used path for outbound communication, which played a central role in recent Clearstream data leakage incidents. IA identified the following gaps in controls for email DLP enforcement and exception management, leading to weaknesses in blocking outbound emails with attachments, especially unlabeled ones:
§ Email DLP is based on rules to block outgoing emails depending on their labeling. Hence, unlabeled email attachments can be sent out to external recipients and will not be blocked. This topic is also covered in the ongoing Ameli project (Tz. 170/171 CEU/ECAG). However, only a limited set of file types, i.e., Microsoft Office and PDF, are required to be labeled.
§ The new DLP rule for blocking non-labeled Microsoft Office and PDF files, planned to go live in June 2025, has not been implemented yet due to a bug within Office365.
§ As a first reaction to the recent data leakage incidents, Excel attachments have been blocked by default from being sent out externally starting April 2025. However, about 1,200 exceptions have been maintained in DBG’s IIQ central access rights management system for employees of different legal entities, allowing them to send out Excel attachments to external recipients. In addition, such exceptions have been maintained for about 280 shared mailboxes. This gap has been addressed during the audit as part of the Clearstream initiative for enhancing email DLP.
§ In general, it is possible to circumvent email DLP controls by renaming file extensions and by changing the label. This gap will be addressed as part of the 2025-099_F01 finding.
§ On the intranet information page “Classification and Labeling” it was incorrectly stated that emails with unlabeled attachments will not be sent. This gap has been addressed during the audit.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require financial entities use ICT solutions and processes preventing impairment of authenticity and integrity, confidentiality breaches and data loss. 		 Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. Implement the new DLP rule for blocking non-labeled MS Office and PDF files and establish a control that enforces labeling for:
§ newly created MS Office and PDF files upon saving
§ PDF files received via email, downloaded, or created with PDF tools
§ all existing MS Office and PDF files, before sending them externally

Part of the first bullet point, related to MS Office files, has been adequately addressed before audit report issuance.		 16.10.2025 20.03.2026 20.03.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Benoit Krier Thomas Kemmerer Thomas Kemmerer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Microsoft 365 Operations (U) Microsoft 365 Operations (ZFR) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Gaps in DLP controls for blocking outbound emails with attachments increase the risk of data leakage via email, with potential data leakage incidents resulting in reputational damage such as negative publicity in regional media. Furthermore, this might lead to material adverse regulatory impact, such as potential for extra reporting requirements and/or regulatory examinations and financial penalties. Benoit Krier CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inadequate Processes CSDR 909/2014,45
2025-099_F05 2025 2025-099 Special Audit - Data Leakage Prevention 2025-099_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the control design for database extracts Although individual procedures for handling data extract requests have been implemented by IT product teams, Internal Audit noted the following weaknesses:
§ Minimum DBG requirements were not defined for data extracts on database level, outside of application-based controls. As a result, complete and consistent control cannot be ensured throughout DBG.
§ Inconsistent approval processes for data extraction requests, with varying approvers (e.g., Information Owners, Business Application Owners), do not ensure appropriate authorization. The completeness of approvals is particularly required in multitenant environments like SAP which house data from multiple legal entities without segregation.
§ Sensitivity labels for output files (e.g., Excel) are not enforced based on source data classification.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require financial entities use ICT solutions and processes preventing impairment of authenticity and integrity, confidentiality breaches and data loss.		 Control Design Effectiveness In collaboration with Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (ICT), and independent of the strategic addressing of data management gaps, consider tactical measures to strengthen and harmonize controls over production data extracts. This includes at least defining the requirements for challenge and approval processes, as well as guidance for applying sensitivity labels to files containing production data extracts. 16.10.2025 15.04.2026 15.04.2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Europe AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Boris Link, Sean Mc Taggart, Dafina Polloshka Vrenezi Thomas Kemmerer Thomas Kemmerer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the control design for database extracts might lead to breaches of the need-to-know principle and increase the risk of data being handled without appropriate authorization. Furthermore, missing sensitivity labels might impair the effectiveness of data leakage prevention controls, especially regarding emails. This is a material violation of internal and external provisions, such as a minor breach of regulatory requirements with limited regulatory impact. Boris Link CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Europe AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inadequate Processes CSDR 909/2014,45
